reviews.content: I watched this film as I've recently finished the Stephen King novel that it is based on, so I wanted to see how the two compared.Short answer, the film is just as good as the novel.Kathy Bates is absolutely brilliant but terrifying as Annie Wilkes. She is very much the fangirl from hell. I was also surprised by James Caan. I've only seen him in the Godfather and his character of the timid, scared Paul Sheldon was a far-cry from the ultra-masculine Santino Corleone. Yet he played Paul Sheldon well and demonstrated his versatility as an actor. Read my full review for more: http://goo.gl/07sRxX

reviews.review_title: One of my absolute favorites, a true classic!!
reviews.content: Oh my gosh, one of the most well deserved Oscar wins of all time!!! Kathy Bates was a shining star in this movie! She really brought Annie Wilkes to life on the big screen! I have not read the book, but I don't need to in order to KNOW that this is a fantastic movie! I really don't know how anyone could hate this masterpiece! And also I love how the film makers didn't bog it down with constant profanity and sex! It was fairly clean for an R rated film. It's obvious why this is considered a Classic! I watch it every time it comes on a channel on TV, I never miss it! There are just "those" movies that never get old, you can watch them a gazillion times, and every time is as great as the last!

Misery is the tale of Paul Sheldon A famous writer who gets into a car accident and comes in to the care of a psycotic nurse Annie Wikes who will do anything to change his upcoming novel.
Misery is a psychological thriller Directed by Rob Reiner and it;s based of the Stephen King Novel by the same name this is one of King's classic stories that really gets under your skin and makes you afraid of fame and to me it's one of the best that has been adapted from King and if i was suggesting what movies based of King for someone to watch it would be 2017's IT The Shining and this one.
In the cast is James Caan {Paul Sheldon} Kathy Bates {Annie Wilkes} Richard Farnsworth {Buster} Frances Sternhagen {Virginia} Lauren Bacall {Marcia Sindell} And Graham Jarvis {Libby} James Cann is amazing as paul Sheldon and he is great I don't have words to describe how great he is play mental games with Annie and Kathy Bates giving her best preformace as Annie and man she is so amazing and she desereved that oscar for this movie and to this day I can remember how great the hobbling scence is and how terrifying she was in that scene.
what can you say about misery it's a great psychological thriller that plays on the fear of people and what people can do and that being famous can have it's consequences and what obesseion from a fan can do and it's a must watch thriler.

What we have here is a decent movie, with decent acting (for the most part) and a good story which avoids the supernatural element that turns me off a lot of Stephen King's work. Having said that, what we also have here is a movie that - in my opinion - didn't reach the heights that are often claimed for it.James Caan was believable (albeit surprisingly unemotional I thought, given the circumstances) as writer Paul Sheldon, "rescued" from a car accident by his self-proclaimed biggest fan Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates) who then holds him hostage to force him to write a novel bringing back her favourite character (Misery) whom he had killed off in the last installment in the series. Bates is clearly the star of this movie, earning her Oscar. Her performance as the insane Annie is very believable (although, I thought, at times a little too over the top.) Richard Farnsworth on the other hand (as Sheriff McCain) I found irritating and totally unnecessary (and, although I have never read the novel on which this is based, I understand that his character was added to the movie, for no apparent reason that I could see.) Rob Reiner directed. This was his second go-round as director of a movie based on a King work. I thought his work on "Stand By Me" was better.This certainly isn't a bad movie. It's suspenseful, edge of your seat stuff a lot of the time. It just lacks consistent power, something that I think a better choice than James Caan and the total elimination of Farnsworth might have helped. Note: this is also a very violent movie in places, the scene in which Annie "hobbles" Sheldon being particularly disturbing.6/10

I am a big Stephen King fan. I have been ever since I picked up the book night shift. But I gotta say, his stuff never really translates well onto film.First, let me say that I thought the acting was fantastic. Kathy Bates deserved the Oscar! James Caan was also first rate in the movie. The problem with the movie had nothing to do with them. I'm not even sure it had anything to do with the director or producers.It was actually quite hard to figure out what bothered me about this movie (other than the fact that I have no deep seeded need to see someones ankles broken!)until my mom pointed out that Stephen King understands something that a lot of horror/psychological thriller writers seemed to have either forgotten or missed and that is that anything you can imaging is much (bigger, hairier, sharper, just plain scarier) than anything I can show you. Once you put it on the screen, you take the director's view of what's scary shoved at you. If that view isn't one that scares the viewer personally, then the movie misses and the scares are just not there.This movie didn't scare me any more than someone jumping around the corner yelling "boo" at me. It didn't make me think, it didn't disturb me, heck...it didn't even say "boo" that loudly! If you want a REALLY good Stephen King movie, go for Carrie instead.I'm giving this movie out of 10 because the acting was good.

reviews.review_title: Not as intense as the book, but more darkly comedic
reviews.content: Ironically, the novel "Misery"--while as much about the nature of fan/celebrity relationships as the writing process itself, is not one of Stephen King's better-written works. Coming in at a relatively lean (for him) 338 pages, the novel IS a relentlessly intense tale of mounting terror and palpable desperation. Condensed by William Goldman into a more conventional, three-act narrative (the novel is essentially a prolonged standoff between the 2 main characters) and directed by Rob Reiner ("This Is Spinal Tap"), some of the novel's intensity has been lost, instead replaced by a gallows humor that hits more often than misses. Upon completion of his latest novel, best-selling author Paul Sheldon (James Caan) hops in his vintage Challenger just as a snowstorm comes up and sweeps him off a winding mountain road; he is rescued by Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates), an ex-nurse who resides on a well-isolated farm and is a raving psychotic. Reiner does a good job establishing the confined setting, amplified in Sheldon's own vain attempts at escape, while alternating with the husband-and-wife Sheriff-and-Deputy team (Richard Farnsworth and Frances Sternhagen in delicious roles) conducting their own search for the missing author. Caan and Bates play off one another wonderfully, and retain the "jousting" effect of King's characters; Bates, especially, becomes a well-rationed blend of the Terminator and a typical, small-town woman (complete with phrases like "cock-a-dookie")--a performance that could have veered into camp, but maintains a veneer of disturbing realism throughout.

Rob Reiner did a fantastic job in the direction of this film. What didn't go right was the adaptation, as usual. The "toning down" of the scenes and events for this movie was an atrocious way to rewrite this wonderful, if somewhat short for King, novel.Kathy Bates is exceptional in her role as Annie Wilkes, a fan of (James Caan) Paul Sheldon's novels. Finding him stranded and unconscious in a snowdrift, she takes him home and attends to his needs until he regains consciousness. That's when the weirdness begins; in the movie's story, as well as the wide angle shots perpetrated upon the actors in their close ups. The deviations from the principal storyline really took away from this movie a great deal. That having been said, the feeling of discorporation you experience from the cinematography of the movie leaves you feeling disturbed and unsettled. Classic King. But again, the deviations just left me saying within the first 15 minutes ... WTF?! It was commonly predictable, horribly off-kilter, and widely uneven. The performances were perfect, but the adaptation left too much to be desired for this to be even moderately enjoyable.It rates a 4.0/10 from...the Fiend :.

There isn't much more to say about "Misery" that hasn't already been said. Cathy Bates may have stolen the show, but playing against James Caan's low-key style made her performance even more arresting. After an accident in a remote location, famed novelist, Paul Sheldon (James Caan), is kept prisoner by his most ardent fan, a nurse named Annie Wilkes (Cathy Bates). There are many twists to the story, but shockingly, she stops him from escaping by breaking his ankles (in Stephen King's novel she cuts off one of his feet). Although the story is unusual, it reminded me of a few I had come across before. John Fowles "The Collector" is an obvious one, and even gets a mention in the novel "Misery", but others are also interesting. Years ago, I used to love those collections of horror stories from Alfred Hitchcock and Pan Books etc. One was "Marmalade Wine" by Joan Aiken, which I read in the "First Fontana Book Of Horror Stories" in 1966. It was about a guy called Roger Hacker who goes for a walk through the woods and meets a once a famous surgeon who lives there as a recluse. Hacker unwisely boasts that he can predict the future, and the doctor invites him to sample his homemade wine. When Hacker awakens from a drug-induced slumber, he realizes he won't be walking home any time soon - the doctor has amputated his feet. It was actually made into an episode of "Rod Serling's Night Gallery" around 1970. Another along the same theme is "The Man who liked Dickens" by Evelyn Waugh, which I first encountered in "The Ninth Fontana Book Of Horror Stories" although it was actually written in 1933. It became a sequence in the novel, and then the film, "A Handful of Dust".In that one, Tony Last, while on an expedition in Brazil, ends up alone and fever-ridden in the jungle. He is found by Mr. Todd and taken to his home in a remote village. When he recovers from his illness, he is happy to comply with the illiterate Mr. Todd's request to read aloud to him for a couple of hours each day. As the days go by, then weeks, Tony realizes that Mr. Todd has no intention of allowing him to leave...ever."Misery" takes its story to a different conclusion, but keeps the tension ramped up all the way. The film emerges as one the most disturbing types of horror story. Like "Psycho", "Wolf Creek", and "Seven", there is no supernatural explanation to screen us from events that could really happen. In the end, "Misery" leaves one a little more wary of one's fans.

reviews.review_title: Could have been great, ended up just good
reviews.content: Stephen King's stories are great cinematic material - there's a couple I can think of in IMDb's Top 250 - and Misery has a similarly strong story. Beneath the storyline, however, I wasn't massively intrigued: the acting felt a bit over-the-top (maybe slightly too retro and 90s for me), and the music was of a similar ilk.All in all, I felt that this film will be remembered more for the story than anything else. Set in the frozen landscape of Colorado's backcountry and following a writer finishing his defining novel, Misery is brilliant at setting a scene. This story is unique in its dynamics, and the acting of Kathy Bates (who won an Oscar for her role) is befittingly scary and unpredictable.Unfortunately, some of stylistic choices are a bit bizarre. Considering the setting, not much of Colorado's scope is used in the film; further to this, some of the "high tension" moments felt forced, sapping a degree of drama from the scenes.I am a big Stephen King fan - I just don't think this was the best adaptation there could have been, and time has not been kind.

reviews.review_title: Kathy Bates hasn't failed me yet!
reviews.content: Paul Sheldon is a popular horror author who has written the fictional Misery series, and carries his work to his agent in his beloved old brown portfolio case. When his car crashes in the snow in a small town and he's knocked out, he's rescued by Annie, a prolific fan who has a very average, almost boring, look to her. She's a little eccentric, Paul notices, when she does things such as bringing a pet sow named Misery to his bedside and makes pig noises at him as she leads Misery out of the room (it's hilarious), but when her nutty antics take a turn towards psychopathic and he discovers a horrifying incident that may have happened during her career as a hospital nurse involving newborn babies, he realizes he has to escape at any cost.This is a wonderful movie and Kathy Bates is just as good in her role as obsessed fan Annie as she was as battered housewife in Dolores Claiborne. The soundtrack was eerie and the plot was disturbing but thrilling, everything a great horror film should be! I'm not gonna lie, I am not always a Stephen King fan, especially when it comes to the 2013 remake of Carrie, and I'm dreading the possible remake of Firestarter. But Some Stephen King films like Pet Sematary, Dolores Claiborne, It and Christine are very good. Misery is no exception, it's one of the better King films.

You can say that this movie puts the protagonist into such misery throughout. Paul is broken up from his car crash and is being tended by a random woman who helped him who's his number one fan of his novels. She is so obsessed with him that she starts to do anything to keep him incapable of leaving her house. She's a psycho and Kathy Bates definitely shows why she won an Oscar for this role. She forces him to rewrite his latest novel since she didn't like the latest one that he wrote. The ending is so satisfying since he gets the typewriter that he was using and bangs her head with it and eventually kills her with a good brawl.
It's great and it is one of the best adaptations of a Stephen King novel.

This is a super black comedy drama that has not aged despite being made around 25 years ago. A famous writer is "rescued" from a car crash by an obsessed fan and what follows is a tour-de-force between kidnapper and her captive. The lead female deservedly won an Oscar for her performance as the fan and the male lead not far behind in his portrayal of the victim writer. It aids the story that it takes place in a remote snow bound town, adding to the atmosphere with spectacular scenery. Excellent supporting cast especially the sheriff and his wife whose chemistry together is charismatic. Another stand out performance is Misery the pig who even up stages the late Lauren Bacall whose role is minimal but worthy. The production as a whole ought to be a lesson to all film makers on how to make an entertaining and compelling drama:8/10

When I first read the book Misery, I thought it was wonderful and when I found out there was a movie based on it, I couldn't wait to see it. Anyways, Misery is about a writer named Paul Sheldon(James Caan) who gets into a terrible car accident and a crazed fan of his Annie Wilkes(Kathy Bates) saves him and makes him a prisoner in her home. Nobody knows where Paul is and there is no way that Paul can escape with his terribly injured legs. But Annie has other plans for him, she wants him to write a sequel for her favorite character "Misery Chastaine". And Paul better obey her, because Annie is his number one fan and she's never going to let him go now. The movie didn't quite follow the book but I still enjoyed it. In the book, Annie Wilkes was way more crazier and violent which was the main reason that I loved the book. Also the movie missed some of the main events in the book that were totally gruesome and gripping and really showed how crazy Annie was. But overall it was a good movie and a wonderful book. Also Kathy Bates gives a great performance. I would give Misery 6.5/10

reviews.review_title: Kathy Bates+ James Caan= A Great Horror Film ( contains spoilers)
reviews.content: The movie is great, there is no other way to describe it. It is about a writer who crashes his car and a crazed fan finds him. She takes care of him, like a normal person, but healing time and resting are not in the picture. She turns violent. Hits him, tortures him so badly. He tries to escape but she always finds out that he tried. Since, he is retiring from writing, his last book, misery (title) dies. She does not like it. She makes him write another one, and Sooner or Later an old cop is murdered by her and she eventually dies. So if you want more. Watch the film.I love this movie so much. Kathy bates gives a Oscar winning performance and James Caan, the perfect victim. The movie adds up and has twists and turns. the perfect movie. SO PERFECT!!!10/10

reviews.review_title: Amazing horror film with Brilliant Bates
reviews.content: I've never read any of Stephen King's novels but this disturbing thriller from director Rob Reiner may push me to start.James Caan (The Godfather) stars as writer Paul Sheldon who is taken in by fan Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates) This claustrophobic thriller provides twists and turns at every corner and can be very unsettling at many points. The famous hobbling scene had me turning away instantly, a truly remarkable moment in the horror genre. This is definitely not for the faint hearted.Kathy Bates plays a remarkable part as obsessive the obsessive fan and housekeeper Wilkes and rightfully won the Oscar for best actress.The plot is extremely gripping, moving and is filmed at the required pace to capture the tension necessary to create wonderful drama.The fact that the main scenes are in a house in the middle of nowhere provides delicious claustrophobia to the plot and situation proving central protagonist Sheldon has a mountain to climb.Caan is also splendid as the caught off guard writer. His performance is not a patch on Bates' but the two still have wonderful chemistry on screen.the ending too is quite shocking and is worth waiting around for.It's a remarkable horror thriller film and is worth watching simply for bates' character and performance.

This has got to be the best king adaptation from book to movie.The story, The Best-selling novelist Paul Sheldon is on his way home from his Colorado hideaway after completing his latest book, when he crashes his car in a freak blizzard. Paul is critically injured, but is rescued by former nurse Annie Wilkes, Paul's "number one fan", who takes Paul back to her remote house in the mountains (without bothering to tell anybody). Unfortunately for Paul, Annie is also a head case. When she discovers that Paul has killed off the heroine in her favourite novels, her reaction leaves Paul shattered (literally)...I was on edge of my seat watching this movie, one scenes made me look away from scene did make me look away, it some scenes I was shouting at at the screen.Kathy Bates was incredible in this movie, she was fantastic playing evil Annie Wilkes so well in this movie and James Caan was Fantantic too.A Great Thriller, I give this movie a 10 out 10

Yet another hit King adaptation that's practically perfect and a horror classic. Again it excels at everything Carrie did but Misery is surprisingly more tense throughout. Of course a big round of praise for the actors Kathy Bates and James Caan who practically make this film. It doesn't really show much up until the end and lesser actors would absolutely not be able to sell the amount of tension and fear that's required to keep this one interesting. I mean the whole setting is claustrophobic and small yet Misery never feels restricted or dull through its hour and forty minute runtime. In fact, most of the time the film is at its weakest when it deviates from the farm and focuses more on the Sheriff character, I still don't understand what he contributes to the story. The ending is also a bit of a letdown as you can tell it must've been filmed rushed or as an afterthought, but everything else, super good.

An enthralling plot (well it is Stephen King), superb acting from Bates and Caan, a cracking soundtrack, and the iconic 'hobbling scene' which really is the icing on the top... what's not to like? Would highly recommend a watch!

reviews.review_title: One of the Better King Adaptations
reviews.content: Misery (1990)*** 1/2 (out of 4) Author Paul Sheldon (James Caan) has finished his latest novel and is trying to drive down from his mountain resort when his car goes over a cliff and crashes. Soon he wakes up in the home of nurse Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates) who claims to be his number one fan. She begins to bring him back to health but before long the writer realizes that this woman isn't all there mentally.MISERY is a rare Stephen King adaptation that actually manages to be extremely good and director Rob Reiner certainly deserves a lot of the credit. He takes the story and does an extremely good job with it and manages to bring out not only the deeply disturbing elements but also some black comedy that was certainly needed to balance out some of the more shocking and graphic moments.Of course, when you've got such a terrific cast in the roles that's a major plus. Bates picked up a Best Actress Oscar for her role of the troubled nurse and no matter how many times you watch the movie you can't help but enjoy her performance even more. This "nut" character has a lot of different personalities that come out here and the actress nails them all. You can believe her soft-spoken sweet nurse and in a split second you can buy her raging psychopath. Caan has never gotten the credit he deserves but he too is wonderful here and especially when you consider that the majority of the time he's stuck in a wheelchair or a bed. Both Richard Farnsworth and Frances Sternhagen are great in their parts and even Lauren Bacall is given a good role.The film features some pretty graphic violence including that "one" scene. If you've seen the movie then you already know what that "one" scene is because once you see it you'll never forget it. If you haven't seen the movie, trust me, when you get to this scene you'll know what I'm talking about. The movie also benefits from some wonderful cinematography, a terrific score and William Goldman's screenplay hits all the right notes. There are some really dark moments here that are hard to watch but as I mentioned earlier, the black humor really helps.Reiner had previously worked wonders with King's STAND BY MEN so he obviously knows how to handle the material. He certainly milks ever bit of suspense and tension that he can out of the material and makes MISERY one of King's adaptations that really works.

Writer Stephen King is considered among the most important contributors to the horror genre of the last times. Wheter the quality of his work is good or bad is up to the reader; what can't be denied, is that his inventive stories have been of major importance for cinema as almost everyone has been adapted to film. Naturally, the quality of those adaptations range from awfully bad to superb masterpieces. "Misery" locates closer to the latter as it is one of the best horror movies ever made.Kathy Bates gives the performance of her life as Anne Wilkes, a lonely ex-nurse that rescues writer Paul Sheldon (James Caan) from a near death as his car crashed during a snow storm. To Paul's surprise, Anne Wilkes is one of the biggest fans of his romance series, "Misery". While Anne takes care of Paul, he discovers that his number one fan may not be sane, and hell breaks loose as soon as Annie discovers that in the last Misery novel, the main character dies. Her obsession with the story will take its toll in Paul's health, as her psychotic nature will be revealed.Director Rob Reiner and writer William Goldman turned King's novel into gold, as their adaptation is superb and according to fans, superior to the novel. The story unfolds at a nice rhythm and it never drags nor gets boring. While it is not a faithful adaptation, it keeps the suspense and the tension is always at peak, it keeps you at the border of the seat.What really makes the movie are the performances of the cast. Bates & Caan have a big chemistry on screen and they were perfect in their roles. Kathy Bates's take on Anne Wilkes has become a classic performance as it is a perfect portrait of the insane obsession the character has with his idol. Truly believable at any moment, she manages to go from sweetheart to psycho in seconds, in a breathtaking Tour-De-Force that won her an Oscar.James Caan is equally great as Sheldon, but I'd like to show some respect to Richard Farnsworth. His performance as the sheriff was top-notch and another one of the long chain of great underrated performances of his career. He wasn't an actor playing a sheriff, he truly captured the spirit of an old cop in a small town.If a flaw is to be found in the movie, I would say that at times it has a "TV movie" feeling. However, it is maybe that subtle approach to visuals what made "Misery" so haunting, so scary, and so real.As if a common drama suddenly descended to darkness in a one way ticket to madness. If Stephen King's work is known for bringing the horror closer to home, "Misery" is the best example of that statement.Without a doubt, "Misery" is a modern classic, and it only gets better with time. This is probably, the best adaptation to a book by Stephen King. 8/10

reviews.review_title: Still Stands Strong In Today Cinematography
reviews.content: I am honestly surprised that they managed to make this movie 1hr and 47min long considering it is mostly set in Annie's house. It starts off a bit slow but still interesting enough. Annie starts off to be this sweet lady who saved Paul who is a writer from a car crash. She is nursing him back to health and is a fan of his writings but then you realise she's got a few screws loose.Kathy Bates does so well, I can kind of relate to her character in some ways such as her attention to detail and passion for the stories even if she's a bit over the top crazy about it. Paul does very well trying to appease Annie from acting up and almost succeeds in drugging her so he can escape but the plan backfires so hard I had to pause because the pain (for Paul) was too much, though it was very well done, well written and executed.The Sherriff is actually a really smart man and manages to figure out where Paul is, I really liked him and his wife, they had some great moments. I wasn't surprised he died but it was still quite upsetting because he was such a good man. The ending was great, the fight, the aftermath and the explanation of Paul still mentally recovering from his ordeal.The film is very well shot and the quality is great considering its 31 years old. If I was to compare this to The Shining, I would watch this movie 30 times over.

reviews.review_title: Audience everywhere would rather be crippled for life than be nursed back to health by the psycho Annie Wilkes.
reviews.content: Misery is the adapted film from the great Stephen King about novelist Paul Sheldon, played by James Caan, the successful writer of the "Misery" series. After having written Misery into the ground for several years Paul decides it's time to retire Misery and kills off the beloved character in his latest book. Moving onto his new project he spends months hidden away in a hotel in the mountains of Colorado writing his new project. After completing his newest manuscript Paul checks out of his hotel and drives his old mustang back into town. However a severe snow storm makes driving an impossibility as Paul drives right off the hill. Paul awakens in the guest room of Annie Wilkes, played by Kathy Bates, a retired nurse living by her lonesome in a secluded cabin. Annie tells Paul that she's his biggest fan and she has read every single one of his Misery books. With the storm knocking out the phone lines and roads Annie tells Paul it's best he just sit tight for awhile while his body heals. Paul's legs are shattered and one of his shoulders has been dislocated. After a couple of days of being nursed back to health Paul is anxious to speak with his agent and daughter but when Annie reads Paul's latest Misery novel she explodes with outrage. She won't stand for her beloved Misery's death. Annie, showing her psychotic and violent tendencies forces Paul to burn his newest manuscript and holds Paul prisoner until he writes the revival of Misery. Locked in a room and presumed dead by the outside world, Paul only hope is the local sheriff, played by Richard Farnsworth who is slowly flowing bread crumbs of his disappearance. Misery is great screenplay with a solid accumulation of twists and turns. The shooting style is a little dated but the use of wide angle close ups does wonders for making Annie Wilkes the scariest nurse you've ever seen. Her bipolar performance is definitely worthy of the Oscar. James Caan is also terrific as the witty and clever writer. I mainly know him from his stereotypical bad-guy roles but he also plays a great sympathetic cripple. One thing that I have to note is the amazing job done on the make up. The swollen broken legs of Paul look absolutely disgusting. Misery is a great horror flick and Kathy Bates will probably go down as the most terrifying nurse in cinematic history. Who this film is not for: -Even though I'm not into the horror genre, I really enjoyed this film. However some people who don't like scary movies will probably want to stay away.

Say what you will about horror films based on the works of Stephen King, it's real terror you'll find in a story like "Misery". The dread you feel every moment for Paul Sheldon (James Caan) whenever Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates) feels betrayed by his newest novel comes across as all too credibly real. Instead of nightmarish visions from "The Shining" or the unrealistic presence of a demonic clown from "It", what you have here is a devoted but deranged celebrity fan who intends to keep her favorite novelist to herself for better or worse, and in Sheldon's case, it's definitely for the worst. The scene I have to avert my eyes, I think you'll know it, is when Annie takes that big old sledge hammer and whacks Paul's left ankle with it to horrifying effect. Once was enough in the picture, as director Rob Reiner only offered up that visual a single time; Paul's right ankle suffered the same fate but what viewer could take it more than once?Bates won a Best Actress Oscar for her portrayal here, of a character who can be sympathetically understanding one moment and terrifyingly vicious the next. However I COULD relate to her extreme frustration with cliffhanger serials from back in the day. I've watched my share and have the same reaction she did whenever the hero of the story miraculously escapes from an impossible predicament under sleight-of-hand circumstances in the next chapter play. No such luck here, as Paul Sheldon's daily nightmare continues relentlessly until he's able to summon up enough strength to take out his lunatic captor.As far as Stephen King based movies go, this one ranks fairly high by IMDb viewers. Of the nearly thirty films based on his works that I've seen up till now, this one comes in at a respectable fifth place ahead of 2017's "It", as well as "Carrie" and "The Dead Zone", though 1980's version of "The Shining" is still considered a stronger horror flick. Strong performances by Caan and Ms. Bates are backed up by Richard Farnsworth as the low key sheriff investigating Paul Sheldon's disappearance, and Lauren Bacall in a guest spot as Sheldon's literary agent. A little credit also ought to go to Misery the Pig in a cameo role. She didn't overstay her welcome and maintained a suitable presence whenever called upon to perform, unlike some other sow who might have gone over the top with a ham performance.

Having director Rob Reiner bring the classic Stephen King novel to life on the screen was actually a good thing back in 1990, because "Misery" turned out to be a rather good movie and a movie that packed a punch - pardon the pun.Of course, I would recommend that you read the book, as there are so many more details and things to be experienced there, and you get to put your own faces on the characters. But I must say that this movie version of the novella is rather outstanding, and that is because of a combination of the story, the directors work and the acting performances of primarily Kathy Bates and James Caan.The story told in "Misery" is a story that should appeal to just about everyone, I think. It is a story of obsession, isolation and desperation. I enjoy the story and have watched the movie a bunch of times over the years, and the movie keeps being just as entertaining as the first time I watched it.I think that having chosen both Kathy Bates and James Caan as the lead roles of Annie Wilkes and Paul Sheldon respectively was quite good, because they are quite capable performers and they did great jobs in "Misery". And there is a great chemistry between the two on the screen, which worked well in favor of the movie and storyline. In all honesty, then "Misery" was truly Kathy Bates' movie, because she far outshone James Caan with her performance.The gradual revealing of the level of obsession and lengths that Annie Wilkes was willing to go to was so nicely constructed in this movie, and director Rob Reiner managed to put that on the screen quite well. And the scenes that involved violence were quite expertly choreographed and captured on the screen, and it felt like you were right there in the ordeal with Paul Sheldon.The ending of the movie, well it was a fairly generic way to end the story, but of course, it was as it usually is in such thrillers/horrors. Could it have ended differently? Certainly. The ending of the movie is the only weak point in the entire movie for me.

Where to start.....Caan is perfect,Bates is brilliant,Farnsworth is.... Farnsworth.perfectly cast,shot well,just enough suspenseful music. Annie will make you feel sorry for her,she's so smitten,& crazy.everytime i watch this movie,i seriously have to rub,& massage my ankles.

reviews.review_title: Gives the words "white-knuckle" a whole new meaning.
reviews.content: This film is truly chilling. I have seen parts of it on television and my neighbor tells me that it is his favorite movie. Well, I thought this was pretty damn scary.Kathy Bates plays a psychotically obsessed fan of a run-down novelist (James Caan). She "rescues" him from a car crash and nurses him back to health only for the novelist to discover that she isn't all that she appears.Well, basically, every moment of MISERY is worth seeing. Based on Stephen King's more unpopular novels and adapted by William Goldman (HEARTS IN ATLANTIS), this film is surely one that will have you up all night.There are parts of the film that were very humorous and I was laughing, and then there were the thrilling parts of the film. They were very well done. The music score is perfect as it fits the mood quite well. I feel that this is one of the better Stephen King book-to-movie adaptations because it actually has a constant story to it. And a hell of a story at that.I was not expecting much when I got this, but what I got was a real treat. I also recommend that you read the book and then see TRAPPED with Kevin Bacon, and ALONG CAME A SPIDER with Morgan Freeman. They aren't quite as good, but still somewhat worthy. MISERY: 5/5.

reviews.review_title: Best viewed as a "dark comedy", Bates and Caan are in top form.
reviews.content: I had seen this movie years ago, and currently viewed it again with Natalie, college Sophomore. This is a dark story, but one with many belly-laugh moments, and we agreed that it is best viewed as a dark comedy. Bates won the Best Actress for her role as "Number One Fan" of novelist Paul Sheldon.James Caan is author Paul Sheldon and has had a series of successes with a "Misery" theme, the name of the main female character. He always follows the same routine, he drives his Mustang from New York to the Colorado mountains, stays in the same place, writes his new book, and drives back to New York.Kathy Bates is nurse Annie Wilkes, living on the outskirts of the small town. She proclaims herself as Sheldon's number one fan. She knows his routine very well, and just happens to be following his car when he drives away in a snowstorm. When his car careens off the road (was it accidental?) and down a snowy embankment, Annie is right there with crowbar to get him out. A sturdy woman, she carries him out and nurses him back to health in her home.The whole movie is about this obsessed woman who has trouble separating fiction from reality when it comes to the "Misery" books. As Sheldon is recuperating she gets him to agree to let her read the latest manuscript, but she becomes very upset over some of the contents, particularly that Sheldon is letting Misery die in childbirth, and in her warped view accuses Sheldon of killing Misery. This begins the downward spiral which cannot end well.Richard Farnsworth is perfect as Buster, the low-key mayor and sheriff of the small community, helping to figure out where Sheldon disappeared to. Lauren Bacall is fun to watch as Marcia Sindell, Sheldon's publisher.SPOILERS, SPOILERS: Early on Annie decides to keep Sheldon captive for herself, and does not notify authorities or try to get him to a hospital for his broken legs and other injuries. As he begins to figure out how to sneak around the house when she makes trips to town, he finds her scrapbook and figures out that starting even as a teenager Annie would systematically "eliminate" people that may have been in her way for an honor or a job. He figures that she may eventually try to eliminate him. She does get rid of Buster when he becomes too nosy, but in an epic struggle at the end on the bedroom floor, Sheldon finally gets the best of Annie with, ironically, his typewriter!

7.7? i give it 10 this is one of the sickest and and most interesting films i've had the pleasure to watch. Annie Wilkes must be one of the best thought out, deranged characters ever concocted by a writer and the actor who plays her is just fantastic. I saw the trailer and could only think: "I have to see this", i did and there was no disappointment whatsoever. I love the scene where she breaks his legs, that made me twitch and my friends turned away. I also love the scene where the police officers are investigating in the snow and the camera moves to a car going by and its Annie smiling. She's ****ing crazy. Great film. Buy or rent

When Stephen King's most successful movie-adaptations are enumerated, "Misery" is nearly always overshadowed by "Carrie" and "The Shining" but in my personal humble opinion this at least is an equally efficient shocker, if not MORE efficient. This film is a sublime plotting triumph in which the gore and action are largely replaced by psychological terror and pitch black humor. The adaptation works both as a demented psycho-thriller and a virulent criticism towards obsessive fan behavior. James Caan stars as the talented author Paul Sheldon who just finished his first personal novel in years, after a series of book focusing on one heroine  Misery Chastain  that nearly killed his artistic creativity. When a car crash during a blizzard nearly kills him, he's rescued and nursed by Annie Wilkes who also turns out his biggest fan. It doesn't take long before Annie proves herself to be an authentic psychopath who imprisons and mutilates John and even forces him into writing a new Misery adventure. Rob Reiner perfectly reflects the increasing feelings of hopelessness of James Caan's character. We witness how every attempt of his to escape fails and how every mental collision with Annie results in a creepy freakshow! The disturbing character of this film may mainly be caused by chilling dialogue and psychological warfare, the script doesn't neglect the horror and shocks entirely! I'm particularly thinking about this eerie sequence in which Bathes does something nasty with a miniature sledge-hammer Granted, "Misery" wouldn't be half as powerful or memorable if it weren't for the top-notch casting job. Kathy Bathes truly deserved her Academy Award for this role and she's one of the most convincing psychos ever! She actually gives a bizarre sort of naturalness to her severely insane character and even playful words like "whoopsiedaisy" sound horrifying coming from her mouth. Caan is terrific as well and his character's oppressed frustration nearly drips from the screen. Last but not least, "Misery" has an excellent supporting cast with some famous "elderly" actors in their best roles in ages. Richard Farnsworth as the little-town sheriff and a still good-looking Lauren Bacall as the agent.

reviews.review_title: A decent thriller, nothing special though
reviews.content: Misery is not the best thriller, but its far from the wort. The cast does well with a good script and limited directing from Reiner. Rob Reiner's thriller based on Stephen King novel is another average thriller, however this one unlike Zemeckis' 2000 film what lies beneath has a better cast and screenplay. Although the film does have some unexpected moments and a few good scenes, as a whole its a bore and the characters are a bit stereotyped. The acting saved this film, Bates is great in her Oscar winning role and Caan and Farnsworth were great too. THis film is written well by William Goldman and directed averagely by Reiner who impressed me much more with The American President. This is a good movie but not great 8/10

Misery was released between two erotic thrillers: three years after Fatal Attraction and three years before Basic Instinct, both which starred Michael Douglas. It happens he was offered the role of Paul in Misery, but perhaps he couldn't swalllow the thought of playing a passive victim to a female psychopath who wasn't orgasmically sex-crazed or conventionally attractive. Kathy Bates had the last laugh with her Oscar-winning role as Annie. Also, James Caan's career was rebooted with his role of Paul.Definitely Misery is timeless. The tensions ratchets up big time, and is a commentary of fandom for the ages.

Based on the Stephen King novel, Caan stars as famous fiction writer, Paul Sheldon, who is working on a new novel in a cabin in the woods (his place of inspiration). As he attempts to drive home during a snow storm, he ends up flipping his car and is trapped inside. When Paul regains consciousness, he finds himself in unfamiliar surroundings. Local nurse, Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates), pulled him from his car and has taken him back to her home to recuperate. She tells Paul that she is his number 1 fan, and he doesn't see anything wrong with that until Annie starts to reveal her true colors.After reading Paul's last "Misery" novel, Annie learns that her beloved heroine has been killed off by the author, and this sets her off into a downward spiral. Paul finds himself trapped in Annie's house with no one knowing here he is, as his overturned car leads people to believe he has injured himself and perished in the snowy forest.I was once again impressed with Kathy Bates in this; she scared me, which made sense, given the type of movie this was. I'd for sure recommend his one.

Before the movie Misery I hadn't heard of Kathy Bates. After the movie Misery I couldn't forget her. She shot to the top of my psycho lady list. It was Glenn Close for her role in Fatal Attraction, but in a close vote Kathy edged her out.Misery was a great book and a great movie. Kathy was so wonderful as Annie Wilkes--the hot tempered woman with an aversion to swearing. She'll torture you and kill you but she dare not use profanity. Annie was so unstably wicked and Paul Sheldon (James Caan) was so hurt and helpless that it made a perfect brew of anxiety, fear, and intensity.The entire movie is full of irony.Paul should've died in his accident, yet he's saved by a woman that may very well kill him.Had Paul not survived his accident his manuscript probably would've died with him. Annie saves him and his manuscript just to have him burn it.Paul kills off his character Misery. Annie forces him to write another book bringing Misery to life, then Paul burns that book anyway.One of the biggest ironies is that entire experience inspires Paul to write a masterpiece in place of the book Annie forced him to burn.Still, the ultimate irony is that Annie loved Misery and Paul was in misery.It was brilliant. The plot was magnificent and played out masterfully from beginning to end, Caan was good, and Bates was stellar. What a wonderful movie.

Misery starts in a snow covered Colorado lodge where guest & famous author Paul Sheldon (James Cann) has just finished his latest novel. Paul packs his manuscript in his bag, checks out of the lodge & begins the journey back to New York. Unfortunately Paul didn't realise that he would have to drive through a severe blizzard & while trying to negotiate the difficult conditions he crashes his car, however help is at hand as he is rescued from the wreck by local resident Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates) who also happens to be a nurse. Back at her farm where she lives alone Annie tends to Paul's injuries including a couple of broken legs & confesses to him that she is his biggest fan & has all of his books. At first Paul is relieved that she saved him but things take a turn for the worse when Annie reads his latest novel only to discover that he is killing the main character off, Paul soon finds out that Annie is a bit mad & will go to extreme lengths to make sure her favourite character's live on even if they're author doesn't...Co-produced & directed by Rob Reiner who also has a cameo in the film as the helicopter pilot, I thought Misery was a great watch. The script by William Goldman was based on the novel 'Misery' by Stephen King, which I have not read so I cannot compare the two, has a good pace to it, while it's slow & not that much actually happens it's very measured, effective & far from boring. The basic story is very engaging & very tense which is exactly what a dark psychological horror/thriller such as Misery should be. There are only three character's of any substance in the film & while everything works well I thought there could have been a bit more background to Annie, for instance it emerges as the film progresses that she may have been responsible for the deaths of babies at the hospital where she worked but it is never confirmed & seems almost nothing more than an afterthought just to make her more 'evil' as it were. I have no idea what the medical/mental condition is called that Annie suffers from or how accurately portrayed it is on screen but she's pretty scary at times & her unbalanced nature is both convincing & well used. I thought the ending lacked a little something & felt a bit rushed & I'm not sure if I'd want to see it again anytime soon but overall I think Misery is a fine film on various levels.Director Reiner does a great job at keeping the tension levels high & it's a film that draws you in & making you want to know how it ends. He keeps thing generally pretty simple, there's no flashy camera tricks or overblown set pieces but I'm sure that was intentional by the filmmakers. Whatever you may hear Misery is lacking as far as blood & violence goes, there's a scene where Annie breaks Paul's ankles with a sledgehammer although you actually 'see' virtually nothing on screen, it's a scene that sticks in the mind because of how it's achieved & frankly how painful it would be in reality. This is one area where the film is different to the original novel, in King's book Annie cuts Paul's foot off rather than breaking it. Trivia: ironically I hurt my own ankle badly at work two weeks ago & went to hospital where x-rays showed I hadn't broken anything but I had a fair amount of soft tissue damage, it hurt so much I was in tears & couldn't even stand on it properly. I cringed while that scene was playing & I can't even imagine how painful it must have been...With a supposed budget of about $20,000,000 Misery is as well made & polished as you would hope for, it does what it has to very well. The acting was good by a pretty small cast. Apparently the role of Paul Sheldon was offered to Jack Nicholson, William Hurt, Kevin Kline, Michael Douglas, Harrison Ford, Dustin Hoffman, Robert De Niro, Al Pacino, Richard Dreyfuss, Gene Hackman, Robert Redford & Warren Beatty all of whom turned the role down, now that's some serious knock backs. Kathy Bates won an Osacr for best actress in a leading role for her performance in Misery.Misery is one of the very best Stephen King adaptations & a great film in it's own right, definitely well worth a watch.

reviews.review_title: Kathy Bates Gives a Cock a Doody Performance
reviews.content: Stephen King's novel had a smashing premise that the film only partially succeeds in capitalizing on.It's clear that "Misery" is an author's (or at least King's) worst nightmare: a writer of disposable potboilers (James Caan) is in an accident and finds himself convalescing in the home of his self-proclaimed #1 fan (Kathy Bates). Trouble is, his #1 fan is holding him hostage, and does nasty things to him if he doesn't write exactly what she wants him to.Some of those things are diluted for the film (in the book, she chops off one of his feet, whereas in the movie she only hobbles him with a sledgehammer) and some missing altogether (the finger in the birthday cake for instance). But it's not the gore that made the book scary -- it was the helplessness of the main character, and director Rob Reiner is right to focus on that in the film as well.Kathy Bates is appropriately wacky as Annie, but she's a wonderful actress who's done a bunch of much better work elsewhere, so it's sort of a shame that this is the film for which she won her Oscar. Caan is good too, but he's shown up by Bates -- anyone would be shown up by this loony-tunes character.It's only toward the end that Reiner trips up, and the film goes lame, veering away from the book. However, in the film's defense, the ending to the book was pretty lame too, so Reiner was probably right to try to do something different, even if that something doesn't really work.Grade: B

Unfortunately, it is impossible to find movies like this nowadays. The plot and the scenes are great. Amazing actors! Everything is so realistic, and the fact that it has no special effects gives you chills, and keeps your attention.

Novelist Paul Sheldon is on his way home from his Colorado hideaway after completing his latest book, when he crashes his car in a freak weather storm. Paul is injured, but is rescued by former nurse Annie Wilkes, hiss "number one fan", who takes Paul back to her remote house in the mountains. Unfortunately for Paul, Annie is also unhinged. When she discovers that Paul has killed off the heroine in her favourite novels, her reaction leaves Paul fearing for his life....First off, this is on par with The Shining to be Kings best horror adaptation ever to be released, and its thanks to the wonderful performances from the two leads. The only time this film ever relieves the tension is when we cut to Richard Farnsworth and wife, providing us with some much needed comic relief.Rob Reiner has crafted a wonderful horror movie, and when we are in the four walls of Annie's house it teeters on unbearable at times, because you really get into Annie, and you never know how she is going to be when she walks into Paul's room.Caan knows that this is all Bates, so he literally lays there and let's her do her thing. Even when she's not in a scene, her presence can be felt, such as when Paul ventures beyond the bedroom.So all in all, its a classy horror movie, Bates is well deserved of her Oscar, and the film drags you in, you really feel for Paul when she spills the wine, and you will tense up at the hobbling scene.A brilliant movie, with a lot of heart.

reviews.review_title: This is an absolute masterpiece and must see
reviews.content: Misery (1990) is a movie in my DVD collection that I recently rewatched on Shudder. The storyline follows a famous book writer who finished his latest book in his mountain retreat and starts off home in the middle of a snowstorm. Unfortunately he's in a car crash and wakes up in a strangers house of a stranger who happens to be his biggest fan. Is this savior a blessing or a nightmare?This movie is directed by Rob Reiner (A Few Good Men) and stars James Caan (The Godfather), Kathy Bates (Titanic), Richard Farnsworth (The Getaway) and Lauren Bacall (The Big Sleep).The acting in this is out of this world. Caan and Bates deliver magnificent performances and play off each other perfectly. The subtle horror elements are very well executed and Bates just being in the room is intense and unpredictable. Her delivery of the personality traits were mesmerizing. The settings were well depicted and it is impossible to not love the sheriff and deputy and their dynamics too. The punishment scene in this is legendary and still makes me cringe every time I watch it. This picture does do a good job of delivering the nursing back story and the ending is absolutely awesome, both at the house and restaurant.Overall, this is an absolute masterpiece and must see. I would score this a 10/10 and strongly recommend it.

reviews.review_title: I am guessing this is how all celebrities see us "regular" folk.
reviews.content: The movie is good and very well acted...then again I generally like a good James Caan movie. Still, I just believe that this how all celebrities see people like you and I. If we ever have the opportunity we would tie up our beloved stars and hoard them for ourselves and our world revolves around them. Me I just want to be entertained and could not care one bit about what these people do in their spare times and such. Still, this movie has a nice flow to it, and has some rather darkly comic moments as our writer struggles to escape the clutches of his one true fan. How does he end up in her clutches, he has a car accident that leaves him severely wounded and the other person in the car dead. His fan is nice enough at first, but he makes the mistake of letting her read his latest manuscript where he has killed off a character that has appeared in a series of books for him. Her name being "Misery", which if I was a fan of the series I would expect that sooner or later a character named Misery was going to die sooner or later. So most of the movie is the interplay between the writer and his crazed fan. Not much in the way of death in this film, but the acting makes up for that as does the story. It is mainly a movie that kind of hangs around the house which says all the more for it that it is entertaining.

Misery is probably Stephen King's most frightening story because of the way it grounds in reality how one person can be living his life, and then suddenly be thrust into the most terrifying ordeal he has ever experienced. Its a refreshing change from King's supernatural stories.Don't be mislead by the title. Misey is far from a miserable experience. Its a gripping, tightly wound thriller from startling beginning to nail-biting conclusion.The film begins with novelist Paul Sheldon (James Caan) finishing a new novel. But one that is different from the "Misery books" he has become famous for. He feels that writing about Misery Chastaine for so long has stifled his creativity. So after he finishes his brand new novel, he checks out of the Silver Creek lodge, and goes for a drive. Unfortunately, a blizzard sends his car off the road.When he wakes up, he finds himself in the home of nurse Annie Wilkes (the superb Kathy Bates). As a result of the accident, Paul is now temporarily crippled. This is not a good thing, in more ways than one. Gradually, Paul (and the audience) realises that Annie is dangerously unstable. She claims to be his "number one fan". She's completely obsessed with him and his Misery novels. She is none to happy to discover in his latest novel, Misery dies. And she wants Paul to write a new novel, heralding Misery's return.So begins the battle of wits between Paul and Annie, as he desperately tries to find a way to escape. There is a real claustrophobic feel to Misery, thanks in no small part to Coen cinematographer Barry Sonnenfeld's tight, unnerving camera angles. They do a great job of capturing Paul's horror at being at Annie's mercy. As most of the film takes place within the confines of his room, Paul must find a way to out-think Annie. But she always seems to be one step ahead.James Caan gives a good enough performance as Paul Sheldon, keeping a subtle, slightly cynical attitude while at the same time terrified of his situation. But the real star of the film is Kathy Bates. She is just brilliant, and steals every scene she is in. The audience is transfixed by how one minute she is a caring, slightly eccentric person, and than suddenly changes to a psychotic, homicidal lunatic. Sometimes she is downright evil.The "hobbling" scene is especially memorable. A demonstration of Annie's power over Paul. Thwarting his attempts to escape. Breaking his spirit. The relationship between the two characters is skilfully handled, as Annie tries to keep Paul to herself forever in the name of love!What terrifies you the most is the way Annie's delusions are the only thing keeping her from killing Paul outright. She would willingly sacrifice both their lives to ensure Misery lives. Although Annie Wilkes is a terrifying creation, she is a sometimes sympathetic character. One wonders what could have possibly happened to Annie to make her so demented. Kathy Bates deserved the Oscar for this film. One of the rare occasions the committee got it right.The novel told the story completely within the confines of Annie's home, but the film includes other characters too. Richard Farnsworth's Sheriff Buster is a likable character. His relationship with his sarcastic wife is fun to watch. Sometimes, it feels like he is the only person looking for Paul. Lauren Bacall puts in a cameo as Paul's agent. Its a pity she couldn't have got more screen time. But this was probably an attempt to keep up the psychological tension between Paul and Annie.The ending is extremely suspenseful, as things inevitably come to a head. The audience (unless you've read the novel) is kept guessing about the outcome. Almost like a Hitchcock film. Kudos to Rob Reiner for making a thoughtful, suspenseful, psychological thriller. Kathy Bates rules. Misery recaptures everything that made the novel so great. It beats the film version of The Shining hands down. Brilliant!

'Misery (1990)' is a really solid thriller. From the moment it opens, it's clear that it knows exactly what it wants to do and how it wants to do it. Barely a second is wasted in the entire affair. It's a fantastic chamber piece that's propelled by two pitch-perfect lead performances. Caan and Bates are both brilliant, especially considering that one is bedbound for the majority of the movie, and it's their battle of wits that keeps things as engaging as they are. The flick excels at putting you in its protagonist's shoes; it really makes you feel his pain and desperation. It's often incredibly suspenseful, especially in a few of its stand-out set-pieces. It's also surprisingly exciting when it needs to be, primarily in its brutal finale. Ultimately, it's a really well-made film. It grips you as soon as it opens and it doesn't let you go until its credits have rolled. It's great. 8/10

Rob Reiner is a fantastic filmmaker, his films, mostly, have been magical. 'Misery' is amongst his best works, a fantastic celluloid version of the novel by the same name by the Legendary Stephen King. It's a must watch!'Misery' is a a very interesting & gripping tale of a prolific writer & his Number-One Fan, who turns out to be a crazy & evil person. 'Misery' holds your grip from start to end, there's hardly a moment when your distracted from the screen. It's surely amongst the best films from the year 1990.Reiner's direction, as always, is arresting. William Goldman's screenplay is simply superb. Barry Sonnenfeld's camera-work is excellent, he captures every moment with proper treatment. Kathy Bates delivers an astounding performance in 'Misery'. She causes terror & hatred in you, that powerful her portrayal is. She deserved all the awards she got! This is the Legendary Actress's best work to date. James Caan is excellent, as he always has been. He plays the part of a helpless man with the understanding only and only he can portray. Others do a fine job.'Misery' is a winner all the way.... Two Thumbs Up All The Way!

reviews.review_title: Control Freaks Almost Win This one
reviews.content: For Director Rob Reiner this is the movie he directed between When Harry Met Sally and A Few Good Men. This movie shows that his fine work directing those 2 films was not a fluke. It is always going to be the movie between those, so it does not get the showings the other 2 films do.James Caan & Kathy Bates give terrific performances in this movie, Caan as the famous author and Bates as the obsessed maniac fan who captures him. The play between these two is amazing. The Stephen King story is of the stalker who terrorizes the object of their affection. What makes it creepier is that in the past she has already gotten away with some stuff in the past.This is handled very well here including all the problems Caan has in trying to devise ways to escape Bates. It finally comes down to a life or death struggle in the end. Lauren Bacall is fine in a limited role as a newspaper critic in this one.

Only Stephen King can turn a basically one-room play into a full length novel of horror, originality and suspense. I've read the Misery book at least once and it ranks as my second favorite of his, behind The Stand, and though some things were changed in the movie adaptation and though some things angered King (Caan), Director Reiner did the same job on the film as King did on the novel. He definitively created a full length movie of horror, originality and suspense.After pulp-novelist Paul Sheldon (Caan) finished his latest story in Colorado, he heads home in a huge blizzard only to crash in the snow and be "rescued" by Annie Wilkes (Bates). She proceeds to nurse him back to health in her isolated cabin in the woods since he's severely banged up. Slowly, but surely, Sheldon begins to see the crazier side of his "number one fan" as she calls herself.See, she's upset Sheldon "killed" off her precious Misery Chastain character from eight novels. She died in child birth, not really murdered. Nevertheless, the character that actually never really lived is gone and no more Misery Chastain novels. Telling this to Wilkes is like taking Jason Voorhees's machete and saying "no more killing, okay, Jason?" How do you think Jason would react? Well, aside from a few brutal tortures she bestows on him during his stay at the Wilkes's farm, she namely reacts by making him write/type Misery's Return to bring back the character to life. Not that he had much choice, but he does write it and all the while concocts up feeble escape attempts until the inevitable conclusion.Despite the mainly one-room set, Misery is tight, interesting, beautifully shot and acted by the leads. I remember the Oscars attached to 1990 vividly. Though I was rooting for Dances With Wolves the whole way, it was absent from the Best Actress category. It was tough deciding between The Grifters's Anjelica Huston and Pretty Woman's Julia Roberts. But it was a no-brainer on who actually won: Kathy Bates in the best performance of her career before and since.I sure did love the book (and the book within the book – Misery's Return, that I objected to at first, but then grew accustomed to and interested in that story as well) and as almost always, the book's better than the movie with a lot more going on, including, again, the book-with-a-book. Still, Misery was an excellent example of film-making, and even holds up today after 19 years.Side Note: Though all I said about the novel, Misery, it appears Stephen King went back to the same general idea with Gerald's Game. Unfortunately, after I read that, lightening really only struck once. It wasn't terrible, but nowhere close to Misery and I sincerely hope they don't attempt to adapt Gerald's Game.

Misery tells the story of an author who his famous off his series of Misery novels. On his way home from a secluded lodge, he is in a violent car wreck that breaks both his legs. He is rescued by a local woman who claims to be his #1 fan. She takes him in, feeds him, takes care of him, and gushes over his Misery novels. However, when she reads his latest novel in which he kills the character off for good, she snaps and begins to torment him, forcing him to write a new Misery novel. This movie is a perfect psychological thriller, almost like a Hitchcock movie.Stephen King writes some great novels, but Misery is one of his greatest. In the late 80s, Stephen King novels were hot properties for films, and with the great success of Misery, it was only a matter of time before they made a movie out of it. The first good sign was that Rob Reiner took the helm. He had previously done a fantastic job bringing Stephen King's The Body to the big screen as Stand By Me. Next, the role of the author was taken by James Caan, who is one of the most talented actors out there. I really enjoyed William Goldman's screenplay, because it stayed true to the book while also adding some things to make it more interesting. The blend of terror and comedy in some scenes is perfect and it makes the movie really enjoyable. I especially love the scene where the woman brutally injures the author, and the next day she gleefully waves at him, and he just nonchalantly waves back...With his finger.The acting in this movie is great. There's only about 5 roles that really mean anything, and the actors are all great. This is one of James Caan's best performances, and it's only matched by Kathy Bates' performance as the crazed fan.Overall, Misery is a classic movie, and it is the best Stephen King movie besides The Shawshank Redemption. Great, great movie.9/10

reviews.review_title: one of the better Stephen King novels adapted for the screen
reviews.content: this is one of the best Stephen King novels adapted for the big screen.this movie is well acted,well written and well directed.Kathy bates makes a great homicidal maniac.James Caan plays novelist Paul Sheldon who ends up being tormented by Annie Wilkes,who is his biggest fan.she goes to great lengths to prove just how big a fan she is.of course,she is also very angry at Sheldon,so of course he must be punished.i won't reveal how he comes to be tormented by her,or why she is angry at him,but she has her reasons,sick and twisted they may be.Caan is also convincing as a man who believes his life is in danger and is desperate to survive.anyway,the suspense factor is high in this one,as is the creepiness factor.for me,Misery is a 7/10

reviews.review_title: Makes you feel trapped, but in a good way
reviews.content: Misery makes you feel trapped, but in a good way. It's almost impossible to pull your eyes away from the screen, even though it's a fairly simple story with minimal settings and characters. This is mostly due to Kathy Bates' mesmerizing performance as the sympathetic psychopath, Annie Wilkes. Not many of Stephen King's film adaptations end that well, but Misery is able to successfully land on both feet.

reviews.review_title: "I have this gun. Sometimes I think about using it. I'd better go now. I might put bullets in it."
reviews.content: "I have this gun. Sometimes I think about using it. I'd better go now. I might put bullets in it."Kathy Bates puts on an incredible performance. She actually got an Oscar acting in a horror movie. James Caan performance is also understated.

I am not a Steven King fan and have never particularly enjoyed his brand of "horror". And while I don't think this movie is as good as many of the other people who have commented, I do think it deserves some attention, especially for those like myself who appreciate the comic effect that some filmmakers bring the the horror genre. Even though Kathy Bates definitely portrays a very scary woman, this movie (unlike "The Shining" for example) is also supposed to be FUNNY. Cann's rolling eyes and his good-bad overacting when he is trying to appease Bates' deranged character is undeniably comic. Judging from how rare it is, it must be difficult to balance dramatic tension with doses of humor, and Rob Reiner has pulled it off with unusual grace. Unlike B grade horror movies which are so bad that some consider them funny, this movie makes people laugh on purpose, and in so doing, is a good specimen of a very particular genre - long live the 'Horror Comedy'!

reviews.review_title: Kathy Bates Still Leaves An Indelible Impression.
reviews.content: It's fun to say that its almost been 5 years since I last saw "Misery", and I want to begin my review with a sentence I wrote all those years ago: "What a great Stephen King flick". Yes, Rob Reiner has delivered one of the more finer Stephen King adaptations. Though I have never read the novel, King himself stated that "Misery" is one of his favourite movies based on his works. James Caan & Kathy Bates have a really hard job to do keeping us entertained throughout the film. But the chemistry between the author and psychotic fan is so incredibly intense and unflinching in its depiction, it manages to elevate beyond expectations and still remain profound in the thriller genre today.Famed novelist Paul Sheldon (James Caan), is the author of a series of regency romance novels featuring a character named Misery Chastain. Whilst driving home he is caught in a blizzard and his car unfortunately goes off the road, leaving him unconscious. Paul is rescued from the wreckage by a nurse named Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates), who brings him to her remote home as Paul is broken and bed-ridden. She reveals to be Misery's "Number 1 fan", and inevitably Annie's fanaticism seems to go way beyond the norm, possibly leading to big trouble for the helpless Paul.It's so well acted and directed, you can get sucked in just like that. Even back then I loved how subtle and cool everything seemed in the beginning, then it just takes a turn for the worse until ultimately it turns into a battle of survival where the odds are completely stacked against you. Kathy Bates takes fanaticism to a whole new level, into the stuff of nightmares. She more than deserved the Oscar for such a career defining performance. James Caan does admirable work, I've always appreciated and enjoyed his performance and presence on screen. Final Verdict: Stephen King is my favourite author, and Rob Reiner adds another gem to his filmography. The performances alone are more than enough reason why I highly recommend seeing it. 8/10.

reviews.review_title: What Your Number One Fan Can Do
reviews.content: Rob Reiner adapts Stephen King's novel into a taut thriller that is intense, well paced, tightly packed and fantastically acted. The tension is well built and maintained throughout the entire film. The screenplay has a few predictable moments and overdone jump scenes but that doesn't stop 'Misery' from being a fine gripping thriller. I see influence of other classic works, such as Hitchcock's films, which is pleasant to uncover. But what really makes this an outstanding movie is the acting. The film 'Misery' really required very talented skilled actors to pull off the dialogue delivery, the subtle nuances and the transformation in character as they are vulnerable to being played as caricatures by lesser actors. Fortunately, Reiner and his casting director have done a superb job in selecting their actor. Richard Farnsworth and Lauren Bacall are simply terrific in their roles. However, it is James Caan and Kathy Bates who own the film. While Bates has deservedly received immense recognition for portraying one of movie's most popular badass female characters, Caan remains overshadowed. But I feel he deserves equal credit. One only ought to notice his reaction to everything Bates's Wilkes says and does in order to understand the greatness of his performance. The acting and screenplay make the film so captivating and entertaining that I could easily rewatch this and enjoy it just the same.

Yes, a good suspenseful & creepy watch. Caan is the consummate pro, just excellent, as always.I really like like Bates, but as another reviewer cited, the acting is over the top. I'd put it differently. For me, her little girl, up/down fairy-tale telling melody of a voice; particularly early on when she's first mesmerized by the writer of the misery series, (Caan), it just phony, and way too often, even if she is portraying a loon. And it becomes annoying fast.But I do like her mood swings and outbursts.Some wicked twists in the flick.Anyway, a great one-time watch.Bob R.

There are three types of people who frighten me: people who have an intense love of popular romantic fiction; people who can't bring themselves to swear and instead invent their own homespun swear-lite; and people who think they actually talk to god. All of these afflictions hint at an arrested development, an inability to deal with reality and a barely suppressed rage. So, needless to say, in light of her suffering from all three of these disorders, Annie Wilkes is a woman to be extremely fearful of.But of course, at first, she seems so nice. She rescues Paul Sheldon from freezing to death after crashing his car in a blizzard and then she gives him medical treatment in her own home. But no sooner has she opened her mouth than she's declaring him 'The World's Greatest Writer' and calling him a 'literary genius'  this she says of a man who loathes his own work and a man who hates the way he's become a manufacturer of bland product rather than a writer expressing himself. But even more worryingly she apologises for making him feel "oogy". The warning bells ring loud and clear.But Annie's insanity doesn't get its first overt display until after she's begun reading the manuscript that was pulled from Paul's car  it's more personal work and it's a breakaway from the Misery tripe he's been getting rich off. She admits that it's well written but she says the profanity bothers her. And she flies off the handle completely when Paul insists that slum children do indeed swear. It's a great scene and Kathy Bates' delivery is perfect. It's both comical and unnerving.However, more frightening than the loss of temper is the way that Annie apologises. She tells Paul she loves him. Paul's sphincter must be playing all kinds of tricks.After this the film plays the humour of the situation for a little while. We get a funny scene where Annie introduces Paul to her pig (which, surprise, surprise, is called Misery) and then there's a fantastic bit where Annie is talking about her failed marriage. At first it appears to be a serious scene, but then halfway through her spiel we find out that Paul has been urinating into a bottle while listening to her prattle on. And it becomes even funnier when Annie begins lecturing Paul while swishing the bottle of urine absently in her hand. The weird humour helps make Annie seem more believable (and therefore more terrifying).Another funny moment is when Annie is talking about 'Misery's Child' (unbeknownst to Annie, it's Misery's final book  Paul's killed her off). She's about halfway through and she calls it divine. And then she asks this wonderful question: "What's the ceiling that dago painted?" "The Sistine Chapel," is Paul's incredulous response. "Yeah, that and Misery's Child, those are the only two divine things ever in this world." It's a funny moment because it reveals so much about Annie's character  she's totally ignorant and she's casually racist, too (so much for being clean and pure).But the humour in the film comes to a bit of a halt when Annie finishes 'Misery's Child' and finds out about Misery's death. She terrorises Paul as he sleeps and then in the morning she makes him burn the manuscript of the new non-Misery book he's written. In a typically fundamental Christian sort of way she insists he must rid the world of this 'filth'. And in one of the most casually frightening bits in the film she walks around the bed absently squirting lighter fluid on his legs. It's only after this that Paul is persuaded to burn his book. And the look on Caan's face is wonderful. He's both completely heartbroken (he might as well have burnt one of his own children) and filled with rage  after this he quietly declares war on Annie.But after the burning the humour does return. However, it becomes more closely linked with the horror. For instance, there's a darkly amusing moment when Annie loses her temper when Paul shows that the expensive paper she's bought for him smudges. She begins shouting and then slams the paper into his lap. And then there's the rant she makes about chapter plays ("He didn't get out of the cockadoode car!"). I mean, it's nutty enough that a woman has her favourite writer held hostage in her house and she's making him write a new Misery book for her, but it's blackly comic that she becomes a violent one-person focus group. It must be every writer's worst nightmare  you've got to tailor your work to the whims of a nutball.A fabulous scene illustrating how precarious Paul's situation is is when Annie begins talking to him in a depressed state. She goes on about how the rain gives her the blues and she says how fearful she is of losing him. And then she pulls a gun out! Again both Caan and Bates are tremendous. Caan barely suppresses his alarm and Bates casually says that she might put bullets in the weapon. Once again it's a small off-hand moment that is horrific in the implied threat.And the famous hobbling scene is made that more unsettling but the way Annie tells Paul she loves him after she's broken his ankles. Nothing says "I love you" like smashed feet, eh? But although Bates rightly gets a lot of attention, I really must give Caan a lot of credit for his performance. He conveys the helplessness of his situation superbly and it's such a cathartic moment when he finally stuffs the charred remains of 'Misery's Return' down Annie's throat. But if I'm nitpicking I do have to say it's a shame that the fight at the end has the clichéd 'back from the dead' moment. It's the only wrong step in an otherwise fantastic film.

I doubt that any writer in history had so many film and TV adaptations of his stories. According to my account, there are about a hundred of them and, as King is one of my favorite writers, I went straight in. I do not know whether he's difficult to adapt to a screenplay or it's just an unhappy coincidence, but most of these adaptations are a big disappointment for the fans of "king of horror". However, there are exceptions. Ten years (and seventeen King adaptations of questionable quality) after Kubrick's masterpiece "The Shining", Rob Reiner treated us with magnificent "Misery".This psychological drama-thriller is so powerful that it borders with horror.
