The movie starts quite relaxed, but from the very beginning gradually builds a hypnotic atmosphere that will keep you pinned to the screen. From minute to minute it becomes more tormented and tense, and it does not ease up even for a moment. King does not need monsters, explicit bloodshed, shock scenes or sudden turns, to keep you on the edge of the seat and distort your stomach. Nevertheless, the greatest merit for this film's impressiveness does not belong to King's story, but to the magnificent Kathy Bates. Even without her rich acting career, the role of Annie Wilkes in "Misery" would be enough to put her among the best actresses of all time. The persuasiveness of her instant transformations is amazing and she deservedly won an Oscar for Best Actress in a Leading Role. The masterpiece that everyone should see at least once.10/10

reviews.review_title: Now this is what a horror movie should be like
reviews.content: I didn't really want to watch this movie as it dealt with some disturbing issues. Namely false imprisonment and a psychotic fan actively preventing her prisoner from leaving. It seemed disturbing, but I decided to watch it anyway and discovered that it was not as disturbing as I thought it would be. What this movie does say, is what I see in a lot of Stephen King movies, and the books that I read, that horror goes far beyond nasty monster and lots of gore.A famous writer, Paul Sheldon (James Caan) finishes a book and leaves his retreat in the mountains in the middle of a blizzard and ends up crashing his car. He is then pulled from the wreckage by a passing nurse (Kathy Bates) who we first discover is a fan, and then learn that she had been stalking him. He at first believes that he is there recovering, but soon he comes to realise that he is not going to get out - especially since he killed off her favourite character in one of his books.What this movie explores is the dark, unseen side of the human psyche. We consider humanity to be generally nice, and prefer to ignore our darker side. Yet it is something that we cannot avoid with stories of horrid murders by apparently innocent people. Yet once they commit such an act, we ignore what drove them to do that act and label them as being bad. What we really ignore is that we are capable of being driven to that point at well.This is not the case in Misery. The woman has been twisted for a long time. We don't get to know her that well to know what caused her to go that way, but we do know that she has been married and the man whom she was married to was disappointing. We also soon discover some nasty secrets about her past, and maybe it was that which slowly drove her mind into the state that it is in, seeking the beauty of Sheldon's books to escape the reality of her true nature.What I like about Stephen King (and what people seem to ignore regarding his works) is that he explores the human psyche, and it is this that is truly horrific, especially since it is something that we choose to ignore. Many of us will say that no human can be like that, yet we look around and see that it is not true.

Misery is a 1990 thriller starring James Caan(Elf) and Katy Bates(Titanic) and tells the tale of a successful writer named Paul(Caan)who is involved in a car crash and is taken in by a quirky woman who happens to be a nurse called Annie Wickes(Bates). But what happens after that is Paul to escape Annie who turns into a complete nutjob as she is an obsessed fan of Paul's who wants him to write her another story based on Misery at her cabin.The acting is good,the story keeps you in the edge of your seat and yes it can be somewhat gruesome to watch.

My main problem with this is that I found the film too long for its rather limited subject matter. We see Kathy Bates go from unnatural calm to hysterical rage then back to calm then rage again and so on, all the while James Caan tries to escape. This scheme becomes quickly monotonous. I think a good half hour could have been cut off to the film's advantage.There is a good deal of dark humour in this film and I would have preferred if this aspect had been emphasised in the manner of old Ealing comedies. There are a few scenes late on, particularly the hobbling scene and the gory fight near the end, which I thought to be overly sadistic. Surely these were unnecessary? I understand the book was gorier, however.Overall, watchable but with longueurs.

reviews.review_title: So don't kill off your central character ...
reviews.content: Stephen King's novel 'Misery' comes to the screen in this scary, chilling, and extremely well-acted film. James Caan has his best role for years as Paul Sheldon, celebrated author, who is rescued from a storm by his No. 1 fan Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates). All goes well until he decides to kill off his long-standing character, Misery.Annie then decides to keep him hostage until he re-writes his latest book, bringing Misery back to life. Sheldon becomes more and more under the power of his crazed fan, especially after she hobbles him, smashing his ankles so he is unable to walk and escape.This film rightly won plaudits and Oscars, and is probably the best King adaptation to make it to the screen. The two leads are excellent, there is plenty of tension, and the whole thing is worryingly believable. A warning to over-zealous writers everywhere!

reviews.review_title: Subtle Horror Thriller With Profound Results !!!
reviews.content: Misery is not just the name of a book character, but a state of mind !Paul Sheldon(James Caan) a writer extraordinaries on his way to the publishers for a review to the conclusion of the "Misery" series books, unexpectedly runs into a snowstorm, and takes a wrong turn that changes HIS life....Rescued by Annie Wilkes(Kathy Bates),who won an Academy award for this part, and is his NUMBER 1 FAN, nurses Paul while he recuperates,and crosses the line between sanity and madness.Annie,a former nurse, with an INTERESTING background, takes Paul into her house where she assaults and further victimizes him, to coerce a final book for the "Misery"series with an ending she prefers.Paul who is barely ambulatory, desperately seeks to escape his tormentor , but is foiled when Annie sees a ceramic "Penguin" rearranged,facing the wrong direction, and realizes Paul must be corrected for the errors of his ways !!!"Hobbling" takes on a whole new application....Directed by Rob Reiner, one of his better works , takes you into the world of Annie Wilkes, a nurse whose background would make Freud scratch his head. She has had a history of being around newborns whose life expectancy has been shortened considerably !The NUMBER 1 FAN of Paul Sheldon, his cross in life to bear, torments and increases his disabilities in order to help him create the ULTIMATE "Misery" book, a nightmare collaboration to say the least !!!Meanwhile, the town Sheriff "Buster" McCain(Richard Farnsworth) is trying to solve the disappearance and stumbles onto Annie and his fate is set !There is a Bittersweet and Tender moment when Annie reveals a softer side for her feelings about Paul, but they are quickly tempered when she pulls an empty revolver from her robe, and we realize how lost and loveless this woman really is...A compelling story , that will send chills up and down your spine, and every celebrity out there, who is wondering , when or where they might run into their NUMBER 1 FAN..!!!???

reviews.review_title: Clever and suspenseful psychological horror that delivers on several levels.
reviews.content: Misery is a great example of an unpredictable and disturbing story set pretty much entirely in one place that is seemingly in escapable. In 1980, Stanley Kubrick delivered one of the eeriest and best horror films of all time: The Shining, penned originally by Stephen King. Ten years on, James Caan is the trapped Shelley Duvall only it's not just the snow that forbids them to leave but the fact most of the bones below his hips are severely broken. Secondly, in true gender switch fashion; the psycho is that of Annie Wilkes (Bates) who does an equally good job as that of Nicholson in The Shining.Why The Shining was a better film is because it was eerie, unpredictable and genuinely scary  it was an out and out horror as the reason to be scared was due to ghosts haunting the hotel. That said, Misery is still a great film as it uses psychology to scare the audience or if not to scare then at least make uncomfortable. Annie takes care of Paul Sheldon (Caan); a writer wanting to wrap up his recent series of successful books about a girl called Misery, with very efficient professionalism that gradually becomes efficient obsession.The reason this film stands out so well is that individual brilliant acting performances and the way in which the tension is utilised to an effective manner stick out. We, the audience, know the ending to his new book so when Annie goes on and on about how much she loves his books and the character of Misery in particular is particularly outstanding as she's not going to like the ending to his latest book  rather a 'wrapping up of events' as far as the girl of Misery is concerned. Watching Paul's reaction to each individual praise Annie gives to Misery is as excruciating as it is entertaining since we don't know how she'll react. Along with this, you have to take into account the fact that Annie is living in a wooden cabin, by her self, in the middle of nowhere which is enough evidence to suggest you have to be weary.Thankfully, the film doesn't toy around too much with this convention and lets the film flow effortlessly into the bulk of the story  Annie's further decent into madness and Paul's further decent into survival. From here, a series of events some of which are managed by cause and effect, kick in but I got the feeling Annie was the real focus  she was the most 'entertaining' character and we learn more about her than anyone else in the film. Her mental state is hinted at when they are having dinner together and a shrine is visible directly behind Paul, dedicated to Paul. The framing here is the key thing  not only are we being presented with good material in front of the camera what with a character being developed during a simple meal scene but the framing emphasises Paul's character as his head fits in perfectly with the middle of the shrine  a sign of good direction.Paul seems to try everything in the book to try and escape but there is no need to tamper with a snow cat in this film  his broken bones make for an excellent suspense device as he is limited to a wheel chair. He has to do everything in stages when he tries to escape: first there's the getting out of bed, then out of the locked room, then out of the locked front door  maybe there's another way? Oh no, I hear a car engine approaching....... so you can see that suspense and the feeling of being trapped really work well together to create an atmosphere.Misery does well in its overall delivery. The story of the old trooper trying to crack the case in true Scatman Crothers style as well as the way in which he has a look around the house alá Psycho (1960) may feel copied but it's just good suspense; a feeling of plagiarism that is partially erased by the extremely satisfying final fight scene which acts as a great payoff for the rest of the film. A tight and uneasy horror film that delivers in suspense over scares.

reviews.review_title: In the country no one can hear you scream (rental)
reviews.content: It's funny but this SK work reminds me of one of my greatest scary movie when I was a kid: it's a old (1975) french movie titled La Cage featuring Lino Ventura (as athletic as Caan) who is trapped in the basement by his crazy ex wife (is this pain a women trademark?). Anyway this kind of story terrorizes me because it's dear home becoming a cruel enemy and being still is a terrible nightmare! So that's why this work has always resonates with me. If the novel (among the last good ones SK wrote) had boring stuff (this goddess thing), the movie was attacked for the foot affair and the exterior scenes: I don't really mind because it features the excellent and future David Lynch old hero from Straight Story! I hoped that the audio commentary from the screenwriter would be interesting but his memory fails about this long past and he doesn't speaks much. Maybe Bates won the Oscar for it but I prefer her as Dolores Claiborne. I never liked much Caan (except in Rollerball) so maybe he is good here because for one time, he is less bragging Anyway I found his room and the cottage very cozy in a beautiful setting so the movie is enjoyable if you look to be stressed without bloody gore...

Rob Reiner takes William Goldman's script about a writer getting in a car accident only to be saved by a super psychotic to new ground with his fresh approach and innovative camera work.  Based on the Stephen King novel, Misery tells the story of a writer meeting his worst nightmare:  his number one fan!  There are so many plusses about this film that make it a wonderful, suspenseful film.  The writing is very good and very literate. The audience is treated with intelligence when supplied with subtle allusions and humour in dialogue.  The acting is top-notch all around.  The two leads are incredible and BOTH deserved some recognition for their performances.  James Caan plays the writer with two legs crushed and unable to walk in the home of Kathy Bates, a former nurse.  Bates gives the performance of her career as this woman capable of being incredibly nice one moment and then totally insane the next.  In fact the quality that makes Bates's performance all the more chilling is the innocence she seems to radiate through her perverse character.  Rob Reiner shoots her well too.  He uses very effective close-ups and the camera always seems to be looking up at her...thus making her seem bigger and larger than life.  The opposite with Caan who is always shot in a down position.  Actors Richard Farnsworth and Francis Sternhagen play a sheriff and his wife, and one wishes they were in the film a bit more for the witty reparte they employed.  An enjoyable film...a chilling film.  Underneath it all is the tenuous relationship that exists between an artist and his/her "fan."

Misery is a typically dull and overrated Stephen King adaptation. It lacks the sleazy and trashy depths of his worst works, but the story is a dull and monotonous rambling where the romance writer is tormented by an obsessed fan. In the novel, Annie Wilkes is the potentially sympathetic character - a heavy-set schizophrenic who desires the world which is clean and beautiful like a frilly romance. But she is also a serial killer who makes the repulsive bestsellerist suffer. Neither character is especially interesting and Paul Sheldon is also downright obnoxious. All this is faithfully copied in the movie - characters are not interesting, nor is a story, and despite certain slickness, the movie is a total waste of too short life.

James Caan, Kathy Bates, Richard Farnsworth, Frances Sternhagen and Lauren Bacall star in Rob Reiner's 1990 thriller based on Stephen King's novel. Caan (The Godfather) plays Paul Sheldon, a best-selling novelist who gets in a bad car accident during a winter storm. He's rescued and nursed back to health by woman, Annie Wilkes (Bates) who happens to be his number one fan. Paul discovers that Annie is unbalanced and that his life may be in danger when he's held captive in her house. The late, Farnsworth plays Sheriff, Buster who investigates Paul's disappearance, Sternhagen plays Buster's wife & deputy, Virginia and Bacall plays Paul's agent, Marcia Sindell. This is a great film, Caan and Bates are terrific in it, especially Bates and Mark Shaiman's score is also good. I recommend this.
Extreme level of thrill,curious drama and amazing film .not even boring for 1 second brilliant direction,strong acting

Making a novel isn't all that bad, even if the fan is more disturbed than the character of a book. In "Misery" Stephen King brings it all in this motion picture. Here you have a very brilliant author, Paul Sheldon(James Caan) who leaves his house for New York. He leaves in his Mustang in the snow, loses control of the car, and wrecks it. When is rescued by a nurse named Annie Wilkes(Kathy Bates) very helpful, but very deadly! She is a big fan of Sheldon and is curious about her favorite character "Misery". She gives Paul all the care in the world, until she finally becomes unhinged. She's a murderous nurse. After finding out what kind of a person she is, he's in deep trouble. After finding her penguin is facing the other way, she drugged, strapped, and re-breaks Paul's legs. That scene is brutal, and gut wrenching especially when the left leg wrapped around that block! After being prisoner of that fiend, he manages to get to New York. Safe at last, or is he? Note to self, watch out for psychotic fans! This movie was very intense, and everyone in the movie were outstanding, including Caan and Bates. She was so amazing! Rating 5 stars!

reviews.review_title: Elevated by standout performances from James Caan and Kathy Bates
reviews.content: Kathy Bates is absolutely awesome in this one. It is likely one of the best, if not the best, Stephen King adaptations. Reiner proves that he can pull off a good horror flick and James Caan simply elicits pity as the man who is at the mercy of his fan.

This was a film that I used to catch in parts on the movie channels growing up all of the time. I don't think it was until my sister actually bought the film on DVD that I saw it all the way through. I might have actually read the novel by Stephen King before actually seeing it start to finish as well. The synopsis is after a famous author is rescued from a car crash by a fan of his novels, he comes to realize that the care he is receiving is only the beginning of a nightmare of captivity and abuse.We start this film in a cabin where writer Paul Sheldon (James Caan) is finishing up his latest novel. He has been made famous by his series of romance novels following a woman named Misery. They take place in simpler times, but he has decided to change it up. He goes through his ritual as he finishes the new novel with a cigarette, lit by a wooden match and a bottle of Dom Perignon. He then calls his agent, Marcia Sindell (Lauren Bacall) to tell her he has finished. He gets into his car and then leaves. The problem is a blizzard hits and he crashes. We do see someone helping him out of his car.Paul then comes to in the house of Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates). She informs him that she saved him and it was a good thing, because she is his biggest fan. Paul has two broken legs and separated shoulder. It is a good thing she found him as she is a nurse. She tells him that the roads are closed due to the blizzard and her phone line is down. Once they are cleared and fixed, she will alert the hospital about him. She has administered the best care she can to help him get on the path to recovery.Some time goes on and Marcia calls the local sheriff, Buster (Richard Farnsworth), being worried that her client hasn't been heard from. Buster puts her at ease and starts to look into it. His wife and deputy Virginia (Frances Sternhagen) helps as well. They don't find any trace of him, but Buster feels something isn't right.Annie asks if she can read the new novel that Paul wrote. He agrees, but things take a turn when she doesn't like it, as she considers it filth. She is even more devastated when she reads his newest novel about Misery and she has been killed off. We see that isn't mentally stable and hurts the man she is supposed to be caring for. She comes up with the idea that he is going to write Misery Returns and fix what he did, against his will. She also tells him that no one knows he's there or that he's even still alive. Paul has to find a way out of this nightmare before it is too late.It is pretty easy to see how this film was nominated for quite a few awards. The concept of this is actually pretty great. We have a writer, who is typecast by the works that he has been making. It has made a good life for him, but he isn't considered to be a good writer. What he is producing is just commercially successful. As an inspiring writer, I can see both sides of this coin here. I'd love to be a writer full time and knowing that my books would sell, but at what cost? If I am writing things that I don't like, would it be that much different from going to a job every day that I don't enjoy? It is an interesting concept here. Also the physical abuse he endures is pretty cringe worthy as well. The title has a duality to it as well, being that he's in Misery with the punishment he's enduring both mentally and physically as well as being the character he wrote about.Going from there, we have the psychopathic Annie. She is doing a good thing by helping Paul. The problem though is she is holding him hostage. She then is forcing him to write something that he doesn't want to against his will. On top of that, she burns the manuscript of something that he is really passionate about. She did say something that I completely agree with though. She complained about the serial shorts that would play before films back in the day. She hated when it would end on a cliffhanger and then the next one would retcon so they could continue it on. This is a big gripe I have with films when they make a sequel and change things so they fit, because a sequel was not in the original plan.The final aspect of the story I really want to cover is Buster and his investigation. I like that he doesn't jump in thinking that he's been taken. It is a gradual thing that feels completely natural. He finds evidence slowly and builds up to figuring out what is going on here. Now this isn't a spoiler, as you know that things have to come to a head. I even like that he starts to read the Misery series to see if he can find something there and when he does, I was all on-board for that.Next to move to the pacing of the film where I think they did a great job. It doesn't take long to get us into the story of Paul coming into the care of Annie. At first we just think that she is a bit socially awkward. I like that they don't show us she is full blown crazy too early, but we do get glimpses. There are some interesting reveals through things she says and does all the way to the point where we see just how insane she is. There is a great scene of Paul as he gets out of the room spliced with us seeing Annie in town. It is tense as we hope he can get what he's looking for and back into his room before it's too late. I also think the investigation by Buster builds at a solid pace to the climax where everything comes to a head. I like the ending and seeing the effects of this nightmare has on everyone.The acting for this film is quite amazing to be honest. Caan I think does a really good job at being helpless early on. I do like that he plays on Annie's emotions to keep things calm, but he's always looking for a way out. Seeing the disappointment and pain on his face are also really good as well. Bates was absolutely amazing. I can see why she won an Oscar for this performance. She seems unstable from the beginning, but the reveals of how crazy she is quite unnerving. Farnsworth and Sternhagen are great. I love their banter back and forth. Their roles definitely help build the tension. I also thought it was great to see a cameo by screen legend Bacall. The rest of the cast definitely rounded out this film for what was needed as well.To the effects of the film, they really didn't use a whole lot of them. This movie is really more based in reality and mostly psychological. The being held captive is where a lot of the fear comes from. The punishment to Paul though definitely made me cringe. It was done practically and looked so real. I also think the blood we get looks good. The wounds inflicted as well. I also think the make-up on Paul to make his car accident injuries look real which was a solid move. The film is also shot beautifully as well.Now with that said, this film is a classic. I think we had a great story here from the mind of King, but director Rob Reiner and writer William Goldman definitely bring it to life. It is terrifying concept to be kept alive like Paul is by this psychopath and forcing him to do something against his will. I think the pacing is great in ramping up the tension and the horror of the situation. Even the investigation by Buster helps in that as well. The acting is absolutely amazing and the effects they use are realistic. The soundtrack of the film doesn't necessarily stand out to me, but it fits the scene for what they needed. This film is great and would recommend it for horror and non-horror fans alike.

This movie gets added to my list of those whose ratings at the imdb site knock me for a loop.  I was sure this one wasn't going to be higher than 6.7.  As to my reaction, I enjoyed Kathy Bates and Lauren Bacall but that was about it.  And even Kathy Bates I felt was asked to do some things that any director worth his or her salt should not have asked her to do (grunting like her sow? Please...)  As to Mr. Caan, he seemed uncomfortable and self-conscious in the role, as a result of which I couldn't get caught up in his plight.  I usually like Richard Farnsworth and Frances Sternhagen, but I found them boring to obnoxious in this outing.The whole thing could have done with a little more subtlety.6 out of 10 from this corner.

reviews.review_title: A Great Monster Movie Without Monster Makeup
reviews.content: The great Kathy Bates, a woman who somehow became a movie star on sheer talent alone, delivered her breakthrough performance after nearly twenty years in the business in MISERY, and won a well-deserved Oscar for it.I have sometimes played the game of predicting who will win on Oscar night. I'm usually wrong, but when I saw MISERY, I said, "That woman is going to win on Oscar night." As I said, I don't usually call it, but I called it in 1990. And again in 1991 with THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS (all four awards; something of a personal best for me), 1993 when I predicted Tom Hanks for PHILADELPHIA despite formidable competition from Liam Neeson in SCHINDLER'S LIST, and once more in 1999 when I predicted Hilary Swank's win for BOYS DON'T CRY. Not much of a record, I know, but trying to predict winners is always fun.But I digress. Rob Reiner was not new to King; he had successfully directed STAND BY ME, based on King's novella THE BODY, some four years previously. But MISERY is as far as I know Reiner's only horror movie, a werewolf story without the werewolf.Paul Sheldon (James Caan), a successful writer of bodice-rippers (think Harlequin Romances) featuring a heroine by the name of Misery Chastain, has just put the finishing touches on his latest novel, his first foray into "literature" after killing off Misery in the final installment of the series. Or so he thinks.Heading for home, he foolishly tries to drive in a blizzard in a vintage Mustang, not the best car for hazardous weather conditions. Naturally enough he has a bad accident and runs off the road, the car flipped over on top of him and both his legs badly mangled.Enter Annie Wilkes (Bates), a former nurse who manages to rescue him from the wreck of his car and put splints and casts on him and tuck him into bed in the guest room of her farmhouse. We discover almost in passing that she is Sheldon's "number one fan," a declaration that most authors have probably heard more than once, but there's something about the way Annie says it that is just a bit...off.At first, she appears fairly normal, if a bit odd (she has an aversion to cursing and some of the things she comes up with to replace curse words are laugh-out-loud funny), but it is not long before we discover that Annie is in fact the werewolf; in the right conditions, given the right provocations, she becomes a ravening lunatic with a dangerous look in her eyes that quite threw me the first time I saw it.I won't say anything more about what happens; this one would truly be spoiled by too many spoilers. Bates is a revelation, and Caan, who as an actor has sometimes coasted along on looks and charm, is forced here to actually give a performance, and it's a damned good one. Also on hand are delightful cameos by Richard Farnsworth, Frances Sternhagen, and Lauren Bacall.But at the end of the day, it is Bates's monumental performance that is the engine that drives this ship. Right into stormy weather. Hang on to your seats and enjoy.

James Caan plays writer Paul Sheldon. When he crashes his car in a ferocious snow-storm, it proves to be a very bad day for him. For Annie Wilkes, it proves to be an improbably good day, for not only does she find and rescue him from the wreckage, but the situation allows her to look after a hero of hers – she is an his 'number one fan' – as he convalesces in her spacious home.Every actor in this small cast has been blessed with a wonderfully expressive face. Director Rob Reiner seems very happy to film a lot of moments in close-up. This leads us to appreciate every raised eyebrow, every wistful look into space and to determine exactly the kind of mood Annie happens to be in on her latest visit to Sheldon's sickbed. The camera often almost zooms into her face as she walks into a scene – most effectively following the film's most harrowing scene which guarantees more than a wince, when she coos 'God, I love you.' She has his books set aside as soon as they are released, she has a documented – notorious even – history of violent, murderous behaviour, she walks around town with her pet pig and is clearly a tolerated local eccentric. And yet it takes local Sheriff Buster – yes, that's right (Richard Farnsworth), forever to conclude she may have something to do with his disappearance. Farnsworth has also been blessed with eloquent features, and we immediately warm to Buster's kindly ways. Which is just as well, because otherwise our patience would be sapped by his inability to recognise the blatantly obvious.So while the story takes a lot of investing into – the coincidence of Annie's hero falling into her proverbial lap, and the Sheriff's hopelessness – the cast and stark direction gives the production its legendary status.

Welcome to every author's nightmare. When famous writer Paul Sheldon (James Caan) flips his car during a blizzard, he is miraculously "rescued" by Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates)  his self-confessed number one fan. However, as he sits in her guest room with two broken legs, waiting for the snow-blocked roads to clear, he could never have imagined just how obsessed this woman actually is. Though Sheldon became famous for writing a series of novels featuring heroine Misery Chastain, he has since grown to hate this character, unceremoniously killing her off in his latest story, "Misery's Child," and setting to work on a "real" novel. When Wilkes finds this out, she is absolutely livid with rage, taking Sheldon as her effective captive and forcing him to write a sequel in which her favourite literary character is resurrected.Legendary horror author Stephen King has often excelled at writing stories about characters who are themselves authors, some of them no doubt inspired (hopefully only partially) by his own personal experiences. Some of these have been translated to the screen with masterful results (such as Stanley Kubrick's 'The Shining'), whilst others have not been quite as successful (David Koepp's 'Secret Window' was saved only by a solid performance from Johnny Depp). 'Misery' is most certainly one of the former, a nail-biting suspense thriller that will leave you feeling both excited and drained.James Caan is very good as Sheldon, a man faced with a terrifying situation in which he is helpless to do anything. Likewise, Richard Farnsworth is very entertaining as Buster, the local town sheriff, who suspects that there might be something unusual about the author's disappearance. But full honours go, of course, to an Oscar-winning Kathy Bates, who is exceptional as Wilkes, snapping like clockwork between mild-mannered gushing and murderous animosity. Her chilling  but certainly not subtle  performance is not one that you are likely to forget quickly.

Pros:
Three very intelligent characters, really allowed the writers to get the characters consistent and well written, especially Annie
Very detail focused, get a good feel of the setting and every small piece in it
Very focused, always know what's happening
Great at keeping you unsettled, Annie's great mix of crazed and fan works too well, and the isolation of the outdoors and the house is always present
Music and set design is effectiveCons:
Few things are unnecessary or unexplained, pig goes nowhere and shotgun was random
Cop was ultimately not any part of Paul getting freeBest part: her getting pissed when she finds out he killed his character, a perfect combination of Annie's two big traits
Worst part: cop dying, a little on the nose with him losing another avenue of escape

Exciting film about a writer (Caan) held captive by a "devoted fan," played deviously by Oscar winner Kathy Bates. Rob Reiner's direction is swift and the script is quick paced and exciting. The best of the King adaptations.

Wonderfully uncomfortable movie. A very interesting script keeps you engaged and rooting for the lead to get out of the nightmarish situation. Good characters, slow pace, but nice and engaging. Stand the test of time.

reviews.review_title: An anguishing and thrilling confinement story
reviews.content: Complete isolation, total inability to move, Misery narrates the anguishing story of a man trapped in a room by a psychotic killer nurse.Paul Sheldon is a very sly and self-controlled character, with whom the spectator easily empathises. The actor succesfully uses body language and facial expressions as a realistic and fascinating mean of communication, thus increasing the bond between the spectator and the character.The plot is easy and the setting is basically a room in a cozy house, but the movie was able to keep the viewer's involvement high for all its duration.The figure of Annie Wilkes was also very powerful and the music and the framings strengthened her image: an impulsive, unpredictable, bipolar, aggressive and violent woman.Some features of the movie vaguely reminded me of Kubrik's masterpiece "Shining", for the theme of the isolated house and the deviated antagonist who threatens and holds hostage the few victims of the house... And also the presence of a typewriter!Specifically about writing, I must underline that I really appreciated that the movie developed around the topic of writers and creative writing: Annie forces Paul to burn his novel, which is very precious to a writer because it is the uninque result of his inspiration and creativity, and it took a lot of effort... And she monitors him, obliges him to write what she wants, taking away art, freedom (which are the elements that make creative writing special) from his work.I really felt the pain in those moments.In addition, I also noticed the parallel development of the sheriff's investigation: well made in the sense that they didn't feel non coherent with the rest of the narration and, finally, cherry on top, the small funny scenes during the movie (in general) didn't make it lose in quality.In a nutshell, what really made me appreciate this movie was the constant emotional involvement that it gave me for its whole duration: plausible and interesting development of the plot, appreciable and unexpected plot twist and an excellent interpretation and description of the two main characters.

I took a quick look at the "hated it" reviews, and no one mentioned the not-so-subtle anti-Christian bent that permeates this film. Should we expect anything less from Rob Reiner? He directed the inane "The American President" in which the protagonist was a card-carrying member of the ACLU, an organization founded by a member of the Communist Party USA.Annie is deranged, but the Christian cross is very prominently hanging about her neck in every scene. In one of the final scenes, she explains to the sheriff--who she will soon kill--that she had been praying that her favorite writer was safe after his car accident. Of course, a few short moments before she had dragged her favorite writer's body down to the cellar.This is all from a God-fearing Christian. And this tripe is all from a leftist director who directed the flop "North" about a child trying to sue his parents. By the way, thankfully I never sat through "North" or "The American President". In the latter film the opening credits were sickening enough: count how many Democrats are shown versus Republicans. The fact that he showed LBJ--one of the most corrupt clowns who ever sat in the oval office, was proof enough that this film was to be severely avoided."Misery" would have been much more watchable if Reiner kept his anti-Christian views to himself instead of putting them on celluloid.

I've got personal beef with about 95% of King adapted films as for some reason I can't get on with his lack of originality and at times his works feel overly complicated and pretentious but nevertheless I went into this with some knowledge of its appreciation. I wouldn't go as far as saying I enjoyed it as it felt a bit bland as you'd expect from a film which essentially depicts cabin fever in some form it's really at times very outdrawn and bland, however for every 10 minutes of boredom there is a good handful of entertaining moments and really ingenious use of film form which require 100% attention and lack satisfying pay offs. But as you might expect, you can't really save a film from the odd moment and such it's largely uninteresting and frankly does have many close running parallels to Psycho now I think about. A lesser film than its 'inspiration' the performances and the odd moment are really all you can take away from this, but in fairness it's in my bracket of 'liked' (and I use that word very lightly) King adaptations

This was a rather faithful adaptation of the Stephen King novel. The DVD jacket talks about how it required the correct director and cast, and they got both right. The leads were perfect with Kathy Bates (Oh, God, they got that right-she was great in that role and deserved her Oscar for her part) and James Caan as the writer who suddenly finds himself down on his luck and imprisoned by his number one fan. The interaction between the two leads was also great and led to an inevitable showdown. Of course, formula was used, but what movie doesn't use it? Basically, it was the type of movie that shows that you can make the most of a limited setting and a (mostly) limited cast. This was one of my favorite Stephen King novels-I think it was autobiographical in that he feels imprisoned to write horror. It was a horror story without the portrayal of monsters or demons.*** out of ****

Several factors make this horror film entertaining. First, the character of Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates) is so interesting. Living alone in an isolated farmhouse, nurse Annie comes across as resourceful, physical, observant, skilled, and competent. At the same time, she's naive, lonely, and delusional. Second, Kathy Bates animates the character with such verve and passion that we have no problem believing in Annie. She seems so real, so homely, such a kind, motherly woman, imperfect perhaps, with a slight temper. But hey, everyone is entitled to have a few imperfections.In addition, the script's dialogue exudes humor throughout. At a candlelit dinner on a card table, as a melancholy Liberace song plays in the background, Paul (James Caan) patronizingly asks Annie how she makes such great meatloaf. With great sincerity and pride, she responds: "My secret is I only use fresh tomatoes ... and to give it that little extra zip, I mix in some Spam with the ground beef". Marvelous.The script's theme is likewise ingenious. Paul, as a famous writer, commands respect and power. By contrast, Annie is a nobody, common and powerless. Yet, the story flip-flops the power structure, and places Annie in control. We sympathize with Paul. But we respect Annie. And ultimately, this is a story about Annie Wilkes, not Paul Sheldon.Competent cinematography, detailed set design, amplified sound effects, and good support performances all enhance the film's production.My only quibble is the casting of pugnacious James Caan as Paul; I would like to have seen what Dustin Hoffman or Robert Redford could have done with the role. Also, the film's climax is a tad over-the-top."Misery" is a slow-moving story about a lonely woman whose outward humanitarian behavior camouflage sinister motives, as she traps a famous writer in her rural sanctum. It's a fine film. And Kathy Bates certainly deserved her academy award.

reviews.review_title: Feels like a cheap TV movie. Stick with the book instead.
reviews.content: World famous author Paul Sheldon crashes his car whilst driving in a blizzard but is rescued by nurse and super-fan Annie Wilkes who has read everything he's ever published as well as reading and viewing every interview he's ever given. Sheldon finds himself trapped with multiple injuries included compound fractures to his legs meaning that he is immobile and dependent on Wilkes to care for him. She also tells him that the telephone lines and down and roads closed, both of which are lies. Things take a darker turn still when Wilkes goes and buys the latest book by Sheldon which has just been published (yes the road to town has mysteriously been reopened but there's no mention of Wilkes taking Paul to a local hospital) only to discover that her favourite character Misery has died during childbirth. Wilkes isn't happy about this. This is bad news for Sheldon.Misery explores the obsessive, irrational fan devotion that was explored in very different circumstances in Scorsese's meisterwerk The King of Comedy, a film that bombed at the box office whilst Misery was a huge hit but is inferior in comparison. Oh, the irony.Before seeing Misery for the first time I had read and thoroughly enjoyed Stephen King's masterful novel of the same name. The film adaptation feels like the finer nuances of the novel have been erased to make a big screen shocker that contains great performances by Kathy Bates (Wilkes) and James Caan (Sheldon) with Paul's literary agent being portrayed effortlessly by the ever divine Lauren Bacall.But the film also feels like some kind of TV movie that lacks not just the depth of King's novel but also the cinematic grandeur that might have been envisaged and realised by another director other than Rob Reiner.Misery feels like an attempt to hit big at the box office by creating two dimensional characters and cheap shocks rather than delivering anything with real intelligence. And it worked. Misery brought in the money and earned Bates an Oscar. But watch Misery next to other, better King adaptations such as The Shining and Carrie and you'll see what I mean. There's no comparison.

Excellent acting in this very suspenseful movie.
It keeps you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end.

A writer wants to make the step from writing (commercial succesful) pulp to writing literature but is afraid for the reaction of his readers. This theme forms the basis for the film "Misery" in which writer Paul Sheldon (James Caan) becomes literally the prisoner of his number one fan Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates).The film which reminds very much of "What ever happened to Baby Jane?" (1962, Robert Aldrich) shows that adoration can be as dangerous as jealousy. In a brilliant performance of Kathy Bates her Annie Wilkes is not insane all the time but does have her outbursts. This only makes it scarier.The film is based on a novel by Stephen King. Most of the books of King become movies and as a general rule the less violent the book, the better the movie. "Misery", which only becomes real violent towards the end, fits into this rule. It was the second King adaptation by Rob Reiner, after "Stand by me" in 1986, and he is up to the task. According to IMDB ratings only Frank Darabont, who made the King adaptations "The Shawshank redemption" (1994) and "The Green Mile" (1999), is his superior.Cinematographer Barry Sonnenfeld, who also did "When Harry met Sally" (1989, Rob Reiner) and sometimes works with Joel and Ethan Coen, did a perfect job. He alternates between wide shots of the (beautiful) landscape of Colorado with claustrophobic shots inside.The film heavily centers around the characters of James Caan and Kathy Bates, but there are a few notable supporting roles worth mentioning. The old sheriff of the little village where Annie Wilkes lives is played by Richard Farnsworth, who would be the leading character in "The Straight story" (1999, David Lynch). The agent of Pauls Sheldon is played by the icon of the '40s and '50s Lauren Bacall.

reviews.review_title: one of the best King movies
reviews.content: this was a very well acted, suspenseful film.  i'm not a huge Stephen King fan but i do appreciate some of his works.  This is one of the better ones. Great, tense performances by both Caan and Bates, which is a damn good thing since their pretty much the only ones you see throughout the majority of the film.  very suspenseful if not flat out scary, well worth a look.  8.5/10 for ankle crushing fun!!!

reviews.review_title: Will have you glued to it
reviews.content: Rob Reiner has faithfully brought Stephen King's very frightening novel to the screen here with the movie "Misery". He manages to keep the audience gripping the edge of their seats as he creates a real claustrophobic type terror through the situation of 'Paul Sheldon' (James Caan), a writer who finds himself trapped in the home of his obsessive 'number one fan' (Kathy Bates) after she rescues him from a car accident in the remote Colorado mountains.This film comes highly recommended to all suspense and Stephen King fans, especially given the outstanding Academy Award winning performance from Kathy Bates. Just imagining what will happen next will keep you glued to this, if you can handle it.Tuesday, September 29, 1992 - VideoReiner's taught direction and Kathy Bates' marvellous, unnerving performance make "Misery" a chilling, suspenseful film that shouldn't be missed by Stephen King and Horror/suspense fans.James Caan and the editing crew are also worth an honourable mention. Scary stuff!Saturday, April 24, 1993 - Video

Authors always end up writing about writing. Naked Lunch might be the best movie about the troubles of disobedient typewriters, but Misery is the scariest(The Shining beats it, but it's not all about writing).The plot is deviously simple and captivating, somehow one can feel that King has worried quite a bit about the events in the book/movie. What is also very good is, that at no point does the plot feel unbelievable. Fans can be VERY disconcerting, as you can see all over the Internet.The acting is spot on. James Caan's performance is very believable and you can really sympathize with him. Kathy Bates is nothing short of brilliance and beats most of Hollywoods pretty faces by a mile. They way she perfectly comfortably changes from cheery and silly to outright murderous is great.Directing is nothing special. It's solid and it carries the good script and the great performances.Misery is certainly worth the time. It's scary, but not hauntingly scary, unless you're a famous novelist. 8/10.

reviews.review_title: A must see...Kathy Bates is perfect and
reviews.content: James Caan is surprisingly good. You must also read the book- even if you are not a fan of Stephen King- you will like this book, and find it horrifying.I just re-read the book again, and found many insightful passages. King's character "Annie Wilkes" is brought to life by Kathy Bates. A fictive personality, Wilkes is a schizoid psychotic, obsessed with writer Paul Sheldon (Caan).The setting is the isolated mountains of Colorado- Wilkes is a retired nurse, who initially helps Sheldon after a near-fatal car accident. It is not long before he realizes he is a captive audience, and Wilkes is his "Number one fan". Bates is believable because she is so unpredictable; one moment she is loving and protective; the next she is sharpening her ax.This film is suspenseful, and more terrifying because, unlike many of other King's adaptations, does not have the element of the supernatural. The fright factor is based on human nature, alone. That is one of the primary reasons most audiences will enjoy this film, even if they are not a fan of Stephen King.

reviews.review_title: "Mix a little spam with the ground beef"
reviews.content: In our post-Hitchcock era, it's often forgotten how much design and formula there is to this kind of thriller, how a picture like this requires precision of timing and technique, space and structure. No matter how ingenious your concept and storyline are, if they're not presented properly they will no more thrilling than a dry account in a newspaper.Of course, one can't underestimate the importance of a good plot, and this one happens to be just such a work of ingenuity. Steven King's novel upon which Misery is based is one of the modern breed of real-life horror stories. These tend to be very effective if they can suggest a disturbing and perilous situation which any one of us can imagine and fear ourselves getting into. Granted, not every one of us is a celebrated novelist as Paul Sheldon is, but we could all conceivably be held at the mercy of some obsessive sociopath. And the business of the writer seemingly doomed to write the same trash over and over gives the story an added layer of interest, the characteristic hook that a good psychological thriller needs. Screenwriter William Goldman retains the core and most of the key aspects of King's novel, but condenses it well for the screen, also adding touches which keep it moving well for the motion picture format, such as the angle with the sheriff's investigation.And a good thriller, no matter how expertly written or constructed, needs a decent cast. Kathy Bates's portrayal of a murderous obsessive is incredibly believable in its superficial charm, mood swings and constant hint of the bizarre, but what really makes it brilliant is the way she works it for the needs of the movie. Her timing and delivery seem expertly calculated to make us wonder just when she will kick off again. In those moments of silence before she speaks, her expression is mysterious, unreadable, and we can't tell whether she is about to tell Paul she loves him or to savagely assault him. She even seems aware of the comical aspects of her own character, emphasizing Annie Wilkes's stranger utterances for comedic effect, without ever losing sight of the underlying realism of her performance. James Caan is very good too. His part here may consist chiefly of pained grimaces, but there is a certain art to that too which Caan has mastered.But these things would be worth little if they weren't put together properly. Misery seems like an unusual assignment for director Rob Reiner, who began his filmmaking career with the acclaimed mockumentary This Is Spinal Tap and followed it up with a series of warm-hearted comedy dramas like Stand By Me and When Harry Met Sally. And yet Reiner is an adaptable fellow because he does not seem to consider himself an artist – he simply applies himself to the needs of the picture, and as he himself has stated he actually set out to learn the techniques of making a thriller when he got signed for Misery. He learned good. Crucial here is Reiner's distortion of space, with lots of confusing close-ups and wide-angle lenses which flatten the foreground and pull the backgrounds forward. In the occasional wider shots of the bedroom where most of the movie takes place we see there is actually a lot of empty space around the bed, which gives us a bleak sense of isolation, and makes the surrounding walls seem all the more oppressive. Reiner even makes sure the scenes outside the house, such as those in the sheriff's office, are not too wide open, with few big landscape shots or visible skies. The audience may be privy to other goings-on, but we are not allowed to escape from the feeling of claustrophobia.The value of these techniques may seem a little tenuous – but they do genuinely work. Space, timing, and visual arrangements can have a strong psychological impact. It is crucial for a picture like this that we share in Paul Sheldon's sense of entrapment and helplessness. Reading a plot synopsis wouldn't be scary, but seeing the plot visually presented in the right way can be a terrifying experience. And this is also why there are so many thrillers out there that have a good idea but simply don't work in practice, or why sometimes an original movie can be brilliant but the remake is an unfortunate waste of celluloid. And the reason we don't often realise that we are being manipulated is that the very best directors do it so well we don't even notice.* * *Note: This is not an attempt to disparage King's novel by suggesting that written thrillers are not as good as cinematic ones. Novels have their own techniques for enthralling us, ones which Mr King is certainly well-versed in.

I hadn't seen this film in years and wasn't quite sure how it would hold up, but it remains a strong example of a chamber-piece horror film that excels at slow burn horror and suspense. James Caan plays romance novelist Paul Sheldon, who's in a horrific snowbound car wreck, but is "rescued" by his #1 fan Annie Wilkes, played by Kathy Bates in a brilliant and terrifying performance. Sheldon soon realizes his savior is in reality holding him captive, but there is little he can do due to the remoteness of her house and his wheelchair bound state. What ensues is a game of cat-and-mouse between Caan and Bates that is suspenseful, frightening, and utterly thrilling. The film is tightly directed by Rob Reiner ("Stand by Me" "A Few Good Men" "The Princess Bride" "When Harry Met Sally") and is smartly scripted by William Goldman ("Magic" "Marathon Man" and the under-appreciated "Dreamcatcher," along with non-genre classics like "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" "All the President's Men" and "The Princess Bride") based on a Stephen King novel of the name. Goldman's script gets major kudos for making this chamber piece horror film believable. Sheldon is an intelligent character and Goldman has him try all of the things an intelligent person would do in order to try to escape, which makes the situation all the more terrifying. Caan is perfectly cast in the role of Sheldon, a tough guy macho on-screen personality who finds himself uncharacteristically laid low, making this plights all the more disconcerting. But it's Bates who steals the show as Sheldon's obsessed and deranged fan, determined to keep Sheldon all to herself at any cost. There are few other characters in the story, but the actors in those roles are equally memorable. Richard Farnsworth is excellent as a small-town sheriff investigating Sheldon's disappearance, as is Frances Sternhagen who plays his wife. It's also a treat to see Lauren Bacall in a small supporting role as Sheldon's publisher, but for the most part, the film is all Caan and Bates. Overall, "Misery" is a class act of a horror movie, which is a rare occurrence, and is essential viewing for fans King, Caan, Bates, or of horror films or thrillers in general. SPOILER ALERT! The hobbling scene still shocks today and is just as cringe inducing as ever.
