reviews.review_title: A tense thriller with great performances
reviews.content: With every plus there's a minus. Life comes with scales and scales require balance. People want success but don't know how to handle it once they do. Being rich is great unless one doesn't know how to be fiscally responsible. The same goes for fame. It's great being the center of attention, but sometimes it's not so great. This film is a great example of that, despite the actual story being an allusion to the author's alcohol addiction. Ordinary people are capable of extraordinary things. Sometimes those things are of no benefit to anyone. So how could being a famous writer lead to such a situation? Try meeting a deranged fan who won't let up on the harassment.The plot is about famous author Paul Sheldon (James Caan) who just finished a new book he's ready to publish. On his travels he has a car accident and is rescued by a devoted fan named Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates). At her place she nurses him back to health, only for Sheldon to realize Wilkes is more than a fervent fan. Her desire is to be Sheldon's next character of focus. Meanwhile, Sheldon's family and agent Marcia Sindell (Lauren Bacall) are concerned about his disappearance. For help, they contact the local sheriff Buster (Richard Farnsworth) and wife Virginia (Frances Sternhagen) to see what they can do. Based on the novel by Stephen King and written by William Goldman who'd later pen Chaplin (1992) and Maverick (1994), makes this quite a watch.It's interesting that viewers get to know quite a lot about the main characters just by the trailer alone. Even with all that being revealed, there's still much to see that will keep viewers on the edge of their seats. With Rob Reiner directing in this genre for the first time, it's all the more captivating. Before this Reiner had also directed Stand By Me (1986) and The Princess Bride (1987). Like mentioned before, the film has a balance between the high strung and more pleasing moments believe it or not. Seeing Paul Sheldon trying to find a way to escape his captor's home is beyond nerve racking because of how unhinged Annie Wilkes is. But then there's also the scenes involving Buster where his deductive skills play a major part in the story.However, a weak point in the story occurs when a plot device is used to tie two different plot threads together. These two plot threads share the plot device, but when looking at it from a bigger point of view, it seems very convenient. Almost like the probability of such a thing happening is completely unlikely. This doesn't take away the performances from the cast members. While Kathy Bates had been acting prior to this feature, it was here she made her breakout role. She plays her character well alongside veteran actor James Caan who was in hits like The Godfather (1972) and Rollerball (1975). The more intriguing scenes are delivered through Sternhagen and Farnsworth's characters. Farnsworth is also known for starring in The Grey Fox (1982).The camerawork is also well done. Shot by Barry Sonnenfeld, who would later on direct The Addams Family (1991) and Men in Black (1997), the camerawork here is shot competently for the film. The viewer truly gets to see how mentally unhealthy Annie Wilkes is in her home and the stress that Paul Sheldon develops because of it. The music was another great component. Composed by Marc Shaiman, the film score again has a stable mix of tones in different areas of the story. There are unsettling cues with piano and strings for Sheldon's hardship, as well as softer easy going motifs using horns for Buster's investigative scenes. Unfortunately, the score is a bit short in material but still captures the feel of the movie.Taking out one convenient particular part of the story that helps move the plot, this thriller will hold its viewers' attention. The tension only cranks up as time goes on thanks to the acting, camerawork and music.
A must watch for fans of the king of horror Stephen King. Kathy Bates did an outstanding job. The movie was incredible, and wasn't so far fetched. I could see this happening in real life.

reviews.review_title: Deadlocked into a Battle of Wits
reviews.content: No one involved in this story -- not the actors, not the director, not even the screenwriter -- indicate any experience or even acquaintance with the horror genre. That this became the hit of 1990, bringing an unknown actress by the name of Kathy Bates into light as a Force to be Reckoned With, granting her an Oscar for her supreme, textured interpretation of what would and could have been (in lesser hands) a one-note role was rather surprising.1990 was a rather weak year for actresses -- few were the roles that really stood out from the heap. Annie Wilkes came to life on screen, and that changed everything. Thanks to the dark magic of Stephen King and the tortuous creative experience that led him to write about the ultimate fan and the nauseous ties that would bind Annie to her object of her desire, MISERY came to light, itself a distant descendant of the type of psychological terror depicted in WHAT EVER HAPPENED TO BABY JANE? but nevertheless a powerful tale describing one of the most mobile moments in the history of horror: the hobbling scene.Originally described as one where Annie hacks off Paul Sheldon's foot with an axe (she of course, hacks off a finger and serves it as a birthday candle later on in the book, which is gruesome to the extent of being unreadable at times), it's effect is no less chilling and stomach-churning when shown in its more muted version -- the one which Reiner and Goldman translated onto the silver screen. Because Bates shows Annie as someone who really, deep down, has some extreme, twisted "love" for Sheldon and his art, the fact she has to make sure he will never escape her gives this moment a complexity it wouldn't have had any other way. Annie is a Creation, a Woman who is a mass of chaotic energy who wants to ensure this fictional world will survive and make her bleak, unlivable world bearable.MISERY works up right until its end, which is predictable -- a necessary event, because we've been waiting for a physical battle between Annie and Paul and Misery all this long. To see the comeuppance of such a dreadful character is the goal for any story. Not to show it would be anti-climactic. To show too much would be camp. Reiner and Goldman create a delicate balance, one that is extremely tense, riveting -- but the Final Scare comes as perfunctory... and that robs the movie of its Effect. (Of course, thank WAIT UNTIL DARK for this, although the climactic moment in the book flattens the story's emotional punch.) However, this is a classic of modern horror, totally enjoyable, and a complex character study of the battle of wits between two people who depend on the existence of an invisible third.

Sometimes a film is remembered for a single performance, or for a particularly memorable moment, or for the expertly crafted score. For me, Misery ticks all those boxes and more. It's one of the most underrated thrillers, and movies, of the 1990's, packed with great dialogue, interesting shots and a killer ending. Rob Reiner's magnum opus, I'd go as far as saying. Some would argue it edges slightly too far away from the source material by Stephen King, but as I haven't read it, I'm going to judge solely on what I've seen, and William Goldman's script is brilliant.I could write for hours about Kathy Bates in the role of Annie Wilkes, but I'll endeavour to be succinct. It's a big, bold, brave performance that occasionally veers towards the more animated, but never, not for a single moment, loses its core of truth. Many other actresses would have toned it down, made Annie quieter and more inwardly intimidating, but the film would have been poorer for that. James Caan, usually the epitome of charisma, is more restrained here, physically and emotionally, which allows for Bates to really go for it. The result is, in my opinion, one of the most unpredictable and fascinating performances in film.There's a creeping sense of dread running through Misery from the beginning, though it's occasionally pierced with dark and often cheeky humour, almost used to disarm us. The camera shows things from everyone else's point of view, rarely, if ever, from Annie's, adding to that growing feeling of unease and making the whole thing so watchable. Makes you wonder what she'll do next. There are a lot of scenes inside the Wilkes house, but there are some beautiful and picturesque shots of the surroundings and nearby town, as well as Paul's agents office in the city, much needed to break that earlier referenced claustrophobia.The first ten minutes will hook you in, and the last ten will wear you out. As for all the bits in between, well... your ankles might jump a bit, you'll find new meaning to the phrase "number one fan" and you'll witness one of cinema's most captivating and disturbed characters come to life.

Of course when someone thinks of Misery the first thing that springs to mind is Kathy Bates' Annie Wilkes which is one of the best villains ever seen on the screen and played to perfection. However, with a film as excellent as this it has more than one factor going for it. One is the James Caan who's nuanced and authentic performance puts the audience right there in his wheelchair with him.Having not read the novel I can't say how much or what is Stephen King or William Goldman, but who cares? They're both terrific writers and you don't need any further proof than this masterfully crafted work. And finally you have Rob Reiner who fully realizes it into one of the most intense films ever made.Misery is one of the most emotionally demanding films that is filled with moments of high suspense, tension horror and even satisfaction.

reviews.review_title: Misery is both a frightening and brilliant thriller but also a perfect adaption
reviews.content: Misery is very much a Stephen King adaption and something worth adding is how King stated that Misery is one of his top ten favorite film adaptations, it's also the only one to win an Oscar and it's of course for the role Kathy Bates played. She's the villain of the story and it's an extremely well written antagonist and character overall, but most importantly, King made her so real that it's almost terrifying. Kathy Bates did a phenomenal job with her performance as the obsessive and manipulative Annie Wilkes. Misery is directed by Rob Reiner and his direction and the vision he had for the adaption, it's quite superb. The film stars James Caan, Kathy Bates, Lauren Bacall, Richard Farnsworth, and Frances Sternhagen. I actually picked this film because of the recent death of James Caan, who plays the lead alongside with Kathy Bates, their performances are strong and mesmerizing.After a famous author is rescued from a car crash by a fan of his novels, he comes to realize that the care he is receiving is only the beginning of a nightmare of captivity and abuse.Stephen King, you sir are a genius, with the themes and all. But it was William Goldman who adapted the material and wrote the screenplay, his script is terrific. Misery is not a horror movie but it's frightening that uses the psychological-thriller genre to perfection. There's not one single scene that makes you feel bored, if it isn't for the brilliant acting, it's the writing and direction that keeps you on edge. It's a thriller I can recommend.

"Yes, this movie is incredible, amazing, and thrilling, James Caan and Kathy Bates perfomance is an oscar worthy, one of the best thriller movie I've ever seen, i really like the way they build it, making us as the audience uncomfortable with Kathy Bates face shot and her brutallity, overall it's a very good and thrilling movie, highly recommended"

reviews.review_title: This Christmas there will be... Misery.
reviews.content: Best-selling novelist Paul Sheldon is on his way home from his Colorado hideaway after completing his latest book, when he crashes his car in a freak blizzard. Paul is critically injured, but is rescued by former nurse Annie Wilkes, Paul's "number one fan", who takes Paul back to her remote house in the mountains. Unfortunately for Paul, Annie is also a headcase. When she discovers that Paul has killed off the heroine in her favorite novels, her reaction leaves Paul shattered (literally)...It has been a long while since I've seen a very good thriller. Suddenly, I saw this film. "Misery," I will say now, is one of the best thrillers ever made, let alone the best Stephen King adaptation I have seen thus far. What I like about this thriller, as opposed to many other thrillers I've seen was how suspenseful and interesting the whole movie was.The plot is good. The characters are great. The scenes are shot in which it builds up on suspense. The score is perfectly scored. The ending is really satisfying. What more can I say? The performance by James Caan was good enough but the real star in here is Kathy Bates, obviously. No wonder she won an Oscar for her role in the movie.Overall, this is a one of the best satisfying thriller I've seen in a long time. I would also call it one of the best movies ever made. The suspense builds up well and the ideas keep on coming. Watch this if you're a big Stephen King fan or if you just want to watch a great thriller.
I'm admire Kathy bates performance here. But its get my 7 star for this reason only.

reviews.review_title: Paul Sheldon never asked for this Annie 😞
reviews.content: Misery is a horror, thriller and is a film very remotely similar to that of Alfred Hitchcock 1960 Psycho. The story follows Paul Sheldon, a successful writer off of his collection of books that goes by the name of Misery. After he had completed a copy of the final edition to the franchise he meets an unfortunate event in which he goes off the main road and crashes his car on the way to work. After the incident he got saved by Annie, his number 1 fan, which at first seemed like everything was going to comeback to normal once she gets him to the hospital. However what he doesn't know coming for hims is that Annie is someone who is totally obsessed with his Misery books, and wasn't going to have him get off so easily unless he concludes the series her way. Mean while, well all of this is happening, detective Buster has been notified by Paul boss about his recent absents, having him go out on the search.The majority of the film took place in one location which is Annie's house and was mainly told from Paul perspective. There will be cuts to Annie getting into a store or to the detective searching for Paul but other than that the audience is basically in the mind of Paul. This makes for an interesting premise since the main protagonist is helpless and there could always be fatal consequences if he doesn't escape or write the story to her liking.The one who carries this movie of course is Kathy Bates which can be seen by her Oscar win. What makes her performances so special is that, she was able to escalate her emotions from a calm and inviting person to full of agony and resentment when her character is proven wrong. James Caan is also great as the backbone of the narrative in which he was required to act as two different people in one character, a reactionary role, and a role where he has to pretend to like Annie. The reactionary road is harder than it looks in this particular story because it collides with him pretending to show affection to Annie. If he shows a lot of anger while not being able to take her on his own than he would risk getting hurt which James kept a good balance of.Overall I rate this film an 8/10 because although it has a neat premise, and a great main protagonist along with antagonist, I feel that the side characters don't add a whole lot to the story. There were times when the detective was given multiple chances to do the right thing but the writers had him not which was to obviously expand the runtime of the film. However this is a much watch film, even if you are not a horror fan!

Misery is a classic portrayal of top notch tension, and it is up there with such Hitchcock nerve-snapping classics that genuinely grab you by the jugular and don't let go. It is a film for thriller fans, although I warn that it is not for the squeamish, it has limited amounts of violence in it but when it gets going it sure hits you. For the first part of the film you feel all relaxed, and you begin to feel that maybe everything will be alright and that everything you've heard about the film is a load of old cobblers, you think she will heal his horrendous injuries and then release him... but still nothing is further from the truth. After a while you begin to get the signs that everything is not good. It has gone a bit sour, and as you watch the helpless Paul Sheldon (James Caan) try to escape you grind your teeth and bite your nails as he narrowly escapes being caught by his captor Annie Wilkes (played remarkably by Oscar winner Kathy Bates) as he tries to find ways out, and looks around the house she is holding him in whilst she is out shopping and do other such like activities. But why? Well Paul Sheldon is a novelist who has written a string of very successful stories about a heroine named Misery... Hence the name, although I guess there are other reasons for such a title. In his latest edition he has killed her off, and naturally Annie is not best pleased, she is paranoid, and outraged that Paul should write such a book, which as of yet he has not published, so she gets him to burn it and write a new book especially for her. After a while it gets a bit routine, you think she will hold him and then let him go as soon as the book is complete, yet something else is lurking. She is not just holding him to write a book whilst he gets better, but she is getting totally obsessed, and by the time he is getting back to health and he is about ready to go as the book is just about finished she snaps... Wanting to keep him she resorts to the infamous sledgehammer and... well you get the picture. The ending is quite fantastic and the overall impact of this brilliant film is quite overwhelming. It is a very good film with many resounding qualities, but still with flaws it being pretty decent but still pretty lax adaptation of what is a true Stephen Knig masterpiece it can only languish at 8/10. I guess it is hard to do justice by such a great book and I think that sure this film is well worth a few viewing, but there is more pleasure in reading the book than there is in watching the film.

reviews.review_title: Another captivating and brilliant Stephen King horror piece.
reviews.content: It took me a little bit to get really into it but I eventually did for sure. While I like Stephen King adaptations like the Shining and Shawshank Redemption better and while I'm not normally a fan of Kathy Bates (who did her job well in the film and disturbed me as she was meant to), this movie ended up being a real shock and a real treat to watch. Little details add up that you're glad that you kept track of, and the suspense and timing were set up very well when Annie left the house and when she would come back with what Paul would be able to do in the meantime. She got exactly what she deserved in the end too which was satisfying. Aside from A Few Good Men and The Princess Bride, this is Rob Reiner's best movie!

reviews.review_title: Caan And Bates Complement Each Other Beautifully.
reviews.content: I was very privileged to see this film in my youth. I am writing this review in my thirties.This film is a suspense thriller and not a horror film.Examples of Stephen King horror films are: The Dark Half, Graveyard Shift, The Langoliers, IT and Pet Cemetery. These films are classified as horror because they all deal with supernatural creatures.The theme of the film is a race for survival, a battle of wits and the battle between good and evil.Sheldon (James Caan) is good, and Wilkes (Bates) is evil embodied.Bestseller novelist Paul Sheldon (James Caan) is the writer of novels depicting a character, Misery Chastain that has become world famous. After finishing the manuscript of his latest novel, he leaves Silver Creek, Colorado to New York, but he is caught in a blizzard and his car sheers off the road. He is rescued in the nick of time by nurse Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates) and brought to her remote home. Both of Paul's legs are fractured, and he has a dislocated shoulder, leaving him bedridden and largely unable to move.Wilkes role in the film is that of a pure dictator. For a woman starved of a mans presence and touch for many years, she shows a real hatred towards all men. She is not at all aroused by Sheldon, who is a handsome man. So her character is that of a frigid woman - a woman devoid of any sexual appetite. Sheldon tries to seduce her, during a dinner with her but fails.Wilkes pride and joy are Sheldon's novels. After reading his manuscript of his latest book, Misery's Child, which Paul intends to be the final Misery novel, she flies into a rage, brandishing a small table on Paul's head. She masters her temper however, and tells him calmly that she never contacted the hospital, or anyone Paul knows as she earlier claimed to have done.And here is where the film really kicks into gear. The race for survival has begun.Sheldon shows more character than he is given. Not many man in his situation would have dared half the things he did in order to survive. I am reminded of a certain die-hard character....The way he crawls out from his bed in his fatal condition brought the tears in my eyes. And the pain he feels in this film is real.This film has a disturbing scene in it: Wilkes breaks Sheldon's ankles with a sledgehammer in an act of "hobbling". Those of you unfamiliar with the term can "google" it up. This method was used in the South African Diamond mines to discipline workers that stole diamonds. Wilkes explains this to Sheldon before she hobbles him.Won't say any more of the plot. You will have to see what happens next. Loose no opportunity to buy this treasure of a film on DVD.Similar films: Midnight Express, Escape from Sobibor, The Great Escape, Papillon, Saw, Cube, Fortress, The Running Man, Surviving The Game and Escape From Alcatraz. Correspond to me if you are a movie lover. Email Vivekmaru45@yahoo.com and I will recommend you which movies to watch.

reviews.review_title: Reiner's Classic Telling of a Stephen King Novel
reviews.content: In 1990, director Rob Reiner brought back to the screen, the legendary James Caan in his comeback role as novelist Paul Sheldon in Stephen King's "Misery." Also starring is Kathy Bates in her Oscar winning role as Annie Wilkes, Sheldon's number one fan.It all starts when Sheldon is finished writing his latest novel, his masterpiece. When he is driving back to the city during a terrible snowstorm, his car slides off the road and flips over, only to be covered with snow. He is rescued by Annie, a nurse and taken to her home to recuperate. All seemed fine, until the local sheriff came looking for Paul. It is then that Paul Sheldon's life is turned upside down.Nurse Annie turns sadistic and furious with Paul, who in his latest novel, has killed off the heroine. It is not only Paul's soul that gets 'crushed' in the end. However, the film does end on a happy note, as eerie as it may be! Clearly a great Stephen King penned film, it is a sure 9 out of 10!

Rob Reiner directed one of the best movies adapted of Stephen King's novels .. what's makes it so good movie is many elements and the key element is the great performances by James Caan & Kathy Bates .. we are (at least myself) used to see good performances by Mr. Caan in many of his best movies .. he is a clever actor and he did not disappoint me in this movie .. Kathy Bates was the real star here .. I've never seen here in a better performance .. it is one of her best performances (which are rare).Frank ?? (The Straight Story) was cool in the movie .. and his performance was very good.Rob Riener is a good director but sometimes, I feel he is more commercial director than artistic .. in this movie he showed us a combination of the two which wasn't bad at all .. very good, actually. Except for certain scenes that I felt he could do much better. Anyway, in the end the result was good.It is a very good movie .. you will like more if you are a fan of Stephen King's movies.

reviews.review_title: Failed, to be what it should have been
reviews.content: It tries to be a dark, suspenseful, serious drama and yet ends up being slightly dark, slow, boring spoof horror movie. I've seen spoofs of scenes from Misery in adult cartoon comedies that are based in ridiculous nonsense situations and always thought wow that's ridiculous and much more overly simplified and not creditable even in a fictitious cartoon. Upon watching the movie I realized that is the actual scene, the cartoon might have changed the dialogue but the events are the same as the original live action film. Most would describe the plot line as being about a psycho woman who is obsessed with an author, but that doesn't seem to be the case. She seems obsessed with power, his books and possibly the one character in the books but despite the claims she doesn't seem to love him just what he made. If anything she seems a bit delusional and might feel as if she is the character in his books, but it's never explored. The big hole in the movie is why does she love his books and this one character so much that she will go to such extremes to keep the character alive. It's a movie about this woman but never tells you much about her.

reviews.review_title: This is what fear is all about.
reviews.content: When it comes to Stephen King books that are transfered to the big screen this is by far the best. James Caen and Kathy Bates have to take most of the plaudits for why this film is so Brilliant. It is the story of a top writer who has a car crash and is rescued by his no 1 fan, a deranged female nurse who has a history of killing her patients. Some of the scenes are quite horrific , especially when she has to break his ankles to stop him from running away. A Classic you should not miss. 9 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Kathy Bates switches from country bumpkin to raging lunatic with the drop of a hat.
reviews.content: Following on the heels of The Princess Bride and When Harry Met Sally, director Rob Reiner decided to try his hands at a much different genre. As we all know, Hollywood adaptations of Stephen King novels have met with varying levels of success, but Misery marked the second time Reiner directed a story from the prolific horror writer (his first film adaptation was Stand by Me). Upon its theatrical release in 1990, the film was met with wide critical acclaim, which many attribute to Kathy Bates portrayal of a psychopathic country bumpkin (she won the Academy Award and Golden Globe for Best Actress). I've seen Misery at least twice over the years, and it continues to provide the same level of tension I experienced in my initial viewing.Paul Sheldon (James Caan) is a well-known author of romance novels centered on a character named Misery Chastaine. Having completed his latest novel at a country lodge in Silver Creek, Paul sets off through a snow covered pass to deliver the manuscript to his publisher. Along the way, he loses control of his car and crashes into a ditch along the side of the road. As he regains consciousness the next day, he looks down to find his legs severely fractured in the crash, and learns his savior is a middle-aged ex-nurse who runs a pig farm. Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates) describes herself as Paul's number one fan, who relied on the stories of Misery Chastaine to make it through some tough stretches in her life and feels incredibly fortunate to have been given the opportunity to take care of Paul. Unfortunately, everything takes a turn for the worst when Paul's latest Misery novel is released to the local store and Annie finds out Paul killed off the star in the conclusion of the series. In a rage, she demands he make it right by completing a new novel that resurrects the heroine, locking him in her house until it's completed. Desperate for a way out, but physically unable to protect himself or escape, Paul attempts to weather Annie's psychotic outbursts and devise a plan to make it through the ordeal with his life.If you're looking for edge-of-your-seat entertainment, Misery will fit the bill perfectly. The tone is absolutely unnerving as Bates lulls the audience to sleep with her happy-go-lucky side, only to catch us by surprise with her pulse-pounding outbursts of uncontrollable rage. Watching her spiral out of control as she scolds Paul about the use of profanity in his new novel give us our first taste of what's to come, but it's not until she learns of Misery's death that we get a true taste of just how demented the woman is. Watching a film of this nature makes us ponder what we would do in Paul's situation, which steadily turns from bad to worse as the film progresses. He knows his captor is demented from an early point in the film, but as Annie so eloquently states "If she dies, he dies". Paul must constantly remember he's not only a prisoner by Annie's choice, but also a prisoner by his own physical circumstances. It gives the film an almost claustrophobic effect that adds to the building tension.One of the effective aspects of the plot in Misery, is the cat-and-mouse game that Paul and Annie play with one another in the second half of the film. I don't want to give away spoilers (in case there are readers that somehow missed the film up to this point), but Paul ends up becoming just as crafty as Annie through the final act. This is a culmination of his earlier attempts that either result in accidental failure or a tendency to always remain one step behind Annie. I won't divulge what happens, but every time the wine scene approaches, I cringe in anticipation of what's about to take place.From an acting standpoint, Misery is a grand achievement across the board. As I mentioned before, Kathy Bates won Best Actress in 1990 for her portrayal of Annie Wilkes, and I can't imagine a more deserving recipient. Moving flawlessly between innocent sweetness and vicious rage, Bates owns your attention every time she steps into a scene, keeping us guessing with the ever-shifting personality of her character. Caan is equally impressive in the role of Paul, which requires him to remain in a bed or a wheelchair through the entire length of the film. His ability to convey vulnerability over a tough-guy facade is a testament to his acting abilities, and I hope we see more leading roles thrown his way in the coming years. Lastly, I have to briefly mention the late Richard Farnsworth as the local sheriff. Though his part in the film isn't as extensive or challenging as Bates or Caan, he's the perfect choice for a role that demands little more than a soft exterior and a good heart. One of the pivotal moments in the film (and most shocking) involves his character, but I don't think it would be nearly as important if we didn't gravitate toward Farnsworth's charming portrayal in the early stages of the story. If anything, Misery is worth watching simply for the performances from the talented cast.

Rob Riener may best be remembered as a meathead, but this man is an amazing director and has done a masterful job here. I think Alfred Hitchcock couldn't have done a better job at creating a thriller. There is somewhat of an intangible spirit in King's books that doesn't come through on the big screen, most movie adaptations of his novels are inferior at best and downright laughable at worst, but this one is THE BEST adptation of his work that I have ever seen it is every bit as good as his prose even better. Since this film is set mostly in a lonely snow covered farmhouse, Kathy Bates and Jimmy Caan have to carry the film on their shoulders pretty much and both come thru in spades! Kathy Bates may not be very glamerous, but she is an awesome actress and rich deserved that Oscar. In a sense, she has to play four different roles. Let me explain, she plays Annie as good and kind, she portrays her as humerous (when she berates Paul for the swearing in his book), she also portrays her as a sympathetic lonely figure and then she portrays her as evil. Lets not take anything away from James Caan, although he has the easier part (a lot of his part is just acting like hes in terrible pain). He is one of the few actors who can play anything well. By the way, to the people who were chilled by the "hobbling" scene. It could have been worse, in the book she chopped off his foot with an axe and sprayed it with a blowtorch.

reviews.review_title: One of the Better Stephen King Movies
reviews.content: Of all the film adaptations of cherished horror author Stephen King's body of work, one of the man's all time favorites would have to be the feature based on Misery. Directed by Rob Reiner, written by William Goldman, and starring James Caan and Kathy Bates, the film was both a critical and commercial darling on its original fall 1990 release and awarded Bates her very first Oscar. King went on record to call the film one of his all time favorite adaptations of his bibliography, and the film has since remained in cult status for years. Looking back on the feature over 30 years later, is its legacy truly earned or not?The story follows famed novelist Paul Sheldon, who upon getting into a blizzard accident, gets abducted by an obsessive fan named Annie Wilkes. Being the biggest reader of Sheldon's Victorian Misery novel series, Wilkes holds the injured man hostage and forces him to rewrite the finale to the series. It has been very common for die hard fans of some famous creators to be picky with the work they make, but in the case of Annie Wilkes, her obsession with Paul Sheldone borders on more than just that of his books. By hiding her devious cruel nature behind a cheery facade, Annie's entire presence in the film becomes that of a sociopathic manipulator. Meanwhile, Sheldon fears her constant mood swinging behavior while also resenting how much she controls his own life through a book series he wants to move on from. Much of the time, James Caan has to do a lot of physical emotive acting rather than the broad gesture approach he'd normally be known for, presenting an incredibly relatable side to Sheldon that anyone could see themselves in if they also couldn't simply walk.With these scenarios in mind, despite how twisted and vile Wilkes is, the feature cleverly finds time to present a more sympathetic side to her. Despite her sick mind and aggressive nature, it's often hinted how depressed and misguided she truly is in her own view on the world, even if it means to have her favorite book series redone to fit her own needs. In addition to being debatably common to others who stalk celebrities, her irreverent violent tantrums come less from a place of malice than a place of logic foreign to the real world. In a way, Misery is a shocking portrayal of a tragically ill woman who simply couldn't see the grand picture. On another note, the late Richard Farnsworth is charmingly laid back as Sheriff Buster, as his subplot of searching for Sheldon by any means possible paints a relieving contrast from the claustrophobic madness inside the Wilkes residence. Admittedly, Sheldon's agent Marcia Sindell and Buster's wife Deputy Virginia have less screen time to really stick out, but since the main focus is on Wilkes and Sheldon, all is forgiven.Going into the aforementioned claustrophobia, Barry Sonnenfeld's cinematography paints the dreary isolating aroma that a remote Colorado cabin would have. A lot of specific far away shots establish the uncomfortable nature Paul Sheldon faces trapped against his own will, by a diluted fan without a semblance of reality no less. On top of that, Robert Leighton's editing is appropriately reserved up until Wilkes snaps, to which it then goes haywire and becomes more intense than the tone already is. In allowing certain edits and shots to go at a jumpier pace every now and then, the filmmakers cleverly let the pacing take its time before the stakes would understandably get higher. Even when it becomes obvious what will happen to a certain character, the result can still leave an impact due to the high tension led by the overtly demanding monster that is Annie Wilkes. Aided by a somberly sinister score from Marc Shaiman and you have a film that knows exactly when to thrill the audience, by easing them into the fear through quiet subtlety and specific filmmaking.After all these years in the spotlight, Rob Reiner's Misery remains a top contender for the best adaptations of any Stephen King novel. In addition to subtle psychological filmmaking and some sweet side characters, the leads elevate the feature with their standout portrayals of two victims being stuck together under the more evil one's demands. If you haven't seen the film yet or have yet to read the original book, then giving them a go would be a tremendous honor amongst King enthusiasts and the psychological thriller genre. It may engage you more from the mind of a depressed madwoman than most out there.

Wow. Maybe I'm biased, but first of all, I have loved Stephen King since adolescence. Born in 1976 (and having a father completely enamored by everything Stephen King had ever written) and seeing this in my teens was amazing. Scary. Now that I've finally watched this movie again (43😨) I am in one word... Terrified. It's absolute brilliance. I know the background, have followed all of SK's works, and can say that this, my dear friends, is nothing short of his best story. Enjoy

reviews.review_title: Edge of your seat thriller witnessing James Caan being tortured by a classic performance
reviews.content: After doing a creditable job of converting Stephen King's 'The Body' with Stand By Me, Rob Reiner goes one step better with Misery. This intense psychological thriller is genuinely shocking and shows the audience what lunacy does to people whilst at the same time, luring the audience in to a journey of fear that can not be escaped.What makes Misery so memorable is Kathy Bates portrayal of Anne Wilkes which is one of the most memorable performances of the decade. Wilkes is such a complex character; her apparent motherly nature is greatly complimented by her obsessive behaviour towards Caan. It is this obsessive nature that gives the first clue she is psychopathic. When her psychopathic behaviour dominates her personality is when the film really starts to become something special. Her constant outburst are often surprising and her body language shows more than her lines, just how on edge she is. Although not in the same league as Bates, James Caan is a great choice for Paul Sheldon. As an actor who often plays very physical, tough guy roles, his frustration at being bed ridden and chair bound comes across very well in his character and his shock and fear mirror exactly how the audience feel.The infamous 'hobbling' scene is a particularly gruesome scene and will be shown on television for many years to come. The lack of discreteness makes it so real to watch and you really feel the pain when you see it. When the plot unravels on Wilkes' character and her background is explained, the film becomes even more disturbing and shows that Caan is in more trouble than he ever imagined.With Bates' performance stealing the show and the fact it is one of Stephen King's better novels, Misery is a contemporary classic that has more than enough thrills and chills to keep audiences satisfied.

reviews.review_title: Hobbled to be in your company! Top Top movie
reviews.content: Have you ever read a book and the author writes a new book, but it just not what you're had in mind for that characters life and just wish you could meet the author and he could change what you hate about his new book. Annie Wilkes obsessed with her favourite author Paul Sheldon does just that in this dark comedy keeps you glued to the screen from beginning till end. An accident or act of god or fate bring their life's closer than you can imagine. Then when all seems doomed "Buster" spots a line in Sheldon's book and remembers, where that saying was used before in the press and leads him to discover a dark secret. Adapted from Stephen king's book and like many other now Classic Movies this one does not disappoint.

reviews.review_title: One of the best film adaptations of a Stephen King novel
reviews.content: "Misery" from 1990 is a really good film. I don't watch many horror films because I'm not a fan of the genre, especially films that are based on Stephen King novels. But this was a great film. James Caan plays Paul Sheldon, a famous writer who is in a life-threatening car crash in the middle of a snowstorm. He is rescued by his "#1 fan" Annie Wilkes, played by an outstanding Kathy Bates. She nurses him back to health and tells him how much of a fan she is of his novels and of the lead character in them Misery Chastain. But when Paul lets her read his latest unpublished novel, and she finds out that Misery has been killed, she reveals her darker side and refuses to let him go. She forces him to burn his book and write a new novel involving Misery's return. Paul soon realizes that she's mentally unstable and much more than a #1 fan. She unplugs the phone, lies about calling for help, locks the doors, and refuses to let him leave his bedroom. But he still tries to escape and get help. There's the infamous "hobbling" scene where Annie breaks Paul's ankles with a sledgehammer after noticing her ceramic penguin has been moved. And she realizes that Paul has been out of his room. That scene is brutal! Definitely not for the squeamish or faint of heart. But it's actually one of the most talked about scenes in the film. And while Paul is being held captive in the middle of nowhere, Paul's agents and book editors and the local sheriff are out there looking for him because he has been missing for quite some time. But Annie refuses to let anyone know that he is even alive. So once he realizes that Annie is dangerously psychotic, he has to fight for his life.I like Misery because it isn't very bloody and doesn't involve some demonic monster. The monster in this film is a human being! And it displays how far some fans of famous people can go to see their idols or even get close to them. This film portrays how dangerous mentally unstable people can be and how their personalities can change in an instant. I have never read the actual book Misery by Stephen King but I think this film was a great adaptation. Kathy Bates played Annie Wilkes perfectly. She was utterly creepy and convincingly psychotic. She deserved that Oscar win and I'm glad she received it. James Caan was also perfectly cast as Paul Sheldon. You felt so much sympathy for him and wanted him to escape so bad! And you just knew that Annie was going to end up killing him before the film ended! And the direction by Rob Reiner was right on cue. Misery is a great suspense film and I'm glad I watched it. Thanks for reading my review!

Is it a masterpiece? No, not really. Is it a good watch? Yes.The premise alone is good enough to reel you in and it's executed well enough.Some moments just were a bit to campy and got a bit lazy with the shock value.Kind of took you out of the otherwise eerie, tense, twist and turns that kept you interested and entertained.

I have been a fan of the works of Stephen King for many years now but, sadly, they seldom translate well to the big screen. This is a rare exception and one I have seen several times before. It is best known for the stand-out performance from Kathy Bates, for which she won the Best Actress Oscar in 1991, and deservedly so (IMO). A very tense thriller, it grabs your attention and leads you down a dark path into the twisted mind of Annie Wilkes.Paul Sheldon is a writer; he has been writing a very successful series of romance novels featuring the heroine Misery. He now wants to write something new and has gone to Colorado to find some isolation so he can finish off his new book. On his way back he is involved in a car crash and is rescued by nurse, Annie Wilkes. It turns out that Annie is also his number one fan. After a few days, Paul's agent, Marcia Sindell contacts the local Sheriff, Buster, and he starts looking for him. Annie looks after Paul, who was quite badly injured in the crash, she is allowed to read his new book, but doesn't like it since Misery isn't in it. Fortunately the new Misery novel has just been published, but when she reads it, things take a nasty turn for Paul. He has killed off Misery and Annie really doesn't like the idea of that one bit.It's a pretty well made film with the action switching between Paul and Annie and Sheriff Buster's investigation. Great performances all round; I've already mentioned Kathy Bates as Annie Wilkes, she was tremendous. James Caan did a pretty good job as Paul Sheldon too, as did Richard Farnsworth as Buster and Frances Sternhagen as his wife Virginia. I must also give a special mention to Lauren Bacall as Marcia Sindell, she's not on screen for long, but she still has such great presence.This is one of those films I could happily watch at least once a year. I love Kathy Bates in this role, she slowly becomes more and more psychotic as the film progresses, it's great to watch! James Caan does a good job too, trying to win her trust so he can make an escape attempt. It's not perfect though, it does get a little baggy in the middle and, I thought, a little too long, but it's still perfectly watchable. Over all Recommended.My Score: 7.7/10

Both Stephen King and Rob Reiner have lost much of their charm for me in the past fifteen years, but in 1990 they were still in top enough form to create this masterpiece. Having struck gold in 1986 with his memorable adaptation of King's Stand By Me, Reiner made another attempt at the works of the successful suspense artist, and brought along for the task screenwriter William Goldman, with whom he worked before on the film version of Goldman's own novel The Princess Bride (Goldman would later adapt King twice more, somewhat less successfully, with Hearts In Atlantis and Dreamcatcher).King's writing is clearly at its best when he keeps the supernatural to a minimum; the stark reality is what made Stand By Me powerful, and it worked even better in Misery. Not only does King keep things frighteningly realistic in this story  it's also clearly semi-autobiographical  not, of course, that he was actually kidnapped by a crazed fan, but King's experiences with over zealous fans of his work clearly seeps into the story, and like in The Shining, King writes best when he writes about writers. James Caan does a more than adapt job of playing the bitter, King-ish author Paul Sheldon; master-adapter Goldman (whose credits also include Butch Cassidy & The Sundance Kid, All The President's Men and Marathon Man) did a fantastic job of translating the book into the big screen.As good a job as Reiner, Goldman and Caan did, this film clearly belongs to Hollywood newcomer Kathy Bates, who won a much deserved Oscar for the role of Annie Wilkes (over old-timers Meryl Streep and Anjelica Huston). Bates is brilliant, frightening and sympathetic in the role which remains the defining role of her acclaimed career, and she makes the character come alive like no other actress could have, proving that being blonde and skinny is not what makes a great actress. Annie Wilkes remains one of the most memorable villains in cinema history, and for good reasons. Caan is excellent in his part, and praise should also go to supporting actors Lauren Bacall and Richard Farnsworth (The Straight Story), but Bates steals the show from all of them.Thanks to Kathy Bates' masterful performance and Rob Reiner's wonderful direction, Misery is one of the most powerful and frightening thrillers in cinema history. If anyone needed proof that Reiner was capable of serious dramatic films and not just quotable cult comedies like This Is Spinal Tap and When Harry Met Sally, Misery proved that point, although it doesn't lack in its own quotable one-liners. It's a strong, realistic horror film that doesn't let go. A modern classic and highly recommended.

Not only is it one of the best movies based on Stephen King's work. Misery is practically flawless in every area. Definitely a better movie than The Shining in my opinion and a 'must-see' for every movie lover.

reviews.content: I don't watch much thrillers but I just wanted to say that the "thriller" part was perfectly done. From the moment he woke up in the house till the very end I was on the edge of my seat! I don't think there was a boring part at all. Everything that happened needed to happen. And one thing that I think was very good is that Annie, in my eyes, actually looked like a really nice woman. But seriously it was just so perfect that when she got angry she was REALLY creepy but when she was just smiling you could see a nice person even though you knew she wasn't.7.5 for me.

I rate this very high as it is basically a tense two-person drama and, as such is very well acted. Kathy Bates thoroughly deserved her Oscar for her impressively nuanced portrayal of a psychotic fan. James Caan has the more conventional role but provides Kathy adequate support. Both play a very effective game of cat and mouse together. The film is just the right length and there are no gratuitous subplots. Sadly, there is a little misjudgment towards the end (MINOR SPOILERS) with some excessive violence. Still worth watching as one of the better Stephen King adaptations.Overall 8/10

Misery (1990): Kathy Bates, James Caan, Lauren Bacall, Richard Farnsworth, Frances Sternhagen, Graham Jarvis, Jerry Potter, Thomas Brunelle, June Christopher, Julie Payne, Archie Hahn III, Gregory Snegoff, Wendy Bowers, J.T. Walsh... Director Rob Reiner, Screenplay William Goldman.A Writer's Fan From Hell"Misery" was writer William Goldman's film adaptation of the popular Stephen King novel and directed by Rob Reiner. Released in December of 1990, this is now a nearly forgotten tale of terror. In truth, "Misery" was never as successful and memorable as other Stephen King classics- "Carrie", "The Shining", "Children of the Corn". The title "Misery" is a play on words- Misery is the fictional heroine in the film and also hints at the misery Sheldon experiences. James Caan portrays the acclaimed novelist Paul Sheldon, whose "Misery" series - about a beautiful and passionate heroine of the bodice-ripper/Harlequin romance kind- have stirred the imagination of millions of readers. Among them is Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates), a lonely widow and retired hospital nurse living in a secluded home in wintry Colorado. When Paul, en route to his Colorado home to work on his next novel, is caught in a blizzard, his car tips over and he is injured. Annie saves him and takes him home, where she nurses him back to health. But it doesn't take long for Paul to realize that this woman is dangerous and psychopathic. She has a criminal past- she killed several babies in hospitals where she worked. She keeps a grotesque pig as a pet. Far more than just a fan of his novels, she is obsessed with Paul Sheldon himself, keeping his photographs and articles about him. When she reads his latest manuscript, she is upset that he kills off his Misery character and demands he write a new novel in which she returns to life. Paul spends a long time trapped in her home, forced to write the novel and forced to battle the crazed Annie herself. At the time of the film's release, this movie received an R rating for the language and the violence. The violence derives from the character of Annie, who is mentally unstable and causes Paul bodily harm. This film is, for me, very engaging as a work of somewhat realistically drawn horror. The fact this film does not feature the supernatural elements that Stephen King is best known for (ghosts, demons, possessions)is a refreshing change. The horror in this film is found in the troubled nature of Annie Wilkes. She is a religious lunatic (she thinks God send Paul to her), socially maladjusted (doesn't have friends, family, job, her husband is dead) and her idea of love is warped. Too many viewers at the time of the release, her breaking Paul's legs and other tortures were too graphic to be seen on the screen. How times have changed! William Goldman, best known for great novels and film adaptations, seems to be in a kind of subtle battle with King's original vision. King clearly wants us to fear this woman and loathe her. But Goldman hints at a woman we should feel sorry for- she is a vulnerable, pathetic woman who is lonely and unhappy, desperate for social contact and love. Because she is so isolated and friendless, she becomes crazy. This madness, believe it or not, seems to derive from her fantasy life, from the life of her inner mind. In the character of Sheldon's Misery, she finds comfort, hope and confidence, as if she is living vicariously through a fictional character. She does not care that this role model Misery is a made-up creation. It would interest some people to know that such crazed fans exist. Some readers become so familiar with an author and their work that they become obsessed. This is a great film and if you enjoy Stephen King, you are sure to love this. Kathy Bates and James Caan have genuine chemistry on screen. Kathy Bates delivers a sensational performance, revealing depth and versatility as an actress. She far outshines James Caan and it is this film that appears to have made her a star that Hollywood took a bigger interest in.

"Misery" is a phenomenal and stunning film. Rob Reiner has done an amazing job with this adaptation of Stephen King's novel. I loved James Caan's performance, this is probably one of his best performances along with "The Godfather". Kathy Bates is terrifying and her performance just gives me chills, her performance does give a lot to the film. What I most loved about the film was one specific scene: when the Sheriff of the town comes to investigate the disappearance of Paul Sheldon and appears at Annie Willkes house. Then gets killed. The similarity between this scene and the scene from Psycho where the private investigator gets killed at the Bates motel are amazing.

The movie tells too much and shows too little. The writer seems some kind of super human as he can just chill with broken legs without needing painkillers. Also they don't explain how he got out of the house and survived during winter.

And yet again, I was surprised in a very positive way by a Stephen King adaptation. I mean, if somehow you've written the stories to the Shawshank Redemption, The Green Mile, The Shining AND Stand By Me, you should consider him a genius, but somehow I don't. Maybe the many lousy TV-series like The Langoliers or It prevent that. But right here we have another example of a great story, and I must say, filmed superbly: Misery... How to make a movie this interesting with just 2 characters is amazing. Obviously, you need 2 good actors. No problem here: Caan and Bates are intense and brilliant. Comic relief comes from the ol' Sherrif's couple, now all you need is a good ending... which IS good (though not great, especially the leap in time at the end) with Caan killing off Bates with his typewriter... In short: great movie, even a bit of a classic if you'd ask me: 9/10.

A really slow build, but a brilliant thriller, and one of the best adaptations of King's work. A film which offers very little in terms of settings and an abundance of characters, but this only develops the protagonist and antagonist further, building a palpable relationship.Bates is deserving of her Oscar in the role of Annie, switching personalities over scenes and creating a truly disconcerting character. Caan, likewise, is superb and displays the feelings of hope and despair well. The violence is limited for the majority of the film, making the intermittent bursts all the more uncomfortable. A brilliant slow burn film.

Adaptations of Stephen King books are notorious for being subpar to the books, and Misery is one of them. The book is excellent, King's best next to The Shining, and has never ending terror. The movie version isn't as good.James Caan is a popular romance novelist, he writes the Misery books, about Misery Chastain, a rich 19th young woman. Millions of fans love her, including Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates, in an Oscar-winning role), who finds Paul Sheldon and brings him to her house after a car crash. At first, she's treating him nicely, but after she reads his first draft of a new book that she doesn't like, and she finds out that in his latest Misery book that Misery dies, Annie gets angry. When Annie gets angry, back away.She makes Paul burn the book she doesn't like, and then Annie keeps Paul captive to write a book: Misery's Return. Since Paul's bedridden with no use for his legs, he can't leave, and if he tries to, Annie will do things to him. One is with a mallet.If you haven't read the book, then most of this review will be worthless, since whenever I see a movie based on a book I have read, my review will be a comparison. Now that that's out of the way, let me go on. The book had nonstop thrills, while in this movie adaptation the thrills varied. Obviously, I knew what was going to happen, but what really made this a good film was the acting.Kathy Bates well deserved her best actress Oscar for this demanding role. Not many people COULD play Annie Wilkes, but Bates is the only person who I could imagine for this role. I was looking forward to seeing her do another great acting job, since I had just seen her in About Schmidt. Caan was also very good, but it's obvious why he didn't win an Oscar. It's really a two-person show, except Richard Farnsworth and Lauren Bacall come in as a police chief and Caan's agent, respectively.To be forewarned is to be forearmed, and there is one brutal scene with a sledgehammer, but that's all I'll say. Much of the violence from the book is taken out, which makes it easier to read. To sum it up, Misery's thrills come and go, but there's some great acting here.My rating: 7/10Rated R for a scene of violence.

My love for Stephen King's work started when I was no more than 8 with "Carrie." It grew from there in leaps and bounds and then I came upon this gem. There were people who looked at me funny when I was a kid because I liked to read more adult material like "Jurassic Park," John Grisham, Stephen King. However, when I got older, the looks stopped and people seeing me read his work wanted to know more about him, my mom and a few of my grade school teachers in particular. Without giving too much away, this one is more psychological than anything. Sometimes you don't need fantastical creatures to get a story across. With this priceless piece, it is best that you watch it with the lights on. Watching it in the dark may make you very paranoid, I will tell you that. In fact, when I first watched it as a kid, I had to actually watch my back before I went to bed because I never knew who was going to be walking behind me or waiting for me in my bedroom. Does it still have the same effect? No, but it is horror at its finest, no doubt about that. If you ever want to be scared out of your wits, watch this one. You may enjoy being scared. I know I did. To this day, I still watch it every October in light of Halloween. You don't even need it to be Halloween to watch this.

Paul Sheldon (James Caan) is a very successful author of romance and thriller books, one snowy night he crashes his car and a lonely woman named Annie (Kathy Bates) rescues him then provides shelter for him. She happens to be Sheldon's biggest fan and would do anything to be with him as her wish has come true, but she's a bit on the psychotic side as she wants him to write a new novel based on her wish-fulfillment ideas even if she won't allow Sheldon to leave.A twisted and stylish modern horror thriller that is very faithful to Stephen King's novel of the same name and is adapted by William Goldman and directed wonderfully by Rob Reiner. The film also co-stars Lauren Bacall, this is one of the best cinematic horror and thriller films ever! In fact, Kathy Bates won best actress for the part of Annie. This is a disturbing film with memorable moments like the horrifying foot torture scene you won't forget and of course atmosphere galore, the acting is phenomenal as well! this movie is a real winner.Also recommended: "Black Christmas (1974)", "Tourist Trap", "Funny Games", "Psycho (1960)", "The Shining", "Dolores Claiborne", "Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer", "Hostel 1 & 2", "Silence of the Lambs", "Audition", "Dressed To Kill", "Manhunter", "Hannibal", "Red Dragon", "Hannibal Rising", "Se7en", "Pin..", "May", "The Others", "Deep Red (1975)", "Tenebre", "Macabre (1980)", "When a Stranger Calls (1978)", "Psycho II", "Psycho III", "Psycho IV: The Beginning", "Vertigo", "North by Northwest", "Rope", "Basic Instinct", "Nightmare (a.k.a. Nightmare in a Damaged Brain)", "Silent Night Deadly Night", "Dead Ringers", "Wolf Creek", "Original Sin", "The Hitcher (1986)", "Secret Window" "Perfect Blue" and "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre (1974)".

I really enjoyed misery. And why shouldn't I? The cast did great, the plot was excellent the pace made sure you were standing still on your seat, in other words it has all it takes for a good film to be such.Caan and Bates have done an excellent job and as far as the storyline goes I'll just say it is another Stephen King Novel. In this instance I cannot remember any King novel made movie that I did not like.With an excellent script, scenery, and a highly charged atmosphere Misery surely makes an interesting watch.9/10

reviews.review_title: Good, but it could have been a lot better
reviews.content: I had mixed emotions about Misery, on the one hand, I thought that Misery was a good adaptation of the Stephen King novel, but on the other hand I thought that it was quite cheesy and came nowhere near to being as good as the book.The acting coming from James Caan is okay, and the acting coming from Kathy Bates is amazing.One of the things that I like about Misery is the fact that the whole movie is not based just on the book. That is something that I really like to see in movies based on books. Misery is a good film, but it lacks a lot of things, such as the ability to be scary. Misery tries to be scary but it is just not scary at all, I don't think that I came even remotely close once during the entire film. It also lacks the ability to express Paul Sheldon as a lively character. In the book, Paul Sheldon appears to be thoughtful and lively, but in the film he mostly appears to be boring and dull.In the end, I do not think that this is Rob Reiner's best film. He has definitely directed better films than Misery like A Few Good Men, but I do think that it is okay. In my opinion, this was a very big missed opportunity for Rob Reiner. I think that he had the chance to turn Stephen King's novel Misery into a very scary movie. But that is not what he did. Misery is a good film, but unfortunately it is nothing more than that.
LOVED Kathy Bates in this movie!!! What a FULL ON NUTTER!!! She did to writers what Glenn Close did to all cheating men in Fatal Attraction. LOL ;D.

You sort of know what is going to happen because of the amount of times this has been parodied.Kathy Bates is excellent as the terrifyingly unstable number one fan of James Caan's author.James Caan has a car accident in the snow and is saved by Kathy Bates who is an obsessive fan of his character Misery.She nurses him back to health/ abducts him.When she learns that he has killed off her favourite character, she put tremendous pressure on him to write ( I know the feeling, 600 words) and put right the killing off.He keeps trying to escape.I like the local police department that just consists of an old bickering couple.Good horror/ Thriller.

Misery, is one of the best Stephen King movies I've ever watched. It kept me in suspense the whole time. Kathy Bates was great.This is a movie I would watch more than once. I recommend this movie to anyone who likes Stephen King movies, and likes a good suspense movie.
