reviews.content: Rob Reiner, Kathy Bates, James Caan, and Stephen King.  This is a cinematic match made in heaven.James Caan doesn't get enough credit for his Portrayal of Paul Sheldon.  He was brilliant in my estimation.  His range of facial expressions taking the place of the internal dialogue that existed for his character in the book. He was definitely sympathetic enough to make us really care about what happened to him, which is what any good horror movie needs.Kathy Bates' performance was simply a tour de force.  She was just perfectly cast.  And she was masterful in her execution as the ultimate villain; a monster that seriously COULD be living right next door.  She demonstrates a common theme for Stephen King: That real monsters don't have tails and fangs and horns, but are instead regular people that we allow to get close to use who either are or become insane.Rob Reiner just proves that he is one of the best directors in the business, and that he can cross genres with aplomb.  I think it is interesting that two of his best are Stephen King adaptations, this movie (Misery) and Stand By Me.If you want to really be chilled to the bone, see this movie.9/10

It doesn't get any better than that. Anyone who has ever tried to write knows that often the only thing that saves you is escapism, the flight into the distance, the establishment of new places, new people and new problems, in the hope that this will breathe life into your story. This is also what the writer Paul Sheldon hopes in his own way, who achieved fame with his Misery series of books, and who sets off - though he always does - from New York to the solitude of the Rockies. There, quartered high up in a hotel, he puts the finishing touches to his dime novels. And when he indulges in the ritual Lucky Strike and a bottle of Don Perignon after his work is done and then heads back home, he is surprised by a blizzard, loses control of his car and ends up in a ditch. And if Annie Wilkes hadn't come along, his biggest fan, who sees this encounter as a divine coincidence, Sheldon would probably have been allowed to freeze to death peacefully in his wreck instead of being subjected to a horror trip of the highest order.Fans have it in them to be fanatical, and Annie is no exception. The trained nurse, who lives lonely in a cottage, at first only cares for Sheldon's wounds, but eventually also takes care of the writerly matters, because she does not like the twist in the case of the novel character Misery at all. Shelton's last novel, which is currently available in bookstores, was supposed to be the conclusion of the series - with the demise of the eponymous heroine. No way!....If it's risky for a writer to create a two-person chamber drama and expect people to want to read it, it borders on megalomania for a filmmaker to expect a movie audience to see it adapted for the screen. Instead of the house on the moor, we have a snow-white frame here as a black backdrop. Bright and peaceful and nothing intrusive or subcutaneously threatening that pushed one toward horror. Except for the vivid psyche of two people, the fear of the writer versus the fanaticism of his fan, incessantly pouring oil on the fire and keeping the cogs turning.Lead flies too, but the film also delivers a sequence that is almost unparalleled in brutality, which Annie carries out with calculated ruthlessness and all peace of mind. Truly demonic. If you haven't seen this film yet, you should make a note of the following sentence: "There is a justice higher than that of man, I will be judged by Him!Rob Reiner converts Steven King's original congenially; in atmospheric density and tension, within the framework of its minimalism, unique.

This film demonstrates what little is needed to create gut-wrenching suspense - just with two characters stuck in a house, this story will totally absorb you, terrify you, and have you dripping with perspiration in a way that the modern explosive action movie could only hope to achieve.As with all the best Rob Reiner films, you get a very polished product - careful direction, including cinematography and music, and flawless acting. Kathy Bates is up there with Hopkins' Lecter and Joe Pesci's evil gangster characters in her portrayal of Annie Wilkes - a cross between the sweetest nurse you could ever imagine, and Satan.Reiner and screenwriter Goldman crank up the suspense with skill, pushing it as far as possible while keeping things plausible, so that by the time you reach the 'hobbling' scene you are going to undergo one of the most harrowing experiences of your life. This is an awesome, powerful piece of entertainment and a true modern classic.

The first time I watched this movie, I wasn't all that impressed. I mean, I thought it was good, but I didn't truly appreciate the film until subsequent viewings.James Caan plays the part of novelist Paul Sheldon, whose books include a series of novels with the character named "Misery". Paul is driving in his car one very snowing evening in Colorado, when his car slides out of control and flips off the side of the road. We see him being rescued by a person who turns out to be Annie Wilkes, played by Kathy Bates. She brings him back to health at her house in the wilderness, always proclaiming to be Paul's "#1 Fan". We can tell something's definitely wrong with Annie right with the first few encounters with Paul, as she's definitely someone who's possessing a wee bit too much fanaticism with the novelist. Eventually, she forces Paul to write a new novel in the Misery series, keeping him under lock and key, not allowing him to leave, even after his injuries have sufficiently healed. In fact, in a possessive rage, she injures him even further, in one of the most grotesque on-screen injuries I've ever witnessed.I'll stop right there and not reveal anything further about the plot. It needs to be seen to really be appreciated. But what really needs to be appreciated is the acting ability of Kathy Bates. Watching scenes of her persona go from admiration of Paul, to quickly turning into rage through the help of psychosis, is something to behold. She really makes it believable. I said her moods turn quickly, but only in the sense of being in the same scene. Just watching her facial reactions turn slowly during these times, are not only truly believable and scary, but they are also the mark of a great actor. Under the direction of Rob Reiner, she pulls these scenes off flawlessly, and it's a beauty to see.James Caan is very good in his own right, but Kathy Bates steals this show. It's kind of a throwback to the great actors from the past, who can make you feel sympathy to vindictiveness in one scene.A Must See!!!

Let me start with saying this- you can neevr go wrong with Stephen King. All of his books are great. I know this when I've only read two of them- "Misery" and "Carrie". My mother has read just about all of them, and she loves them all. This is almost identical to the book, therefore, it is a great film. We start with a writer, Paul Sheldon. He is on his way home when he is in a massive car wreck. An obsessed fan, Annie Wilkes (Bates) abducts him from the totaled car and begins to nurse him back to health. After discovering that she is a serial killer, he gets in a wheelchair and picks the lock, escaping while she is gone. He has killed off her favorite character, Misey, in his latest book, so she makes him burn a book that he has finished and has yet to be published. She has him write a new sequel, where Misery is resurrected. He knocks down a statue, and puts it back up. When she arrives and finds out that he is trying to escape, she ties him down and takes an axe to his ankles, shattering the bones. This is the most famous scene in the film. Anyway, he begins to plan her demise and his escape, through the new book that he is writing. I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a great watch. Look out for some of her shocking but hilarious lines:Paul: Profanity offends you? Annie: It has no nobility. Paul: They're slum kids. I was a slum kid, they all talk like that. Annie: THEY DO NOT!!! WHAT DO YOU THINK I SAY WHEN I GO TO THE STORE? HEY WALLY, GET ME SOME OF THAT EFFING PIG FEED AND SOME OF THAT BITCHLY COW CORN! AND WHEN I GO TO THE BANK? YEAH, SUE- HERE'S ONE BIG BASTARD OF A CHECK, GIVE ME SOME OF YOUR CHRISTING MONEY... LOOK WHAT YOU MADE ME DO!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!Hilarious.

reviews.review_title: looks even better ten years later
reviews.content: just watched this  on showtime...first time I've seen it sincetheatrical release.A text book of how to make a movie.Direction,photography, acting and story all blend perfectly to make superbthriller.plus, I forgot how pretty the scenery is and what a contrastthe views of the house from the outside are against the terrorgoing on inside . One thing I didn't forget was how  marvelousJames Caan is. Bates well deserved her oscar, but remember thatshe played virutally  all of her scenes with only Caan, and hisreactions, just those small facial expression, way he delivered hislines, added to the  audience awareness of her increasingmadness.  Reiner terric here...the Hitchcock touches of macabrehumor along  with the terrific suspense.  As years go by and moresuspense movies are made this one is taking its place as aclassic.

reviews.review_title: Will send shivers up your spine!
reviews.content: Even although the book is obviously better (as is frequently the case), the screen adaptation does not disappoint.Basically, a best selling novelist, Paul Sheldon (James Caan) crashes during a blizzard and is rescued by his "number one fan", Annie Wilkes(Kathy Bates) Wilkes nurses her hero back to health but when she learns that he has killed off her favourite character in his new book, she turns psychotic and demands that he writes another book, bringing the character back to life. Throughtout the movie, Annie Wilkes becomes increasingly terrifying. And be warned: one scene involving a sledgehammer will leave the hairs on the back of your neck standing on end!!!James Caan does an excellent job as the terrified writer but it is Kathy Bates' outstanding performance as the crazed nurse which makes Misery so enjoyable and thrilling. She totally deserved her Oscar.Recommened: 8/10

reviews.review_title: King ditches the supernatural and gives us real life horror.
reviews.content:
After a long history about dealing with the supernatural horror with haunted hotels, resurrected murderous kids, telekinetic prom queens, possesed cars and killer clowns from other dimensions, we get from the master of Horror a heavily isolated movie that's scarier than all things mentioned above.When we think of survival horror we often think in zombie movies or post apocaliptic films in which the character have to survive a force of great evil. This one whoever fits in the genre in the most unusual of ways, isolating the protagonist in a cabin inside the a situation that is almost ironically funny, and making the evil force a psychotic nurse in whose our main lead's life depends.Is a thrill ride from start to finish that only gets heartbumping every minute.
We cannot ignore Kathy Bates's amazing performance as the emotionally unstable Annie Wilkes. From the moment she is on screen we learn that something is not right with her, is then when the film starts pumping when we know she can jump from loving careful mother to murderous psychopath displaying a master class in acting.Thrilling and unsettlingly realistic.

reviews.review_title: Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde is right. Spoilers.
reviews.content: When doctor Paul Sheldon takes a ride home, he didn't imagine in his wildest dreams that he would be taken captive by a woman whose whole persona changed at the drop of a hat. All seems well at first, although the audience does wonder whether Paul is as injured as he seemed to be at the crash site. His legs seemed to look worse than they should have been.Soon she begins to inquire about his recent book and even goes out to purchase a copy. She shows her true colours and flies into a rage upon discovering that Misery Chastain is dead. She goes as far as to nearly hit him in the head with a chair. Annie then claims to have not told anyone about his whereabouts. Without her, he will not survive. This film is an example of a good script, great talents and directing coming together. It is a film you will be able to re-watch throughout your life. James Caan is very believable in his role as a man held captive by a raving lunatic who has killed babies in the past. Kathy Bates has not been given enough films. Her portrayal of Annie Wilkes will leave you wondering whether she is like that in reality!A true interpretation of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde. She is a truly underrated actress who has not been appreciated enough. A true thrilling classic!
I did not find the acting to be particularly good. paul could have been played by anyone, and annie was pretty stilted. a movie where nothing much goes on

reviews.review_title: The Best Steven King Adaption Ever!
reviews.content: Wow. When i saw the title and cover of this movie i didn't really want to see it. But when i saw how well Kathy Bates portrayed Annie Wilkes it became an amazing ride. Misery is my all time favorite movie. I recommend this to ANYONE. Both Bates and Caan were amazing. I am so surprised its not in the top 250. If you go to blockbusters one day and don't really know what get, i think this will be the smartest choice you will ever make. When Bates was given the Oscar i was relived happy and most of all extremely excited to see what she would say. I cant believe this movie didn't win more Oscars!!! Again, i recommend this to anyone and everyone.

oh my god!! this movie goes in my top 10. the film is about james caan, a writer, being captured by a crazed fan played by kathy bates. the film is very well directed, which i recently found out it was directed by Rob Reiner, which i think in anyone elses hands this movie could be an absolute mess, but he pulls it off.The main reason this movie is so terrific, is Kathy Bates, she plays Annie Wilkes, probably one of the most complex characters in film. She won a well-deserved Oscar for this role and she should have. Her performance is great on so many levels, and after seeing her in this mad me appreciate the film twice as much. Great directing, great performances, great film!! don't' even bother renting it, just go out and buy the DVD

This is another great Stephen King novel adaption. As usual, it is set in a desolate, snowy area where there is no nearby life. Kathy Bates gives an outstanding performance as Annie Wilkes, a psychotic, yet caring woman who takes in author James Caan after a car accident. He is grateful, but soon learns that his "number 1 fan" has a few screws loose. A sheriff in the nearby town tries to find the lost writer and even brings his comical wife in on it. Great performances by the entire cast and a brilliant thriller with a great script/ story. Anyone who is a fan of Stephen King books/ film adaptations should see this great piece of work. Add it to your list of things to see!

I watched Misery in dark, rainy night. And I couldn't sleep after watching it. The image of Annie Wilkes just stuck in my head all the time! She's so scary ( I wish I would never have such a "number-one" fan like her). Kathy Bates definitely deserved her Oscar for bringing us one of the most scary movie villains of the century. Caan and Fansworth did a great job in their roles, too. And we cannot forget Rob Reiner, the talented director who made this movie more than a thriller. Every scene of the film is very exciting and thrill. I like the ending, although there's some blood, which I don't really like to see in a thriller. On the whole, this is a very good film. I recommend this to everyone who loves watching something scary at night. And remember to close your eyes...

As a big Stephen King fan I would just have to say that the movie based upon King's novel was extremely well acted.  The could have found better actors to play the 2 starring roles.  Kathy Bates was the perfect match for Annie Wilkes, the deranged fan of Paul Sheldon (played by James Caan).  Kathy Bates more then deserved the award she received for her portrayal of Annie Wilkes and Caan's performance as Sheldon was nothing short of wonderful. I'm sorry if I sound like a critic but I absoultely loved the movie.  You know how people often say the books are always better than the movie? Well, this movie to me is as good as the book.

reviews.review_title: "He didn't get out of the COCKADOODIE CAR!"
reviews.content: Paul Sheldon is a very successful author for creating the 19th century novels called 'Misery', after completing his final 'Misery' book he heads back home to New York until his car steers off road and crashes in the mountains, due to the weather conditions. As luck would have it, someone is there to the rescue Paul from the wreckage... and his book!.Paul wakes up from being unconscious and finds himself resting in a bed in Annie Wilkes's home. "I'm your number one fan!"Annie Wilkes, an obsessed Paul Sheldon fanatic who loves his novels, has the great pleasure of having him in her home.Annie has the chance of reading Paul's brand new draft of 'Misery', until she's the critic, by wanting what she wants Paul realises throughout the weeks Annie isn't just an ex-nurse but that he's being taken care of by a violent-tempered-psycho. Missing for weeks, presumed dead, Paul thinks of all the possible ways to escape. Whereas he used to write for a living he's now writing to stay alive.Brilliantly portrayed by James Caan and Kathy Bates, this makes Stephen King's best!!!

reviews.review_title: A brilliant Thriller-Brilliantly Cast-Brilliantly Acted-Brilliantly Directed-based on a Steven King masterpiece...need i say more!?
reviews.content: Once again, a brilliant Novel from the legend that is Mr Steven King. I feel this film version really does do justice to Mr Kings work. The director has brought the novel to life, and has created an extremely thrilling and entertaining film. He also did extremely well with regards to casting Kathy Bates as the freakish and obsessed 'Annie Wilkes' You couldn't find anyone else who could of done the job (and fitted the role) even half as good as Kathy did! Brilliant. In fact, i think all the actors fro the other characters were perfectly cast for this classic film. There's not much more i can say-that other haven't already put...Except i strongly recommend you watch this film if your into thrillers. One or two disturbing scenes (one in particular), so be warned! The film is directed brilliantly with a great screenplay based on yet another Steven King masterpiece. There is really good character development throughout the film-and you actually feel for main character 'Paul Sheldon' as he is held, helpless by his 'number 1' obsessed fan 'Annie Wilkes' If you haven't seen this yet...get a copy. You will enjoy it-if you like Steven King/ a good thriller/ Brilliant acting and good work by the director. Fantastic for those rainy/Snowy!nights in! A must for any collection!8/10

reviews.review_title: Kathy Bates is scarier than Norman Bates
reviews.content: My dad made me watch this. I didn't want to but now i'm glad i did. It doesnt have the normal horror-type scary scenes, but it is very well written, and you couldnt have made Kathy Bates (Anne Wilkes) more crazy. And one more thing, James Caan's acting is awesome. (Espesially when he is in pain)

this is by far rob reiners best film of all time. Kathy bates gave an exillerating performance, and did deserve the acamedy award for best actress. I was very suprised when it was not nominated for the best picture award. The film itself is disturbing, especially the hobbling scene, where James Cann get feet sledge hammered into the opposite direction. I object to the 18 age rating in England as the film itself is disturbing but not that violent.A brilliant movie.9/10 this is the best!!!!!!!

This is the best adaptation of a Stephen King novel that I've seen.  I saw the movie before I read the book, and the book wasn't confusing, which it usually seems to be with King if you see the movie first.    This movie holds true to the book very well.  There are some slight differences, and I think the book goes much deeper into Annie's psychosis, which I enjoyed more, but these things don't detract from the general quality of the movie. I liked this movie a lot.

reviews.review_title: Creating such intense tension with one house, two persons is extraordinary!
reviews.content: This thriller is really one that never gives you a calm moment untill it´s over, and even not then, when you think about it! The two actors are great, Kathy Bates is really fitting into this role, she is tottaly amazing! In this one, everything is well thought out, there are no misstakes like in the film Dead Calm for example. This is very exiting, a thriller at the top, Hitchcock would not have been ashamed of it!

reviews.review_title: A terribly pathetic movie considering the great cast
reviews.content: Yes, this movie did keep my interest.  No, this movie was not a feel good movie or even a good movie, considering the possibilities with such an excellent cast.
I created my IMDb account just to rate this masterpiece, do your self a favor and watch it.

The movie "Misery," based on the book by Stephen King, is a movie that keeps you on the edge of your seat the whole time! It starts off with a famous writer getting into a car accident. He ends up at the home of his "number one fan." The fan, Annie Wilks, played by Kathy Bates, is such a troubled woman, and the way she acts towards Paul makes us realize our obsessions, and what we would do to get them. Though crazy and psychotic, Annie reminds us of what we truly are, obsessive creatures.Leaving Paul in the bedroom also adds suspense. Throughout the whole time he is there, you start to wonder what is really outside of those walls. Annie Wilks' house is charming and sophisticated, which is ironic in a way, and that is what makes her so lovable.Even though her beliefs are totally out of whack, they make you hate her, but love her at the same time.Annie's unusual beliefs and Paul's struggle to survive make this movie a great thriller for those who can't stand ghosts and monsters. I give it a 9 out of 10!

By its new story it gives the audience a chance to feel that there are still several untold stories that can be illustrated in an artistic way.Brilliant film script of the movie which is based on a novel is just a piece of valuable jewellery.I loved every moment of the movie...the point which makes the film unique is its great directing and awesome performing of the actors and actresses .The movie gave me different feelings of love,sadness,pain,excitement and revenge.A movie wouldn't be able to do such a thing with its viewers unless it is perfect in all aspects.I do recommend watching this movie to whomever wants a brilliant drama thriller with a bit of mysterious atmosphere till the middle of it.

reviews.review_title: The best movie by Stephen King ever!!!
reviews.content: This is one of the best movies I've ever seen. It has everything; Drama, horror, suspense. If this were real life and I was Paul Sheldon, I'd be so freaked out, it's not like he wasn't. It's just I'd be a little more freaked out, because I'm younger. The movie scared me. When Annie Wilks hit Paul with the sludge hammer, I turned around and limped out into the kitchen that's how bad it hurt.When Paul finds the pin and tells her to go get paper for him, I thought he was really going to get out! I was cheering for him to get out and... the phone has nothing in it! It's nothing... there are no wires in it or anything, and then in the same scene when he gets to the kitchen and finds out it's locked... that part was scary. The expression on his face when he heard the car coming up the driveway... I was screaming at the TV "Get back there, Hurry!" The final scene when Paul burns his book, I was scared and happy for him. But when they were fighting, I think that was the best scene in the entire movie. I Really loved that movie and I'd give it a 1,000,000 out of 10 but that's not a rating so I went with 10/10.

God Of Modern Horror,Stephen King wrote another intriguing,genuine and brilliant thing. And when you add on top of it fantastic directing, marvelous photography, cute and gorgeus James Caan and........ Breathtaking,wild and beautiful Kathy Bates you've got one of the masterpieces of modern horror. As my favourite film of all the time is another Stephen King's novel " The Shining",next to it is "Misery". Stephen King always cheated on human with some partial combinations of evil,suspense,deaths and warmth in the middle of. In almost every King's work we have some very warm characters of which you have more creeps than with the villains. This divine piece of dramatic,claustrophobic riding thriller will always stay in anals of cinematography as perfect work in both ways: Telling the story and presenting the true horror that actually exists in this poor,climacteric planet

This film is one of the best ever! It is intelligent and scary and just plain GOOD!!! I think the only tiny letdown is at the end, because the film seems to stop taking itself seriously which is usually a good thing, but it didnt really work well in this case. That didn't wreck a great movie, though, and Kathy Bates totally deserved the Oscar she won. The way she played Annie definately rates up there with Tony Perkins and Norman Bates. Just superb performances by everyone, especially Kathy Bates and James Caan. Watch it and Love it!

reviews.review_title: The production makes it great; The stars make it extraordinary!
reviews.content: Misery is a truly deep and disturbing film. I've read the book and, whilst being a true wonder, is an almost different experience from this film. Kathy Bates' Annie will undoubtedly haunt your nights in bed. The cinematography is eye-popping and Bill Goldman's script is a flawless adaptation of King's greatness. Rob Reiner turns in a fine directing job. But it's the story that hooks you. A popular romance novel crashes and is rescued by his #1 fan. Except she turms out to be really crazy. And that's not even the 1/2 of it. But all in all you are amazed by the two performances. This one must been seen to loved."Annie, whatever it is you're thinking about doing...please don't do it."

Writer Paul Sheldon finishes the last book in his 'Misery' series. Soon after, he loses control of his car during a snowstorm and sustains crippling injuries. He is found and looked after by nurse Annie Wilkes, his "number one" fan.Terrific film. 10/10

I'm not a big fan of Stephen King (he leaves almost nothing unsaid as if he wants to prove he's thought of everything), but I have seen several of his movies and this is one of the better ones. The plot is simple: A quiet writer crashes his car during a blizzard and is rescued by his "number one fan"-who's a little morbid. His legs are broken, he's stuck in bed and she gets very upset when she finds out her favorite character of his, "Misery", has been killed off. You can figure out what happens next, but the movie remains compelling thanks to good performances from Kathy Bates (who hits a nerve head on) and James Caan and Rob Reiner's professional direction. Because so much of the movie involves Caan playing straight man to Bates, the movie may seem too low key for some horror tastes, despite one key violent scene that's all the more effective because of the utter lack of violence before it. Caan's character and some others are dull compared to Bates; I'm told the novel has more fleshed out characters and a nastier finish. Still, I prefer a measured achievement like this than the messes that usually result from Stephen King adaptations.

reviews.review_title: A excellent adaptation of an excellent book. A modern classic.
reviews.content: *there may be possible spoilers but I doubt they will ruin the film or give away the ending)I picked up the Misery DVD in my local cd/video/dvd store and read the synopsis at the back. Then I remembered where I had heard it before. On the Steven King novel. I rushed out and bought the book, the film sounded interesting but I wanted to read the book first. It was wonderful a brilliant, tense thriller that had hints of humour. It was definatly the best Steven King book I have read (The others are Apt Pupil and Shawshank Redemption).I know this is'nt a book review, so i'll get back on track. I got the dvd for Christmas and was delighted at how good it was. Kathy Bates and James Caan are perfect in their roles and often funny aswell. Kathy Bates truly deserved her Oscar. She does'nt just play Annie Wilkes, her performance is so realistic, she is Annie Wilkes. She can turn from calm to total psycho, yet appears pretty normal. James Caan often goes unrecognised for this role, yet he portrays Paul brilliantly.The film has the same plot as the novel, but it is not really faithful to it's original source. Many differences occur, and the film is better for it. It is interesting to see a different view on the story, rather than just seeing the book. Differences are the hobbling scene, the policeman scene and the added bonus of the hilarious candlelit dinner.Annie and Paul's characters are different in on film than the book. For instance, Annie wasn't following Paul on the night of the crash. Also Annie does'nt predict things about Paul, e.g. cigarette after finishing a book, he has to ask her.On a whole the film is an excellent adaptation. It offers a new insight to the story. I don't think that I managed to get the most out of the film because I read the book first. The film would have been more enjoyable if I did'nt know what was going to happen. Overall, its a cock-a-doodie marvel.9/10

This movie absolutely scared the daylights out of me. No horror movie has ever scared me nearly as much as Misery did.I guess because the fact there are insane fans out there. I mean just look at John Lennon or Selena. They were both killed by their fans. Watching this frightens you and makes any average joe thankful he does not have a "fanbase."What makes this movie scary is the fact it could actually happen.It doesn't have crap like a psycho murder who can't die, or some ghost/monster like creature.Kathy Bates does a great job with her role. I recommend this movie to anyone who wants a real scare.

Annie Wilkes is one of the best villians in the history of horror. I think the book is much better than the movie, but I have nothing to say about Kathy Bates in this movie. Outstanding. An Oscar couldn't be more well-deserved than this one.

An excellent film of kidnapture with very little characters.From Steven King and Rob Reiner (Stand By Me,This Is Spinal Tap)this films makes you wonder,are there people like this?The story revolves around a character named Annie Wilkes,a fan of a writer named Paul Sheldon.Paul gets hurt in a car crash and is rescued by Annie.The problem is Annie is obsessed,and psycho!When she is disappointed from Paul's latest book after he kills off her favorite character.So,she makes him write a new book for her.The film is a bit dated but anyone should be pleased by watching this film.Believe me,Annie is one psycho b*tch.

From the beginning to the end, the movie showcases a well crafted and tight script. The lead woman character...what a brilliant performance!! Another movie "Run" (2020) similar to this movie is also a great watch!!

reviews.review_title: Good but changes from the book stop it being perfect!
reviews.content:
This is a SPOILER ALERT (for the book anyway)Misery was the first book that I have ever read that actually frightened me, I felt that Annie Wilkes would be lurking behind my door, waiting to put me through torture.The film Annie however didn't scare me in the slightest, whilst Kathy Bates IS Annie Wilkes the script makes her a far less threatening character, couple that with the pathetic characterization of Paul Sheldon and you get a film that doesn't even come close to the terror of the book.
In the film Annie is never quite nasty and insane enough, a good example of this is when she first gets angry. In the film she spills some soup on the bed and shouts, comes back to earth and apologizes. In the book she throws the soup across the room, comes back to earth, sweetly cleans it up with soap and water then makes Paul drink the dirty water before she will give him his pain killers. This highlights another problem with the film and that is James Caan, he is just too strong as a character and I never felt that he was in the amount of pain he should have been. In the book the pain was debilitating, the slightest movement would cause excruciating pain, there is no way he could have put both his legs onto one side of his wheelchair and lowered himself onto the floor, as he does in the film, without causing himself to blackout from the pain. The Paul Sheldon in the film was a nasty character who I never had any sympathy for, he was far too strong willed and unlikeable, in the book he is flawed but still very likeable as he gains a new sense of life from his expieriances.With a humanised Annie and an unlikeable Paul the terror was never going to be all it could have been and was in the book. The one scene from the book that turned Annie from having freaky tendencies to all out Psycho was the hobbling scene, in it Annie uses an axe to slice Paul's foot off,using a blow torch to cauterize the wound. This scene was originally written for the script but was replaced with the sledgehammer sequence by Reiner and Scheinman, the scriptwriter William Goldman said 'They were right{to change it} because if she'd cut his feet off, you never would've forgiven her' but that is the point, from that moment on there is no sympathy for the character, you shouldn't forgive her, it's what makes her such a horrifing and frightening character.I have read that the lawnmower sequence was considered too comical to be filmed, I don't think it would have been if done the way it was written, the effect would have been comic to start off with but with a slight change of expression on Annie's face and her shredding the arm of the cop first, showing his reaction and leaving time for audiences to feel sympathy for him before totally ripping apart his upper torso, the scene could have worked. Even if they couldn't achieve this they could have captured Paul's guilt at causing the cop to die. In the film he causes the Sheriff to bite the bullet but his reaction seems too selfish, no time is given for him to feel bad for being the reason the Sherrif died.I agree with a comment someone else made that it would have been nice to see the final irony of the last 'Misery Chastaine' book being his best. But I would put that down to the awful characterization of the Sheldon character anyway.The film is a good film, well directed and beautifully photographed, and adds the plotline of the elderly Sheriff slowly finding out where Paul is which is a very good innovation. Had I just seen the film I would have thought it was excellent, frightening in parts and well crafted. But having read the book first and seen what this film could have been I was disappointed.PS. The Libreace line was awful, I hated it. I suggest whoever is responsible for it should be made to listen to nothing but Liberace for the rest of their life.

I have watched Misery many times over the past few years and still look away at the sledgehammer/foot scene. Nobody else could have played the role as well as Kathy Bates did and there is something likable about her even after everything. There was something that made you go 'awww' when she died and feel a little bit sympathetic for her. Well....I did anyway! I did think that there were some very atmospheric bits left out of the film that were in the book (even thought it isn't right to compare) such as the soapy, soupy water drinking scene. However the film is very well done and some of the shots where she is in the room with Paul when he is peeing and also the kiss-blowing were made quite sickening after all she did to him. I have also just helped backstage with the stage show of Misery which is more like the book than the film as there are only the main two characters throughout the whole play, but it does always manage to hold the audience and the best speeches such as the 'Rocketman' one and the part where she tells him she doesn't like swearing were included which brought a bit of humour to it. One of Stephen Kings best stories and film adaptations made even better by Kathy Bates.

Kathy Bates is a wonderful actress in this wonderfully simple but scary movie. One successful writer, one crazed fan, bring them together and you get Misery - how far will Annie go to stay with Paul Sheldon?The movie is pretty much as I imagined it from the novel and, OK, the 'hobbling' is different as many people point out, but it still makes you go 'AGGGGGGHooooooww!!!!'Great movie, watch it!

This movie is a good adaptation of the book, although a lot of the key psychological elements present in the book are lacking in the film. I highly recommend that anyone who has not seen the movie and wishes to reads the book first. Adversely, I recommend that those of you who have not read the book, but have seen the movie, read the book. There are pieces of the story missing in the film. In order to get the complete story, you should read the book and view the movie. Kathy Bates and James Caan are exceptional in the film. Good thriller for anyone wanting to see a scary movie. Highly recommended for anyone who wants to bone up on their scary movies.

The movie is excellent and Kathy Bates doing her best work. The part with the 2X4 and the sledge hammer still sends shivers down my spine. The movie was made true too King's book and was well put together.James Caan did a great job in the role of paul Sheldon an Author trapped in a house with a crazed fan..Must see for any king fan

This is one of the best suspense thrillers released after Hitchcock's death. James Caan gives a genuine performance as the captured author, Paul Sheldon, and because of this - we can really place ourselves in his shoes during certain difficult situations. But the real gem of the whole movie goes to Kathy Bates, who plays the psycho devout ex-nurse Annie Wilkes perfectly. Her performance can makes us laugh one minute, then make us feel very uneasy and scared the next. Annie Wilkes is, my opinion, one of the greatest villains of all time and Kathy Bates made her what she is. I think that this is probably the most simple psychological thrillers ever made - yet it still manages to affect audiences even to this day. 10/10 HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

reviews.review_title: I hate Annie Wilkes, in a good way
reviews.content: This movie is a good movie, the only reason for this is Kathy Bates. she does a near flawless job of Annie Wilkes Who in the book, i feel, was a very two dimensional character, along with all the characters.this in turn is one of the downfalls of the movie. the fact that the storyline is very basic and most of the characters are two dimensional. Especaily Paul Sheldon. There is no real character development baring Annie.But Annie is what makes this movie. Kathy Bates does a haunting job of Annie, and i can really tell why she won an award for it. The hobbling scene is so creepy i can barley watch it.Even the house is haunting, like when Paul picks up the phone and it is just a shell. there are some downfalls though in addition to the ones i mentioned earlier. James Carn does an okay job of Paul Sheldon but it is just okay. there is little if any music which can be good or bad. I also don't like the ending but i will not ruin that.all in all i think that Misery is a fine movie but has a few flaws when it comes to character and plot development. 7/10

Paul Sheldon, who is famous for his novels he writes, is traveling to New York with his new book in a big snow storm. He crashes his car and is left to die. But, his number one fan, Annie Wilkes, who is known for killing the objects of people for many decades, rescues him from the car wreck. Annie takes him to her house and begins pumping medicine through his body. As the movie goes on, her temper and violence on Paul Sheldon goes up. She gets mad about the swearing in his book, she gets mad and shakes his bed and hits him with a board when she finds out that he killed Misery Chastain in his book. She gets mad when Paul tells her she got the wrong paper. She has also made him burn his new book and start another book the way Annie wants it. But then something happens to Annie. She is depressed and suicidal. She pulls out a gun with no bullets in it and then tells him she might put bullets in it, then leaves. Paul is left all by himself. He decides to go out of his room to get a knife, when he does he finds her scrapbook called Memory Lane which contains her over the decades where she has killed people and found behind bars. Paul is astonished and returns back to his room into his bed. The rain and thunder is able to be heard outside. After a couple of hours Annie returns then hobbles him. At the end Paul finally kills Annie and then escapes

i really liked this film although it was a bit one-dimensional. both Kathy Bates and James Caan were good at acting the story but i don't think that the story itself flowed with any realism, it wasn't a film you could get lost in. the characters seemed to lack depth and their motivations are a bit vague. in the book the fact of Annie's charges of murder is never even touched upon in the film. this sort of explanation would have cleared u a lot of questions that i had after watching the film, because frankly i thought that Annie's sudden change from nice-as-pie nurse to total psychopath was a bit random!!!! however, this was one of the better adaptations from the great Mr King's novels, but i have resigned myself to the fact that if you want a good scare the best thing to do is read the book rather than watch the film.
I've just finished watching Leave Her To Heaven (1945). Is this a remake? It is very similar.

reviews.review_title: Okay, but too unsure of itself
reviews.content: Misery was first released in 1990 and stars James Caan as a novelist named Paul Sheldon who has just finished the book that will kill off his character named Misery Chastain, after getting into a car accident he is rescued by a former nurse named Annie Wilkes played very well by Kathy Bates, but there is more to her than meets the eye.So what did I think of Misery, well to be honest I thought the film was very bizarre and a little sick in places, I couldn't help but think that the movie degenerated into a sick and twisted love story between the characters played by Caan and Bates and there is also no clear indication in the film as to exactly why Wilkes keeps Sheldon in her home and because of this I couldn't help but feel that the movie went along the direction it did.But I didn't think that badly of it, I really enjoyed the performances by Caan and Bates as well as the supporting performances by screen legend Lauren Bacall as Sheldon's editor and Richard Farnsworth as the town sheriff, I also enjoyed the photography by Barry Sonnenfeld who would later become a director, these I helped elevate the film.Out of 5, I will give this a 3, it has some good performances but the story is too unsure of itself.

I promise you, after watching this movie, Annie Wilkes will feature in your nightmares.It is horror at its best - not through watching pounds of gore, but by holding your breath as terror unfolds as slowly as a rose.  The actors - especially Kathy Bates - do an amazing job, making it hard to believe that this was not really happening.  The truly frightening part is that it is not such an implausible scenario.Personally, I loved the book.  Watching this brilliant movie makes you appreciate the nuances of the book even more as they come to life on the screen.

reviews.review_title: My Favorite Movie of All Time!
reviews.content: A few weeks ago I read the book by Stephen King, and it was overwhelming. The next week I rented Misery and watched it for the first time and loved it. This is without a doubt my favorite movie. Even before I saw this movie I loved Kathy Bates, She is my favorite actress. Everything about this movie is wonderful, It's definitely one of the best Stephen King adaptations ever, right next to Stephen King's The Shining. Don't rent it, Buy it today!!

There are very few flaws in this film. As horror films go it eats most others alive.Paul Sheldon (James Caan) is an author, most notably for his 'Misery' series. During a blizzard his car goes off the road and crashes. He is 'rescued' by Annie Wilkes (Cathy Bates), who happens to be his number 1 fan, and nursed back to health. Soon it becomes apparent that Annie is unstable and obsessed with Paul, and Paul finds himself crippled, drugged and unable to leave.This is a truly creepy film as it contains a large amount of realism, both in the scenario and the characters, and a particular scene that will make even the hardest person cringe.Tension and suspense combined with terrific, convincing performances make a true horror film, and one much more disturbing than screaming teens, 2D characters and CGI limbs flying. A true masterpiece of cinema. *****

reviews.review_title: The story behind Annie Wilkes in 'Misery'
reviews.content: The story 'behind' the writing of Misery is indeed an interesting one. Stephen King said that Misery was the book with which he wrote himself out of addiction. (10 grams of coke & a case of tallboys a day!!!!) Kathy Bates' character Annie is coke and booze, and no matter how hard he tried, he just couldn't get away (ie, get out of bed and escape in the story). Finally, somehow, without rehab, he simply said 'enough' and quit drinking and drugging. Anyone who has been through this or watched someone go through it knows how insanely difficult it is to stop cold-turkey, especially when your habits are as seemingly inescapable as King's.

This movie is one of the most bone chilling movies I have every seen! It features Kathy Bates as a deranged fan and James Caan as a famous writer. Everything in life is alright for Paul Sheldon(Caan) until he crashes his car and wakes up inside the house of his number one fan, Annie Wilkes(Bates). Annie Wilkes soon shows Sheldon how much she really loves him and his number one bestseller and the main character(Misery). I highly recommend watching Misery if you like anything by Stephen King and anything with a huge element of suspense. You will watch as Paul Sheldon fights for his life inside the house of one who says she "loves" him. You will also watch as a detective tries tirelessly to find Sheldon before something worse can happen to him. You will watch one of the most suspenseful tales by King on screen. Enjoy!

I found the characterisations probably the best aspect of the film, with great performances from both James Caan and Kathy Bates. Paul's frustration and desperation to leave his confines makes for quite a gripping watch, although there are some parts of the plot which may be a little slow moving for some people's taste. I suppose as time moves on, some film viewers may be more impatient than those of the past perhaps. The topic/theme of obsessive fans is, if anything, more relevant or contemporary than ever in the age of social media, I reckon and so it makes for a somewhat thought provoking watch as well. The presence of the typewriter made me think of The Shining (also based on a Stephen King novel), only in this instance its not the villain who uses it, rather the victim.

Although the charm of "Misery" may be a challenge to concisely pin down, its power is undeniable; it has kept me coming back to the film countless times over the years regardless of the story's notable imperfections. "Misery" would seem to have the makings of an enjoyable albeit unexceptional horror experience, yet few of even the best films are so incredibly amenable to repeated viewings. I never tire of it, and returning to it feels akin to visiting a reliable old friend. Scrutiny may reveal the scattered sources of the underlying secret to its allure; the performances are iconic and memorable, the scenario is obviously a personal one for Stephen King, the suspense is palpable, and the setting confers the charm and the danger of quiet isolation. Then, of course, there is the stunning creation which is Annie Wilkes and the frighteningly off-kilter manner in which Kathy Bates animates her on the screen. It may also be noted that a comic element belies the film's horror, always enrapturing us in a fashion that simultaneously scares and welcomes us. As the title of the film suggests, misery is certainly the name of the game for poor Paul Sheldon, but for the rest of us, the misnomer couldn't be more apparent.
It is to be applauded this masterpiece, a modest budget with spectacular performances and faithful to the book.

After collaborating on The Princess Bride, director Rob Reiner and writer William Goldman changed direction with their adaptation of Stephen King's Misery.  After completing his latest romance novel, author Paul Sheldon (James Caan) accidently drives his car off a mountain road in snowy Colorado.  Rescued by former nurse Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates, who gives a remarkable performance as the unhinged Wilkes), he soon finds himself held captive in her remote rural home and engaged in a cat and mouse game of survival.  While there are portions in the middle of the film that sometimes feel like they drag, it is a suspenseful thriller with one iconic scene that will leave your legs aching long after it's over.

Along with The Shawshank Redemption and Stand By Me, Misery is one of the best adaptations of Stephen King's work. On its own terms too, it is a brilliant film with a wonderful atmosphere especially. The film looks very good, with the sets, costumes, locations and cinematography striking and suitably atmospheric. The screenplay is very fine, exploring themes such as fanatical devotion, artistic dilemmas and worthiness of commercial fiction without a psychological suspense context, while the story is always well paced and compelling.

Also outstanding is the direction of Rob Reiner. He adeptly exercises in chilling claustrophobia and allows a numerous numbers of genuine jolts. The acting is great, James Caan, Richard Farnsworth and Lauren Bacall are all great but the film belongs to Kathy Bates who is monstrously scary and deservedly won an Oscar for her brilliant performance.

Overall, Misery is a superb film and one of the best Stephen King adaptations. 10/10 Bethany Cox

With sharp direction by Rob Reiner, a screenplay by William Goldman adapted from a novel by Stephen King, cinematography by Barry Sonnenfeld, and a cast that includes Lauren Bacall, Richard Farnsworth, James Caan, and Kathy Bates there's little wonder how Misery turned out so well. Even with all of this talent behind and in front of the camera, the key to Misery's success is the phenomenal and chilling performance by Kathy Bates as Annie Wilkes, one of the most memorable and frightening non-supernatural horror movie villains.

Author Paul Sheldon (Caan), famous for writing a series of novels set in the 19th century featuring a heroine named Misery, is badly injured in a car accident during a snowstorm in rural Colorado. Fortunately, he's rescued by a former nurse who also happens to be his "number one fan," Annie Wilkes. She tells Paul that the road to hospital is blocked by snow but as the winter rolls on Paul realizes that Annie is dangerous and he is a prisoner.

The situation Paul finds himself trapped in is grim, but the film itself is not thanks to the still fresh feeling approach to the material. There are moments of dark humor peppered throughout that at times border on absurdist but are welcome breaks to the tension. They also help ground the story in the real world, where humor slips in at the strangest times in the strangest ways.

Annie and Paul are both clever and resourceful characters which really ratchets up the tension. We think one character has the upper hand, then the situation flips in a believable way. We're always rooting for Paul to outsmart Annie but we know he has his work cut out for him. Scenes of Paul's agent (Lauren Becall) in New York and the local sheriff (Richard Farnsworth) in Colorado keep the film from being claustrophobic and add to the tension as we wait for someone to figure out what has really happened to Paul.

A very well played and uniquely scary scene, which also has humorous undertones, happens when Annie explains to Paul why he can't just change the ending to the last "Misery" book to fit the new one she is forcing him to write. Her reasoning is so clear and logical, and her disdain for being condescended to as an audience member is so intense, that it makes her all the more frightening. Tricks and plot holes won't work on her; Paul will have to be extra clever to outsmart her.

Perhaps the most famous scene in Misery is the "hobbling" scene. Annie has discovered that Paul has broken out of his locked room and explored the house. She holds a sledgehammer and calmly and meticulously explains the purpose and method of "hobbling." The scene is set to Beethoven's hypnotic "Moonlight" sonata, a perfect choice. There is no blood and you don't have to look hard to see the special effect, but the scene is heart pounding and shocking nonetheless. I still jump or look away every time. Overall, Misery is not an especially bloody movie which makes the few scenes of violence even more effective and shocking. Aside from the "hobbling" scene, maybe the most famous moment of Misery is the shot of Annie's face coming into focus as Paul regains consciousness from the car wreck. It's an unforgettable introduction.

In a rare instance of the Academy Awards recognizing and honoring horror, Bates deservedly won the Oscar for Best Actress of 1990. Annie is never really likable but thanks to Bates, she is always interesting to watch and her swings from wholesome and vulnerable to psychotic and violent are believable and frightening. Even as she tortures Paul, you still believe her affection for him is real and that's what makes her so scary. She plays Annie Wilkes to such perfection that you can't imagine the character or the movie without her.

World famous author Paul Sheldon crashes his car whilst driving in a blizzard but is rescued by nurse and super-fan Annie Wilkes who has read everything he's ever published as well as reading and viewing every interview he's ever given. Sheldon finds himself trapped with multiple injuries included compound fractures to his legs meaning that he is immobile and dependent on Wilkes to care for him. She also tells him that the telephone lines and down and roads closed, both of which are lies. Things take a darker turn still when Wilkes goes and buys the latest book by Sheldon which has just been published (yes the road to town has mysteriously been reopened but there's no mention of Wilkes taking Paul to a local hospital) only to discover that her favourite character Misery has died during childbirth. Wilkes isn't happy about this. This is bad news for Sheldon. 

Misery explores the obsessive, irrational fan devotion that was explored in very different circumstances in Scorsese's meisterwerk The King of Comedy, a film that bombed at the box office whilst Misery was a huge hit but is inferior in comparison. Oh, the irony.

Before seeing Misery for the first time I had read and thoroughly enjoyed Stephen King's masterful novel of the same name. The film adaptation feels like the finer nuances of the novel have been erased to make a big screen shocker that contains great performances by Kathy Bates (Wilkes) and James Caan (Sheldon) with Paul's literary agent being portrayed effortlessly by the ever divine Lauren Bacall.

But the film also feels like some kind of TV movie that lacks not just the depth of King's novel but also the cinematic grandeur that might have been envisaged and realised by another director other than Rob Reiner. 

Misery feels like an attempt to hit big at the box office by creating two dimensional characters and cheap shocks rather than delivering anything with real intelligence. And it worked. Misery brought in the money and earned Bates an Oscar. But watch Misery next to other, better King adaptations such as The Shining and Carrie and you'll see what I mean. There's no comparison.

Review: 
‘Misery' is an American psychological-horror film directed by Rob Reiner. It is based on Stephen King's novel of the same name. It's been a while since I seen this movie and I've got to say that I didn't love it as much as I remember I did. I mean, it's a great claustrophobic thriller with some great performances. It just didn't have the same feel it did when I first watched it years ago.
The plot revolves around a famous writer, Paul Sheldon (James Caan), who gets into a car wreck and is saved and seems to be nursed back to health by a woman, Annie (Kathy Bates) who claims to be his number one fan. After ready a copy of his latest release in his famous ‘Misery' book series, and finding out her favorite character was killed, Annie makes Paul write another story to bring her favorite character back to life, while also making his life a living hell.
Everybody talks about Kathy Bates's performance in this movie, and while it is a scary and good take on Annie Wilkes, James Caan is break takingly good as the writer Paul Sheldon. In every helpless scene he is in where he is trying to escape or showing us how much pain, he is in when going in and out of his wheelchair. I was seriously in awe watching him work this character into his own creation.
I love the camera work in this movie. I expected to because it is a Rob Reiner film, but he is so good behind a camera. He uses long and wide shots for extremely simple scenes. By that I mean it could just a be man sitting in the library looking up information and the angle he uses is so beautifully shot. Where the movie lacks is in its scare department. This is supposed to be a horror movie after all or at least a thriller, but where I see it, it's just a drama movie that has intense scenes. That's not to say the movie is bad or anything, just if your going to serve me a slice of lemon pie, make sure I taste the lemon.
Overall, this movie shows that Stephen King is more than just a weird horror author that only writes about creepy monsters or supernatural elements. It still has a feel on a movie he would produce, but with a certain zest added to it.

I hadn't seen this film in years and wasn't quite sure how it would hold up, but it remains a strong example of a chamber-piece horror film that excels at slow burn horror and suspense. James Caan plays romance novelist Paul Sheldon, who's in a horrific snowbound car wreck, but is "rescued" by his #1 fan Annie Wilkes, played by Kathy Bates in a brilliant and terrifying performance. Sheldon soon realizes his savior is in reality holding him captive, but there is little he can do due to the remoteness of her house and his wheelchair bound state. What ensues is a game of cat-and-mouse between Caan and Bates that is suspenseful, frightening, and utterly thrilling. The film is tightly directed by Rob Reiner ("Stand by Me" "A Few Good Men" "The Princess Bride" "When Harry Met Sally") and is smartly scripted by William Goldman ("Magic" "Marathon Man" and the under-appreciated "Dreamcatcher," along with non-genre classics like "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" "All the President's Men" and "The Princess Bride") based on a Stephen King novel of the name. Goldman's script gets major kudos for making this chamber piece horror film believable. Sheldon is an intelligent character and Goldman has him try all of the things an intelligent person would do in order to try to escape, which makes the situation all the more terrifying. Caan is perfectly cast in the role of Sheldon, a tough guy macho on-screen personality who finds himself uncharacteristically laid low, making this plights all the more disconcerting. But it's Bates who steals the show as Sheldon's obsessed and deranged fan, determined to keep Sheldon all to herself at any cost. There are few other characters in the story, but the actors in those roles are equally memorable. Richard Farnsworth is excellent as a small-town sheriff investigating Sheldon's disappearance, as is Frances Sternhagen who plays his wife. It's also a treat to see Lauren Bacall in a small supporting role as Sheldon's publisher, but for the most part, the film is all Caan and Bates. Overall, "Misery" is a class act of a horror movie, which is a rare occurrence, and is essential viewing for fans King, Caan, Bates, or of horror films or thrillers in general. SPOILER ALERT! The hobbling scene still shocks today and is just as cringe inducing as ever.

Horror has never been my favorite genre because I do not really have the desire to put myself through a situation that will provoke fear and pain in me. I decided to watch this film however because so many of my friends who did not like horror really enjoyed it and had a lot of praise for the performances of Kathy Bates and James Caan. I am glad that I followed their advice and decided to watch this entertaining, suspenseful little film that rests on it's central performer, Bates, who is able to deliver an Academy Award worthy performance. I would recommend this film despite it not necessarily being to my personal tastes because it absolutely achieves what a film of  it's genre should and I enjoyed it in spite of myself.

Writer Paul Sheldon, James Caan, is famed for a series of novels he has written that follow the adventures of a Southern Belle called Misery Chastain. He heads to Silver Creek Lodge, a holiday town in a secluded location, to finish writing the final novel in the series in which Chastain will die. He has a horrible car crash that breaks both of his legs when driving back to New York City and finds himself in the care of suspicious nurse Annie Wilkes, Kathy Bates, who calls herself his "Number one fan." He slowly realizes that Wilkes is more sinister than she initially appeared and her anger at the death of Chastain in his draft of the book leads to a horrific series of events.

The film works both as a traditional horror film with a villain being slowly revealed in the lead up to a dramatic, bloody climax and more interestingly as a commentary on the difficulties of being famous and dealing with fanatics. It is easy to be charmed by Wilkes initially because we in the audience relate to her more than we relate to the successful and famous Sheldon. We all idolize some famous person who we hope to meet and because she appears helpful and kind at first we are willing to accept the slightly creepy statements she makes about having watched Sheldon work. When she becomes a full on evil psychopath we are almost upset because she had been the person we could most identify with on screen and we were rooting for her to gain respect from a man who she so desperately wants to prove herself to.

Obviously Reiner is very skilled at building suspense in the scenes in which we witness Sheldon plot to murder Wilkes with various items found around the house while he keeps an eye on her in fear of her catching him. The hobbling scene is deserving of it's iconic status as everybody winces in pain when watching it and the sight of Caan sweating while rolling around in a wheelchair is surprisingly effective. These scenes were probably the least interesting to me as they felt like something out of a very traditional horror film and while I know these scenes are necessary to please the fanatics of Stephen King they felt a bit generic at times. 

Bates completely inhabits her role as she gives a very over the top, hammy performance but she fits the tone of the film overall and is simultaneously disturbing and sad. We are convinced by her warm bedside manner and luminous smile that she is a good person and Bates makes the shift very believable as she is chilling in the soup scene. Just the sight of her face giving a wide grimace towards the end of the film is terrifying and that is a testament to Bates' power as an actress. Caan is also very good giving the less showy performance as he gives an impressive physical performance with the audience feeling his pain through every gritting of his teeth and widening of his eyes. The two together are a wonderful pairing as they have an odd chemistry of sorts with Bates being willfully disobedient of Caan's lack of interest in her and Caan seeming ill at ease throughout, we enjoy spending time in the company of these characters because these two make them so interesting and so worth watching.

Adapted from Stephen King's 1987 novel, Misery tells the story of bestselling author, Paul Sheldon (James Caan), rescued from the wreckage of a near fatal car crash by his "No.1 fan" the seemingly solicitous Annie Wilkes. What follows is typical King fare, a psychological game of cat and mouse that ranges from the surprisingly droll to the disturbingly brutal.
As Stephen King adaptations go, Misery is fairly well done, a faithful if slightly pacified version of a story that naturally hooks us in. It's really elevated by two fantastic lead performances with James Caan playing captive writer Sheldon with an understated brilliance. The real stand out, however, comes from Kathy Bates (an Oscar winner for her role), who plays the unpredictable Annie with a remarkable level of complexity and realism. A subplot involving Richard Farnsworth's Sheriff meanders along, but the bulk of the film is a two-player game, complete with scenes of biting tension, sporadic violence and unnerving tenderness. Marc Shaiman's score adds a chilling touch that suits the film's slow build from the typical to the terrifying.
There are enough gems of excitement in Misery to keep us interested (even at a slightly stretched 107-minute run time), but the film lacks both the introspection and horror of its source material. There are moments of greatness (the famous "hobbling" scene springs to mind), but much of the film is approached with a heavy-handedness, never as clever nor as scary as it seems to think it is. Nevertheless, the film remains pretty much consistently entertaining, with just enough surprises to keep it afloat. 
In the end, Misery may be rather uninspired, but it's a loyal and well-crafted adaptation of a good story, elevated by a scintillating central performance from Kathy Bates.

I must mention the nice supporting roles from Richard Farnsworth, Frances Sternhagen, and Lauren Bacall. Farnsworth is the quintessential small town sheriff with a quaint charm. His sincerity and intrigue adds some joy and suspense to Misery. I think The Coen Brothers must have seen Misery to inspire their similar detective in Fargo (1996). Misery is alike Fargo in its local mystery alongside the enclosed insanity of The Shining (1980).

In short, Misery is a well directed film that depicts how depraved fans can resort to if unchecked by decency. It is as upsetting and humorous as the first time I watched it. You will be rooting for Caan the entire time. So sit back and endure the pain of Misery.

From director Rob Reiner comes the intense suspense thriller Misery.  Based on a Stephen King novel, the story follows famed novelist Paul Sheldon who's rescued from a car crash by an obsessed fan; but things take a dark turn when he discovers that he's being drugged and is locked in his room.  James Caan and Kathy Bates both give strong performances; particularly Bates, who does a good job at subtly moving from eccentric fan and psychopath.  And Reiner effectively builds tension and suspense quite well; especially in showing Sheldon's captivity and isolation.  Still, there are some problems with the script, such as the underdeveloped subplot of the sheriff's investigation and the rushed conclusion.  Yet despite its flaws, Misery is a frightening horror film.

I just finished watching the movie and it was spectacular! It's one of those films that gets under your skin which is what a good psychological thriller should do. The pacing is perfect from beginning to end and nothing feels out of place, you get just the right amount of suspense and action. The acting from the two leads is fantastic and they both help to get us sucked into every celebrity's worst nightmare. As a writer myself I especially sympathize with James Caan's character and how he is deprived of his freedom of expression and mobility just to please a psychotic and prudish fan of his (played brilliantly by Kathy Bates). Kathy's character seems to serve as a bit of a personification of fan bases in general, praising and adoring an artist's work when it meets their arbitrary, often contradictory expectations, while going crazy when that artist decides to change things up and create something that challenges his intended audience. The terror Paul Sheldon is forced to endure becomes all the more nail-biting as Annie Wilkes seemingly loses more of her sanity as the film progresses (or at least does away with the facade of sanity), and it builds up to a satisfying climax. I can't believe I hadn't seen this movie before but I'm very glad that I did! Will definitely rewatch it in the future.

Misery is directed by Rob Reiner, and it stars James Caan and Kathy Bates in a Stephen King adaptation about an author who accidentally got himself in a car crash, but got rescued by his number 1 fan Anne Wilkes (Kathy Bates) and wanted to see his next book that he's writing. When she didn't like what happened, she goes on psycho on Paul Sheldon (James Caan) and keeps him inside her house. In his young years, Rob Reiner used to be a big deal in terms of the films that he has made, but then he starts to slips away in his films that people wonder ask, what happened to Rob Reiner? When I watch his past films to see how it came to be, even though I didn't like This Is Spinal Tap, I come to a realization that he just surrounded himself with talented writers that know how to write a film, whether it be from Aaron Sorkin for A Few Good Men and The American President, Nora Ephron for When Harry Met Sally..., and William Goldman for The Princess Bride, and this movie. James Caan did a great job acting like a calm person trying to go through with the situation that he's in, while dealing with the pain of his legs. Kathy Bates did a fantastic job of her performance as a big fan of the author that is nice in one hand, but the other way she goes complete crazy, and also get depressed too in one scene, which I'm glad she got the Academy Award for it. The writing by William Goldman is really good that understands how scary people can be when they are a bit too obsessed with who they enjoy reading their books. It gets pretty tense at times as you really want the author to get out of her house despite his legs being in pain, and it can be hard to watch at times, but in a good way that makes you more invested in this. There were some moments that I was disinterested, but I still had a great time watching this film that it's one of the creepiest Stephen King adaptations that I've seen.

"Misery" is kind of like "The Shining" lite - both are set in the winter, both have writers as the central characters, and both have villains that are totally insane. There are obvious differences; in "The Shining" of course the writer is the one who goes crazy, there are numerous supernatural elements that aren't present in "Misery", and "Misery" doesn't exactly have the visual or philosophical depth that Kubrick brought to "The Shining".

Still, Rob Reiner's film is a very entertaining and often terrifying study of obsession, and its simplistic themes about Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates)' over-infatuation with Paul Sheldon (James Caan) still have a lot of relevance today in our age of fandoms and #Cut4Zayn / #Cut4Bieber. 

Kathy Bates won the Oscar for her performance - the only Oscar ever won for a movie based on a Stephen King work - and so it's no surprise that her performance is hauntingly effective. James Caan is also great in his role as the writer. His performance is mainly physical, as many scenes are devoted to him trying to escape his imprisonment (Wilkes takes him in after he crashes his car during a snow storm, and pretends to "care" for him before forcing him to write her a new book to her liking). 

It's a well-edited and nicely framed movie, though most of the entertainment value is down to the bare-bones, quickly-paced script and the committed performances from the leads. Richard Farnsworth and Frances Sternhagen are also great as the local sheriff and his wife, respectively, who attempt to figure out where Paul has gone after he's declared missing. The comic rapport between the two characters reminded me a bit of the characters played by Frances McDormand and John Carroll Lynch in "Fargo", though with a slightly more sarcastic tone. It's hard not to root for the small-town sheriffs in these films, anyways.

Wow, has Misery really been around for almost 25 years? It is a superb story of an author who gets in a bad car accident and then is dragged to "safety" by his his #1 fan. This is one of those films that I wish I could have seen without knowing anything about it, because that gradual turn the story takes from a simple drama into an all-out thriller is very subtle. It is such a great slow burn as you actually realize along with Paul Sheldon, that perhaps Annie Wilkes isn't his savior. In fact my only real complaint is that, when you know what's coming, it can seem like it is taking too long to get there. But once Annie shows her darker side the tension is heightened in every single scene. One of my favorite aspects is the fact that Paul over time starts to understand how Annie's mind works and he uses that knowledge to manipulate her into doing things she might not have anyways. It is a very unusual relationship because it starts out so gentle from both sides and in her mind the gentleness never goes away despite his growing paranoia, anger, and fear.

James Caan delivers an excellent performance as Paul Sheldon. I'm always complimenting actors when they perform in such a way that we can tell just through expression what they're thinking, and this is one of those times when it is nearly flawless. I also had to continue reminding myself that he was just pretending to be crippled because he did a great job of dragging his legs around like they were broken. Of course the real master stroke of Misery is Kathy Bates. Holy cow, does she ever deliver a terrifying performance. In those later scenes she says some things in the sweetest tone you can imagine and yet they give me the chills because I can feel the underlying threat. This might be one of the best films adapted from a Stephen King novel. If you have not seen Misery, hopefully I haven't spoiled it too much for you, because this is one I would recommend you check out. It still holds up 25 years later, because the story of obsession is somewhat timeless.

"A NUMBER ONE FAN"  

- 'Misery' is a 1990 psychological thriller based on the novel by bestselling author Stephen King. No people with psychic powers or alien creatures; this film shines in its simplicity: a writer is rescued by his number one fan, who turns out to be his worst nightmare. A lot of great actors turned down the role of Paul Sheldon, before James Caan accepted. All credits must go to the wonderful performance of Kathy Bates, a the psychotic Annie Wilkes. She won an Academy Award and Golden Globe for best Actress. Enjoy the movie, and remember: Not all friendly faces are trustworthy... 

Successful author of the Misery Chastain-series Paul Sheldon (Caan) has been staying at a remote lodge in the snowy mountains, waiting for the release of his latest book and working on a new manuscript. Heading home he is surprised by a blizzard and crashes with his car. When Paul regains consciousness, he finds himself in a bed with his wounded legs and shoulder taken care of by a nurse called Annie Wilkes (Bates), who rescued him. Because of the heavy snow, she took him to her house. As gratitude and because Annie claims to be his number one fan, he lets her read his new manuscript. The woman admits she doesn't like it as much as the 'Misery'-books. When the following day Annie comes home from shopping, she has brought a copy of Paul's latest book. Excited she starts to read it.  But when Annie learns that her favorite character dies in the end, she's in a total rage. Paul is no longer her patient. He's her prisoner...

Deserving of its praise as one of the best Stephen King adaptations, Misery is a well-written and crafted thriller. Kathy Bates is disturbingly well-suited to her role as obsessed fan Annie Wilkes, and James Caan is fitting as well in his role as the writer of the "Misery" novels, Paul Sheldon. The elements are all in place to be claustrophobic and have an appropriate amount of thrills, and even to show the situations that can arise when fans go too far. Admittedly the premise is convenient to the character of Annie, living not so far away from Paul's writing cabin and being a former nurse, but it partly contributes to the deranged circumstances the two find--and put--themselves in.

MISERY works on many levels, but most particularly in the performances.  The obvious standout is Kathy Bates' Oscar-winning turn as the psychotic and slightly tragic Annie Wilkes, a bubbly celebrity stalker prone to severe mood swings and a vicious mean streak.  Her unreal cheeriness clearly disguises something, so from the moment she appears, there's a feeling of tension.  The cheery facade is quite thin though, and the devil within bubbles up unpredictably, yet the viewer is unlikely to be entirely unsympathetic toward her severe depression.  James Caan plays her victim, and even as his performance rarely leaves a bed or a wheelchair, he conveys his character's plight effectively.  An unfortunately less remembered performance is Richard Farnsworth as the local sheriff investigating the disappearance of Cann's character, who provides a healthy amount of wry humor to the dark proceedings.  Also of note is the chilling cinematography by Barry Sonnenfeld, especially as the shots focus on Bates' face during her wrathful tantrums.  William Goldman, who wrote the script, was originally most excited to have Bates chop off Caan's feet with an ax in the infamous "hobbling" scene, but while plenty of feet have been seen cut off, the image of a sledgehammer knocking a foot well out of a natural position is not easily forgotten.
If there was just one reason to watch this film, it would be Kathy Bates' performance. No character will ever make your heart race as much as she does.
